questions.stem: Which action BEST meets minimum patient identification practice before starting EEG?
options: Confirm identity by face recognition only
Use two identifiers (e.g., full name and DOB) and match to the order
Ask a caregiver only, without checking documentation
Start recording and confirm identity after electrodes are applied
questions.explanation: Two identifiers matched to the order reduces wrong-patient procedures.

questions.stem: An EEG order is missing the clinical indication. The MOST appropriate technologist action is:
options: Create an indication based on your impression
Clarify the indication through appropriate channels and document the clarification
Cancel the EEG without notifying anyone
questions.explanation: Indication guides strategy; clarify and document—do not invent diagnoses.

questions.stem: The order reads 'routine EEG' but the patient is actively convulsing in the ED. The technologist should:
options: Proceed as routine and do not alert anyone
Recommend immediate physician evaluation and follow urgent/emergency lab protocol
Refuse to perform any EEG ever in the ED
questions.explanation: Recognize urgency and follow institutional escalation; patient safety first.

questions.stem: Which is the BEST documentation when patient identity was initially mismatched but corrected before recording?
options: Do not mention it to avoid confusion
Document the discrepancy, how it was resolved, and confirm correct identifiers before proceeding
Delete the order and create a new one without explanation
Proceed and mention it only verbally later
questions.explanation: Transparent documentation supports safety, auditability, and continuity of care.

questions.stem: Which element MOST directly supports legal defensibility of the EEG record?
options: Accurate identifiers and time-stamped documentation of key actions
A longer recording regardless of quality
Using a notch filter on every study
questions.explanation: Accurate identification and documentation are core medicolegal standards.

questions.stem: Which environment factor MOST commonly contributes to non-cerebral electrical artifact during EEG?
options: Nearby powered equipment and poor grounding
questions.explanation: Electrical devices/grounding issues can introduce line noise.

questions.stem: Before taking the EEG cart into an isolation room, the FIRST priority is to:
options: Prepare PPE and follow isolation/infection-control requirements
Skip electrode prep to save time
questions.explanation: Infection-control compliance is a safety requirement.

questions.stem: A new 50/60 Hz artifact appears after plugging the cart into a different outlet. BEST next step:
options: Immediately label it as cerebral fast activity
Check ground integrity, outlet, nearby devices, and lead placement before using notch
questions.explanation: Fix source first; notch is secondary and can distort EEG.

questions.stem: Which practice MOST helps prevent 'electrode pop' artifact?
options: Secure electrode attachment with appropriate prep and stable leads
questions.explanation: Good skin prep and stable electrode/lead setup reduces intermittent contact artifacts.

questions.stem: Which item is MOST essential to confirm before starting recording?
options: That the room has music playing
That adequate storage/recording space is available on the EEG system
That photic will definitely be abnormal
questions.explanation: Insufficient storage can compromise the entire study.

questions.stem: Effective patient rapport MOST directly reduces which recording problem?
options: Behavioral/movement artifact from anxiety or poor cooperation
questions.explanation: Calm patients move less and tolerate activations better.

questions.stem: A patient is fearful that electrodes 'shock'. BEST response:
options: Explain electrodes only record brain signals and do not deliver electricity; reassure and answer questions
Promise the EEG will be normal
Tell them to ask the interpreter later
questions.explanation: Clear education improves cooperation and reduces anxiety-driven artifact.

questions.stem: For a child with ASD who resists touch, the BEST approach is to:
options: Use stepwise desensitization, caregiver involvement, and breaks while maintaining safety
questions.explanation: Accommodations and rapport improve success and reduce distress.

questions.stem: Which is MOST appropriate documentation of patient cooperation?
options: Objective description (e.g., limited cooperation; HV not completed; frequent movement)
questions.explanation: Objective language supports interpretation and professionalism.

questions.stem: The technologist should encourage patient questions primarily to:
questions.explanation: Understanding improves cooperation and safety.

questions.stem: Which instruction MOST improves yield for a sleep-deprived EEG?
options: Use hair oil before the test
Avoid sleep prior to the study as directed
questions.explanation: Sleep deprivation increases likelihood of sleep during recording.

questions.stem: A patient asks whether to stop antiseizure medication before EEG. BEST response:
options: Follow the ordering provider's instructions; generally continue usual meds unless directed otherwise
questions.explanation: Medication changes are provider-directed; technologist follows orders/policy.

questions.stem: Which is MOST important to include when explaining photic stimulation?
options: That it uses flashing light to assess photic driving and may rarely provoke abnormalities; patient can request to stop
That it replaces the need for EEG electrodes
That it is only for children
questions.explanation: Accurate explanation supports informed cooperation and safety.

questions.stem: Which consent-related statement is MOST accurate?
options: Consent is optional if a doctor ordered EEG
Patients have the right to refuse; refusal should be respected and documented per policy
Technologists may coerce cooperation for better data
Refusal should be ignored if the patient is anxious
questions.explanation: Patient autonomy and documentation are essential.

questions.stem: Pre-test hair preparation is important primarily because:
options: It reduces impedance and improves signal quality
questions.explanation: Clean scalp/hair improves electrode contact and signal quality.

questions.stem: Which history element is MOST important to document for event correlation?
options: Time of last clinical event and description of behaviors
questions.explanation: Timing and semiology guide correlation and strategy.

questions.stem: Medication documentation is MOST complete when it includes:
options: Dose and time of last dose
questions.explanation: Dose/timing affect EEG background and yield.

questions.stem: Which history item MOST helps assess HV safety?
options: Known cardiopulmonary disease or relevant contraindications per policy
questions.explanation: Contraindications screening supports safe activation.

questions.stem: A patient had a seizure 'sometime last week' with unclear details. BEST documentation approach:
options: Write 'seizure yesterday' to make it specific
Document uncertainty and obtain best available description from patient/caregiver/records
questions.explanation: Accurate documentation includes uncertainty—avoid fabrication.

questions.stem: Documenting skull defects is important because it can:
questions.explanation: Skull defects can change recorded amplitude and field distribution.

questions.stem: Which statement is MOST accurate about electrode placement?
options: If impedance is low, placement accuracy is guaranteed
10–20 measurement accuracy is required for reliable localization
Placement can be estimated if the patient is asleep
Electrode location does not affect interpretation
questions.explanation: Localization depends on accurate 10–20 placement.

questions.stem: Persistently similar waveforms across adjacent channels with unusually low impedances MOST suggests:
questions.explanation: Bridging electrically connects electrodes and distorts localization.

questions.stem: Best practice for impedance management is to:
options: Ignore impedance values if tracing looks clean
Achieve acceptable impedances per lab policy and recheck after patient movement
Increase sweep speed to hide noise
questions.explanation: Stable impedances reduce artifact and improve quality.

questions.stem: A reference electrode becomes intermittently loose. The MOST likely effect is:
options: Widespread distortion across referential channels and potential false asymmetries
questions.explanation: Reference instability can contaminate multiple channels.

questions.stem: Which documentation is MOST helpful if a non-standard electrode position was used?
options: No mention; interpreter will infer it
Diagram/annotation of the change on the recording and in technical notes
Change montage labels to hide it
questions.explanation: Deviations must be documented for correct interpretation.

questions.stem: Which change MOST likely attenuates slow waves and masks diffuse slowing?
options: Raising the low-frequency filter too high
questions.explanation: Higher LFF removes slow activity and can hide slowing.

questions.stem: Which change can make the EEG APPEAR to have higher-frequency activity without changing true cerebral frequency?
questions.explanation: Sweep speed changes display scaling and can mislead perception.

questions.stem: The notch filter is BEST used when:
options: Only when needed after attempting to correct the noise source
questions.explanation: Notch can distort EEG; address source first.

questions.stem: Reducing sensitivity (higher µV/mm) MOST likely causes:
options: Low-amplitude activity to appear smaller and potentially be under-appreciated
questions.explanation: Lower sensitivity compresses amplitude display.

questions.stem: Which setting change MOST risks distorting spike morphology?
questions.explanation: Too low HFF smooths sharp transients and can blunt spikes.

questions.stem: Why are montage changes important during routine EEG?
options: They can clarify localization and confirm suspicious discharges
They eliminate the need for activation
They are only for normal EEGs
questions.explanation: Different montages reveal fields and help confirm true discharges.

questions.stem: Phase reversal in a bipolar montage is MOST useful for:
options: Identifying the site of maximal negativity
questions.explanation: Phase reversal helps localize maximal negativity.

questions.stem: A sharp transient appears only in one channel in a referential montage. BEST next step:
options: Review in multiple montages and check for field/phase reversal and artifact sources
questions.explanation: Confirm with montage changes and artifact review.

questions.stem: Which montage often helps detect lateralized slowing most clearly?
options: A montage that provides good interhemispheric comparison (e.g., bipolar longitudinal)
questions.explanation: Side-by-side comparisons are strong in bipolar longitudinal chains.

questions.stem: Recording strategy should be modified primarily based on:
questions.explanation: Patient context and indication drive strategy.

questions.stem: Hyperventilation was omitted due to poor cooperation. What should be done?
options: Document HV omission and the reason
questions.explanation: If an activation is omitted, document why.

questions.stem: Which response during photic stimulation is MOST expected in normal subjects?
questions.explanation: Photic driving is a normal physiologic response.

questions.stem: A patient becomes dizzy during HV. BEST action:
options: Force HV to complete full 3 minutes
Stop HV, ensure safety, document symptoms and duration achieved
questions.explanation: Safety first; stop if needed and document.

questions.stem: Sleep was ordered but not achieved. BEST documentation is:
options: Document that sleep was attempted, not achieved, and why
State that sleep was recorded anyway
questions.explanation: Accurate recording state is essential for interpretation.

questions.stem: Eye opening/closure is performed primarily to assess:
questions.explanation: EO/EC tests reactivity and helps confirm posterior rhythm.

questions.stem: High-frequency 'fuzzy' activity that increases with jaw clenching MOST suggests:
questions.explanation: EMG increases with muscle tension.

questions.stem: A rhythmic waveform time-locked to the QRS complex most likely represents:
questions.explanation: ECG artifact can contaminate EEG channels.

questions.stem: Which is BEST practice for line noise?
options: Use notch only if needed and correct causes first
questions.explanation: Notch can distort; correct the source first.

questions.stem: Sweat artifact typically appears as:
options: Slow baseline drift that improves with cooling/drying
questions.explanation: Sweat causes slow drift and unstable baselines.

questions.stem: A single channel shows intermittent high-amplitude sharp transients with no field and coinciding with head movement. MOST likely:
questions.explanation: Electrode movement causes pops without physiologic field.

questions.stem: K-complexes are MOST associated with:
questions.explanation: K-complexes are characteristic of N2.

questions.stem: Mu rhythm is MOST often seen over which region?
questions.explanation: Mu is central and may block with movement.

questions.stem: Which feature MOST supports that a temporal 'wicket' pattern is a benign variant?
options: Occurs in brief trains with arch-like morphology, no disruption of background, and no epileptiform field
questions.explanation: Wickets are benign variants lacking epileptiform features.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes focal slowing from generalized slowing?
options: Focal slowing is confined to a region and persists across montages; generalized slowing is diffuse and affects most channels
Focal slowing only occurs in sleep
Focal slowing cannot be seen in children
questions.explanation: Topography and consistency across montages are key.

questions.stem: A well-formed posterior dominant rhythm in an awake adolescent is MOST typically:
questions.explanation: Adolescent PDR is generally in alpha range.

questions.stem: During a suspected seizure event, which annotation is MOST useful?
options: Observed behaviors, responsiveness, onset/offset, and key phases
questions.explanation: Detailed clinical timing and behavior support correlation.

questions.stem: A prolonged convulsive seizure occurs during EEG. The technologist should FIRST:
options: Prioritize safety and follow emergency protocol (call help, protect from injury)
questions.explanation: Safety and escalation come first.

questions.stem: Documenting responsiveness during an event helps differentiate:
options: Artifact vs cerebral activity and seizure vs non-seizure events
questions.explanation: Clinical responsiveness is key for interpretation.

questions.stem: Best method to confirm whether rhythmic activity is artifact during an event is to:
options: Perform safe bedside maneuvers, check ECG channel, and review across montages for field
Assume it is seizure if rhythmic
questions.explanation: Artifact confirmation uses behavior correlation, ECG, and montage/field review.

questions.stem: Which is MOST appropriate to document when the patient has no visible clinical change but EEG shows a brief burst of generalized spike-wave?
options: Objective note: burst observed; no clinical change noted; patient remained responsive (if tested)
questions.explanation: Document objective EEG + clinical observation without diagnosis.

questions.stem: Which approach is MOST appropriate for neonatal EEG?
options: Customize montage/strategy for neonatal physiology and clinical context
questions.explanation: Neonates require tailored approach and age-specific expectations.

questions.stem: In ICU EEG, the BEST approach to high artifact burden is to:
options: Use very aggressive filters to 'clean' the tracing
Optimize electrodes/grounding, annotate artifacts, and keep filters conservative
Turn notch on permanently and ignore sources
questions.explanation: Preserve cerebral signals; troubleshoot source and document.

questions.stem: Which statement is MOST accurate about electrocerebral inactivity (ECI) EEG studies?
options: Any short routine EEG is sufficient
Strict technical criteria and protocol adherence are required and must be documented
ECI can be declared by technologist alone
questions.explanation: ECI studies are protocol-driven and require strict technical documentation.

questions.stem: A key risk of overly aggressive filtering during suspected ECI evaluation is:
options: Masking low-amplitude cerebral activity and creating false impression of inactivity
questions.explanation: Over-filtering can hide residual cerebral activity.

questions.stem: Special protocols are MOST important because they:
options: Match strategy to population/question, improving safety and yield
questions.explanation: Protocol tailoring improves safety and interpretability.

questions.stem: After electrode removal, the technologist should:
options: Send the patient away without checking comfort
Clean scalp per policy and ensure patient is comfortable/stable
Diagnose EEG findings to the patient
Discard all electrodes regardless of type
questions.explanation: Aftercare and safety are required; interpretation is not given by technologist.

questions.stem: A patient reports dizziness after standing post-EEG. BEST next step:
options: Ensure safety (sit/lay patient), seek assistance per policy, and document
questions.explanation: Patient safety and appropriate escalation/documentation are required.

questions.stem: Skin breakdown at electrode sites is MOST likely reduced by:
options: Gentle, appropriate prep and avoiding excessive abrasion; monitor vulnerable patients
questions.explanation: Appropriate prep and skin care reduce irritation.

questions.stem: Which aftercare statement is MOST appropriate when asked 'Was it normal?'
options: Explain that results are reviewed by the interpreting clinician; you can explain process/timeline
questions.explanation: Maintain scope: explain process, not interpretation.

questions.stem: The technologist should document post-study status especially when:
options: A clinical event occurred, patient required assistance, or condition changed
Only when the EEG is normal
questions.explanation: Status changes/events require documentation.

questions.stem: Which practice BEST matches infection-control standards?
options: Disinfect reusable electrodes per protocol and manufacturer guidance
Skip cleaning if study was short
Use only water regardless of policy
questions.explanation: Follow protocols and manufacturer guidance; do not reuse single-use items.

questions.stem: Hand hygiene is MOST critical:
options: Before and after patient contact and after removing gloves per policy
Only when the room is visibly dirty
questions.explanation: Standard infection control requires hand hygiene before/after contact.

questions.stem: Which is BEST for cleaning an EEG headbox/cables after a contact precaution case?
options: Use approved disinfectant compatible with equipment; follow dwell time and manufacturer instructions
Skip cleaning and rely on gloves
questions.explanation: Use approved methods to avoid damage and ensure disinfection.

questions.stem: A technologist notices a cracked electrode cup. BEST action:
options: Use it anyway if impedance is low
Remove from service and replace; document/notify per policy
questions.explanation: Damaged equipment may harbor pathogens and compromise safety/quality.

questions.stem: PPE selection should be based on:
options: Institutional policy, patient isolation status, and task exposure risk
Whether a bipolar montage is used
questions.explanation: PPE follows policy and exposure risk.

questions.stem: Which statement belongs in a technologist technical description?
options: This EEG proves frontal lobe epilepsy
HV not performed due to poor cooperation; photic unremarkable
questions.explanation: Technical notes document conditions and observations.

questions.stem: Which is MOST appropriate language for a behavioral event with no EEG correlate?
options: Clinical event observed; no clear EEG change identified during the event
questions.explanation: Describe observed event and EEG correlation without diagnosing.

questions.stem: A key goal of the technologist report is to:
options: Provide objective context that supports accurate interpretation
questions.explanation: Objective technical context improves interpretation.

questions.stem: If the system does not auto-document settings, the technologist should record at minimum:
options: Filters, sensitivity, montage changes, and notable adjustments affecting interpretation
questions.explanation: Settings materially affect what is seen and must be documented.

questions.stem: When an activation is omitted, the report should:
questions.explanation: Omission + reason is required documentation.

questions.stem: Which is BEST practice for EEG data management?
options: Store EEG on personal USB drives
Archive per institutional policy with confidentiality protections
questions.explanation: Use institutional systems and retention policies.

questions.stem: A technologist wants to show an interesting EEG to a friend outside the care team. BEST action:
options: Share it if the name is removed verbally
Do not share; maintain confidentiality and follow policy for educational use
Post it in a private group chat
Take a photo of the screen without identifiers
questions.explanation: Confidentiality rules apply even if identifiers seem removed.

questions.stem: Spike-detection software is BEST described as:
options: An assistive tool that requires expert review
questions.explanation: Software assists; expert review is required.

questions.stem: Which situation MOST requires extra care with data handling?
options: Video-EEG with patient face visible and embedded identifiers
questions.explanation: Video often contains direct identifiers; must be protected.

questions.stem: Retention and archiving rules are MOST determined by:
questions.explanation: Follow policy and legal requirements.

questions.stem: A patient requests to stop the EEG. The MOST appropriate action is to:
options: Continue because a doctor ordered it
Stop and follow policy; notify appropriate staff/provider and document refusal
questions.explanation: Respect autonomy; document and escalate per policy.

questions.stem: Which setting is MOST appropriate for discussing patient information?
options: Private setting with authorized team members
questions.explanation: Confidential information only with authorized staff in appropriate settings.

questions.stem: Which statement about patient consent is MOST accurate?
options: Consent is implied and never needed
Patients can withdraw consent at any time
Refusal should be ignored if anxious
Consent is only needed for photic
questions.explanation: Patients may withdraw consent; follow policy.

questions.stem: A family member demands the EEG conclusion immediately. BEST response:
options: Explain that the interpreting clinician provides results; you can explain process/timeline
Tell them it is normal to calm them
questions.explanation: Stay within scope and protect confidentiality.

questions.stem: Confidentiality includes protecting:
options: Any information that can identify a patient directly or indirectly
questions.explanation: Identifiers can be direct or indirect.

questions.stem: Which action BEST demonstrates working within scope of practice?
options: Providing a diagnosis to the family
Documenting technical observations and communicating concerns through proper channels
questions.explanation: Technologists provide technical info and escalate appropriately.

questions.stem: Objective documentation is BEST characterized by:
options: Neutral descriptions of behaviors and conditions affecting recording
questions.explanation: Objective notes support interpretation and professionalism.

questions.stem: Effective team communication during EEG is BEST described as:
options: Using accurate medical terminology and clear, timely reporting
questions.explanation: Clear, objective communication supports patient safety.

questions.stem: A technologist observes a pattern concerning for nonconvulsive seizures on ICU EEG (per lab role). BEST action:
options: Ignore until the end of shift
Follow lab escalation pathway to notify appropriate clinician promptly and document the notification
Tell the family the patient is seizing
Change filters to make it disappear
questions.explanation: Escalate through proper channels; do not counsel family with diagnoses.

questions.stem: Constructive feedback to colleagues should be:
options: Private, specific, and focused on quality/safety improvement
questions.explanation: Professional feedback improves team quality and safety.

questions.stem: Which practice BEST supports electrical safety during EEG?
options: Use damaged cables if tracing looks OK
Inspect equipment, maintain safe connections, and mitigate noise sources
Increase notch filter to solve all issues
questions.explanation: Electrical safety requires equipment integrity and proper grounding.

questions.stem: SDS/MSDS information is MOST relevant when:
options: Handling cleaning/disinfection chemicals in the lab
questions.explanation: SDS/MSDS governs chemical safety.

questions.stem: Which is an appropriate seizure-safety precaution in the lab?
options: Positioning to reduce fall risk and ensuring rapid access to call system/help
Putting objects in mouth during seizure
questions.explanation: Safety measures reduce injury and enable prompt response.

questions.stem: Infection control protocols are MOST commonly guided by:
options: Institutional policy and public health guidance
questions.explanation: Follow policy and recognized guidance.

questions.stem: Which action is MOST appropriate if you suspect a chemical exposure from disinfectant?
options: Follow institutional exposure protocol, seek help, and document/report per policy
questions.explanation: Occupational safety requires prompt reporting and care.

questions.stem: A patient becomes unresponsive with no apparent breathing. The technologist should FIRST:
options: Activate emergency response per policy and begin BLS/CPR if trained
questions.explanation: Emergency response and BLS take priority.

questions.stem: During a convulsive seizure, the technologist's priority is to:
options: Protect from injury, time event, and follow emergency protocol
questions.explanation: Protect patient and follow protocol; avoid unsafe actions.

questions.stem: Which documentation is MOST essential during an emergency event?
options: Event start/stop times, key behaviors, responsiveness, interventions, and notifications made
questions.explanation: Accurate event timeline and actions support care and interpretation.

questions.stem: Oxygen equipment is present in the lab. The technologist should:
options: Adjust oxygen flow for any patient without authorization
Use oxygen only within training/scope and institutional policy; call for help when needed
Use oxygen to treat photic responses
questions.explanation: Interventions must be within training/scope and policy.

questions.stem: If a seizure lasts longer than expected and status epilepticus is suspected, the BEST action is to:
options: Initiate emergency response per institutional protocol immediately while maintaining patient safety
Leave to find the interpreter without ensuring safety
questions.explanation: Prompt escalation and safety are required.

questions.stem: An EEG shows diffuse theta-delta slowing. After raising the low-frequency filter from 0.1 Hz to 1.0 Hz, the slowing appears reduced. The technologist should:
options: Report that the encephalopathy has improved based on the filter change
Recognize this is a filter artifact and interpret the original recording with standard settings
Lower the sensitivity to make the slowing less visible
Document that the patient's condition normalized during the study
questions.explanation: High LFF artificially attenuates slow activity; this is a technical artifact, not a clinical change. Always interpret with standard filter settings.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old patient shows brief, arch-shaped transients in the temporal region during drowsiness. They occur in trains, do not disrupt background, and lack aftergoing slow waves. The technologist's BEST interpretation is:
options: These are definitely epileptiform spikes requiring immediate intervention
These are wicket spikes, a benign variant that should be documented but not overinterpreted
These are artifacts from muscle activity
These indicate a seizure focus requiring urgent medication adjustment
questions.explanation: Wicket spikes are benign temporal variants. Key features: arch-shaped, trains, no background disruption, no aftergoing slow wave. They should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: A sharp wave appears maximal at C3 in a referential montage but shows phase reversal at C3-Cz in a bipolar montage. The MOST accurate localization is:
options: The abnormality is at the reference electrode
The abnormality is at C3, confirmed by phase reversal in bipolar montage
The abnormality is at Cz, since that's where the phase reverses
Phase reversal is meaningless and should be ignored
questions.explanation: Phase reversal in bipolar montage localizes the abnormality to the electrode between the two channels showing the reversal. C3-Cz reversal indicates C3 is the source.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old child's EEG shows a 7 Hz posterior rhythm that attenuates with eye opening. The technologist should:
options: Report this as abnormal slowing requiring immediate intervention
Recognize this is age-appropriate PDR; slower frequency is normal for this age
Increase the high-frequency filter to see if faster activity is hidden
questions.explanation: PDR frequency increases with age. A 7 Hz posterior rhythm in a 6-year-old is within normal limits. Reactivity to eye opening confirms it's genuine PDR, not slowing.

questions.stem: All electrodes show impedance values of 3-5 kΩ, but Fp1 shows 8 kΩ. The EEG has excessive noise. The technologist should:
options: Proceed; all values are under 10 kΩ so they're acceptable
Re-prep Fp1 to balance impedance; large differences cause artifact even if individual values are acceptable
Lower the sensitivity to reduce noise
Use a different montage to avoid Fp1
questions.explanation: Impedance balance is more critical than absolute values. A 5 kΩ difference can cause significant artifact. Re-prepping to balance impedances is the correct approach.

questions.stem: A central rhythm at 10 Hz appears arch-shaped and attenuates when the patient moves their right hand. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: Mu rhythm, a normal variant that blocks with contralateral movement
questions.explanation: Mu rhythm is a normal central rhythm (8-13 Hz) that attenuates with contralateral movement or movement intention. Arch-shaped morphology and movement reactivity are key features.

questions.stem: A technologist increases sensitivity from 7 μV/mm to 3.5 μV/mm to 'see more detail.' The waveforms appear larger. The technologist should understand that:
options: The brain activity has actually increased in amplitude
Only the display scale changed; actual brain voltage is unchanged
Lower sensitivity values always mean better recordings
This change will reveal hidden epileptiform activity
questions.explanation: Sensitivity controls display scaling, not actual brain voltage. Lower sensitivity values (μV/mm) mean higher gain (larger display). The actual brain signal amplitude is unchanged.

questions.stem: During N2 sleep, a technologist observes 12-14 Hz spindles maximal centrally and K-complexes. The patient then shows low-amplitude, desynchronized activity with rapid eye movements. The technologist should recognize this transition as:
options: The patient has entered REM sleep, characterized by desynchronized background and REMs
The patient is having a seizure
questions.explanation: REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, desynchronized background, rapid eye movements, and absence of spindles/K-complexes. This is a normal sleep stage transition.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old patient with known sickle cell disease is scheduled for EEG. The technologist should:
options: Perform hyperventilation as standard protocol for all pediatric patients
Skip hyperventilation due to risk of sickling crisis; consult with ordering physician if uncertain
Perform hyperventilation but at reduced intensity
questions.explanation: Hyperventilation can trigger sickling crises in sickle cell disease. This is a contraindication. The technologist should skip HV and document the reason, consulting with physician if needed.

questions.stem: An EEG shows 3 Hz spike-and-wave complexes that are perfectly synchronous across all channels, maximal frontally, and occur in bursts. The technologist should classify this as:
options: Generalized spike-and-wave, typical of absence epilepsy
questions.explanation: Generalized spike-and-wave is characterized by bilateral synchrony, symmetric distribution, and frontal maximum. This pattern is typical of generalized absence epilepsy, not focal.

questions.stem: A regular, 1 Hz sharp transient appears in all channels, time-locked across montages, and correlates with the patient's pulse. The technologist should identify this as:
options: ECG artifact, best confirmed by checking pulse correlation and ECG channel if available
questions.explanation: ECG artifact appears as regular, sharp transients time-locked to heart rate (typically 60-100 bpm, ~1 Hz). It appears in all channels and correlates with pulse. Checking ECG channel confirms it.

questions.stem: An awake adult's EEG shows a 9 Hz posterior rhythm that does NOT attenuate with eye opening. The technologist should:
options: Report this as normal; PDR doesn't need to be reactive
Document poor reactivity, which may be significant depending on clinical context and other findings
questions.explanation: Normal PDR should attenuate with eye opening. Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medication effects, or encephalopathy depending on context. It should be documented accurately.

questions.stem: An EEG system samples at 200 Hz. The technologist should understand that the maximum frequency that can be accurately represented is:
questions.explanation: Nyquist theorem states maximum representable frequency = sampling rate / 2. At 200 Hz sampling, maximum frequency is 100 Hz. Higher frequencies will alias.

questions.stem: An EEG shows diffuse theta-delta slowing with preserved PDR reactivity. The technologist should recognize that:
options: This indicates severe encephalopathy requiring immediate intervention
This suggests mild-moderate encephalopathy; preserved reactivity is a favorable sign
This is normal for all age groups
questions.explanation: Diffuse slowing indicates encephalopathy, but preserved PDR reactivity suggests the encephalopathy is not severe. Reactivity is a key prognostic indicator.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation at 15 Hz, the EEG shows a 15 Hz response over the occipital region that is time-locked to the flash rate. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: Photic driving, a normal response where occipital activity follows the flash rate
questions.explanation: Photic driving is a normal response where occipital activity synchronizes to the flash frequency. Photosensitivity would show spike-and-wave or other epileptiform activity, not just following.

questions.stem: An EEG shows a brief, isolated sharp wave in the left temporal region with no evolution, no clinical change, and normal background. The technologist should:
options: Document this as an ictal event requiring immediate intervention
Document this as an interictal epileptiform discharge (IED), not ictal activity
questions.explanation: Ictal activity shows evolution (frequency/amplitude changes). An isolated sharp wave without evolution, clinical correlation, or background disruption is interictal, not ictal.

questions.stem: A technologist uses subdermal needle electrodes for a patient with thick, matted hair. The technologist should be aware that:
options: Needle electrodes are always preferred for better signal quality
Needle electrodes require strict sterile technique and have infection risk; scalp prep may be preferable if possible
Needle electrodes don't require impedance checks
questions.explanation: Needle electrodes have higher infection risk and require sterile technique. They should only be used when scalp access is truly limited. Proper scalp prep with cup electrodes is generally preferred.

questions.stem: An EEG shows slowing maximal at T5-T6. The technologist should understand that this localizes to:
options: Posterior temporal cortex, recognizing EEG primarily reflects cortical surface activity
questions.explanation: EEG reflects superficial cortical activity. T5-T6 correspond to posterior temporal cortex. Deep structures like hippocampus are poorly represented on scalp EEG.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old patient performs hyperventilation for 3 minutes. The EEG shows 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave complexes that appear during HV and resolve when HV stops. The technologist should:
options: Document this as abnormal but not significant
Document this as HV-activated generalized spike-and-wave, which is significant and supports absence epilepsy
Ignore it as artifact from breathing
Document this as normal HV response
questions.explanation: HV-activated generalized spike-and-wave in children is a classic finding in absence epilepsy. This is a significant activation, not artifact or normal response.

questions.stem: Regular, high-amplitude deflections appear in Fp1-Fp2, time-locked to visible eye blinks, and are out of phase. The technologist should identify this as:
options: Eye blink artifact, confirmed by correlation with visible blinks and frontal maximum
questions.explanation: Eye blink artifact is maximal frontally (Fp1-Fp2), time-locked to blinks, and shows out-of-phase deflections due to eye movement polarity. Correlation with visible blinks confirms it.

questions.stem: A technologist understands that EEG measures:
options: Electrical current flowing through the brain
questions.explanation: EEG measures voltage differences (electrical potential differences) between electrodes, not current flow. This is a fundamental distinction in EEG physics.

questions.stem: Brief, low-amplitude sharp transients appear in the temporal regions during drowsiness, lasting 50-100 ms, with no aftergoing slow wave. The technologist should recognize these as:
options: BETS (benign epileptiform transients of sleep), a normal variant
questions.explanation: BETS are benign temporal transients during drowsiness/sleep: brief (<100 ms), low amplitude, no aftergoing slow wave. They should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: A technologist switches from bipolar to average reference montage. A focal sharp wave that was subtle in bipolar becomes more prominent. The technologist should understand that:
options: Average reference can enhance focal abnormalities by reducing common-mode activity; this is a montage effect, not a clinical change
questions.explanation: Average reference can enhance focal abnormalities by subtracting common activity. This is a technical effect of montage choice, not a change in the actual abnormality.

questions.stem: A 2-week-old neonate's EEG shows periods of high-amplitude activity alternating with periods of relative suppression. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: Trace alternant, a normal discontinuous pattern in neonates
questions.explanation: Trace alternant is a normal discontinuous pattern in neonates (up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age). It shows alternating high-amplitude bursts and suppression, distinct from abnormal burst suppression.

questions.stem: A technologist lowers the high-frequency filter from 70 Hz to 15 Hz to 'reduce muscle artifact.' Small sharp transients become less visible. The technologist should understand that:
options: Low HFF can attenuate spikes and sharp waves, potentially masking important findings
This is the correct setting for all recordings
Muscle artifact is now completely eliminated
questions.explanation: Excessively low HFF (e.g., 15 Hz) can attenuate spikes and sharp waves, which contain high-frequency components. This can mask epileptiform activity. Standard HFF is 35-70 Hz.

questions.stem: A technologist observes a sharp transient with duration of 80 ms and pointed morphology. The technologist should classify this as:
questions.explanation: Sharp waves are defined as 70-200 ms duration. Spikes are 20-70 ms. An 80 ms transient is a sharp wave, not a spike.

questions.stem: An EEG shows 60 Hz artifact in all channels. The technologist checks and finds the ground electrode impedance is 50 kΩ. The technologist should:
options: Fix the ground electrode first; poor grounding causes 60 Hz artifact that affects all channels
questions.explanation: Poor grounding is a common cause of 60 Hz artifact affecting all channels. Fixing the ground should be the first step. Notch filter should be used only if the source cannot be fixed.

questions.stem: During N2 sleep, a technologist observes a high-amplitude, sharp transient maximal at Cz that is not part of a K-complex. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: A vertex wave, a normal sleep graphoelement maximal centrally
questions.explanation: Vertex waves are normal sleep transients maximal at Cz (central vertex). They are sharp, high-amplitude, and occur during N1/N2 sleep. They should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: An EEG shows prominent, symmetric beta activity (18-25 Hz) over the frontal regions. The patient is on benzodiazepines. The technologist should:
options: Report this as abnormal fast activity requiring intervention
Recognize this is medication-induced beta, a common effect of benzodiazepines
Increase the high-frequency filter to eliminate it
questions.explanation: Prominent frontal beta is commonly seen with benzodiazepines and other CNS depressants. This is a medication effect, not abnormal activity. It should be documented but not overinterpreted.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, the EEG shows spike-and-wave complexes that are NOT time-locked to the flash rate and persist after stimulation stops. The technologist should:
options: Document this as normal photic driving
Document this as photosensitivity (IPS), an abnormal response requiring reporting
Document this as normal background activity
questions.explanation: Photosensitivity shows epileptiform activity (spike-and-wave) that is NOT time-locked to flash rate and may persist. This is abnormal and different from normal photic driving, which follows the flash rate.

questions.stem: An EEG shows periodic, high-amplitude triphasic waves with frontal maximum in a patient with hepatic encephalopathy. The technologist should recognize that:
options: These are epileptiform discharges requiring antiepileptic medication
These are triphasic waves, characteristic of metabolic encephalopathy, not epileptiform activity
These indicate a focal seizure focus
questions.explanation: Triphasic waves are periodic, high-amplitude waves with characteristic three-phase morphology, typically seen in metabolic/toxic encephalopathies. They are NOT epileptiform and should not be treated as seizures.

questions.stem: A patient arrives for EEG and reports taking 'seizure medication' but cannot recall the name. The technologist should:
options: Proceed without documenting medications since the name is unknown
Document 'seizure medication - name unknown' and note the importance of obtaining accurate medication list for interpretation
Assume it's not important for EEG interpretation
Cancel the study until medication name is confirmed
questions.explanation: Medications significantly affect EEG (e.g., benzodiazepines cause beta, AEDs suppress epileptiform). Documenting what is known (even if incomplete) is better than omitting it. Attempt to obtain accurate list but don't cancel study.

questions.stem: An EEG shows persistent 30% amplitude asymmetry with lower amplitude over the right hemisphere. PDR is 9 Hz bilaterally. The technologist should:
options: Report this as definitely abnormal requiring immediate intervention
Document the asymmetry; <50% asymmetry may be normal variant, but clinical correlation is needed
Report this as a seizure focus
questions.explanation: Mild amplitude asymmetry (<50%) can be a normal variant, especially if PDR frequency is symmetric. However, it may also indicate pathology. Document accurately and let interpreter correlate with clinical context.

questions.stem: A single channel (C3) shows brief, high-amplitude, sharp deflections that occur randomly, are not time-locked to any visible movement, and appear only in that channel. The technologist should identify this as:
options: Electrode pop artifact, likely from poor contact at C3
questions.explanation: Electrode pop appears as brief, high-amplitude, sharp deflections in a single channel, caused by intermittent poor electrode contact. It's not time-locked to movement and is isolated to one channel, distinguishing it from cerebral activity.

questions.stem: A technologist understands that epileptiform discharges result from:
options: Increased blood flow to the brain
Synchronous, excessive neuronal firing (hyperexcitability) and synchronization
questions.explanation: Epileptiform activity results from hyperexcitability (excessive neuronal firing) and synchronization of neuronal populations. This is a fundamental neurophysiological concept.

questions.stem: During a clinical seizure, the EEG shows sudden, marked attenuation of background activity (electrodecremental pattern) followed by rhythmic fast activity. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: Ictal onset pattern, with electrodecremental response indicating seizure initiation
questions.explanation: Electrodecremental pattern (sudden background attenuation) is a classic ictal onset pattern, often followed by rhythmic fast activity. This indicates seizure initiation, not artifact.

questions.stem: A technologist understands that 'time constant' is related to:
options: Low-frequency filter behavior; shorter time constant = higher LFF cutoff = less slow activity
questions.explanation: Time constant is an analog concept related to LFF. Shorter time constant = higher LFF cutoff = attenuation of slow frequencies. This is important for understanding filter effects.

questions.stem: During drowsiness, a technologist observes 14 Hz positive spikes over the posterior temporal regions in an adolescent. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: 14&6 Hz positive spikes, a benign variant common in children/adolescents during drowsiness
questions.explanation: 14&6 Hz positive spikes are benign variants seen in children/adolescents during drowsiness, maximal posterior temporally. They should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, a sharp wave shows phase reversal between F3-Fz and Fz-F4. The technologist should localize this to:
options: Fz (the electrode common to both channels showing reversal)
Cannot be determined from phase reversal
questions.explanation: Phase reversal localizes to the electrode common to both channels. Fz is common to F3-Fz and Fz-F4, so the abnormality is at Fz.

questions.stem: A 3-year-old child's EEG shows a 6 Hz posterior rhythm that is reactive to eye opening. The technologist should:
options: Recognize this is age-appropriate; PDR frequency increases with age, and 6 Hz is normal for a 3-year-old
Increase filters to see if faster activity is hidden
questions.explanation: PDR frequency is age-dependent. A 6 Hz posterior rhythm in a 3-year-old is within normal limits. Reactivity confirms it's genuine PDR. Normal PDR frequency increases with maturation.

questions.stem: A patient with recent stroke and hemiparesis is scheduled for EEG. The technologist should:
options: Consider stroke as potential contraindication; consult with ordering physician about HV safety given recent stroke
questions.explanation: Recent stroke may be a relative contraindication for HV due to risk of increased intracranial pressure or vasospasm. Technologist should consult with physician rather than automatically performing or skipping.

questions.stem: An EEG shows 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave complexes that occur in bursts, are perfectly synchronous, and are activated by hyperventilation. The technologist should recognize this pattern as:
options: Classic pattern of childhood absence epilepsy (petit mal)
questions.explanation: 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave, perfectly synchronous, in bursts, activated by HV is the classic pattern of childhood absence epilepsy. This is a well-defined epileptiform pattern.

questions.stem: All electrodes show impedance of 2 kΩ except Fp1 at 15 kΩ. The EEG shows excessive noise. The technologist should:
options: Proceed; Fp1 is still under 20 kΩ which is acceptable
Re-prep Fp1 to balance impedance; the large difference (13 kΩ) causes artifact even if individual values are 'acceptable'
Use notch filter to eliminate noise
questions.explanation: Impedance balance is critical. A 13 kΩ difference between electrodes causes significant artifact, even if both values are individually 'acceptable'. Re-prepping to balance is essential.

questions.stem: An EEG shows low-amplitude, desynchronized background with rapid eye movements and absence of spindles or K-complexes. Muscle tone is low. The technologist should identify this as:
options: REM sleep, characterized by desynchronized background, REMs, and low muscle tone
questions.explanation: REM sleep shows desynchronized low-amplitude background, rapid eye movements, absence of spindles/K-complexes, and low muscle tone. This is distinct from NREM stages.

questions.stem: An awake adult's EEG shows prominent 5-7 Hz theta activity diffusely. The technologist should:
options: Consider drowsiness; theta can be normal in drowsy adults but abnormal in fully awake adults
questions.explanation: Theta in adults is state-dependent. It's normal during drowsiness but abnormal in fully awake adults. The technologist should note the patient's state and document accordingly.

questions.stem: An EEG shows slow, irregular baseline drift affecting multiple channels, worse in areas with more hair. The technologist should identify this as:
options: Sweat artifact, caused by salt bridging between electrodes
questions.explanation: Sweat artifact causes slow, irregular baseline drift due to salt bridging between electrodes. It's worse in hairy areas and affects multiple channels. It can mimic slowing but is technical artifact.

questions.stem: An EEG shows polymorphic delta slowing (1-3 Hz) confined to the right temporal region, persisting across montages. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: Focal polymorphic delta slowing, suggesting underlying structural or functional abnormality in that region
questions.explanation: Focal polymorphic delta slowing is abnormal and suggests underlying pathology (structural lesion, seizure focus, etc.) in that region. Persistence across montages confirms it's not artifact.

questions.stem: A technologist changes sweep speed from 30 mm/s to 10 mm/s. The technologist should understand that:
options: The actual brain frequencies have changed
Only the display compression changed; faster speeds (30 mm/s) spread out waveforms for better spike identification, slower speeds (10 mm/s) compress for slow wave viewing
questions.explanation: Sweep speed controls display compression, not actual brain activity. Faster speeds (30 mm/s) spread waveforms for spike identification; slower speeds (10 mm/s) compress for viewing slow waves.

questions.stem: A patient with suspected epilepsy has a normal routine EEG. The technologist should understand that:
options: Sleep-deprived EEG or prolonged monitoring may be needed; normal routine EEG does not exclude epilepsy
The patient definitely does not have seizures
questions.explanation: Normal routine EEG does not exclude epilepsy. Sleep-deprived EEG, prolonged monitoring, or activation procedures may be needed to capture interictal or ictal activity. Epilepsy diagnosis requires clinical correlation.

questions.stem: A technologist measures and marks electrode positions using the 10-20 system. The technologist should understand that:
options: Exact measurements are optional; approximate placement is sufficient
Accurate 10-20 measurements are essential for proper localization and comparison across studies
Electrode names don't matter for interpretation
Only frontal electrodes need accurate placement
questions.explanation: Accurate 10-20 measurements are critical for proper localization, comparison across studies, and standardized interpretation. Approximate placement can lead to mislocalization and errors.

questions.stem: During wakefulness with eyes open, a technologist observes sharp, positive transients over the occipital region that occur with saccadic eye movements. The technologist should recognize these as:
options: Lambda waves, normal positive occipital transients associated with eye movements
questions.explanation: Lambda waves are normal positive occipital transients that occur with saccadic eye movements during wakefulness with eyes open. They should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: A technologist uses a 60 Hz notch filter to eliminate line noise. The technologist should be aware that:
options: Notch filter has no effect on EEG interpretation
Notch filter can distort spikes and sharp waves near 60 Hz; fix the source of noise first if possible
Notch filter improves all aspects of the recording
Notch filter should always be used on every recording
questions.explanation: Notch filter can distort activity near 60 Hz, including spikes. The best practice is to fix the source of noise (ground, impedance, etc.) first. Use notch only if source cannot be fixed.

questions.stem: An EEG shows slowing maximal at T5. The technologist should understand that this localizes to:
options: Posterior temporal cortex; EEG reflects cortical surface, not deep structures
questions.explanation: EEG primarily reflects superficial cortical activity. T5 corresponds to posterior temporal cortex. Deep structures like amygdala/hippocampus are poorly represented on scalp EEG.

questions.stem: A technologist observes a sharp wave followed by a slow wave. The technologist should understand that:
options: The aftergoing slow wave is always present in epileptiform discharges
Aftergoing slow waves are common but not required for epileptiform classification; morphology, field, and context matter more
Only spikes have aftergoing slow waves, not sharp waves
questions.explanation: Aftergoing slow waves are common in epileptiform discharges but not required. Classification depends on morphology (pointed, sharp), field (physiologic), and context, not just presence of slow wave.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation at 20 Hz, the EEG shows generalized spike-and-wave complexes that are NOT time-locked to the flash and continue for 2 seconds after stimulation stops. The technologist should:
options: Document this as normal photic driving
Document this as photosensitivity (IPS), an abnormal response requiring reporting
Document this as normal background activity
questions.explanation: Generalized spike-and-wave NOT time-locked to flash and persisting after stimulation is photosensitivity (IPS), an abnormal response. This is different from normal photic driving which follows flash rate.

questions.stem: A 35-week post-conceptual age neonate's EEG shows periods of high-amplitude activity alternating with periods of relative suppression. The technologist should:
options: Report this as abnormal burst suppression
Recognize this as trace alternant, a normal discontinuous pattern in premature/young neonates
questions.explanation: Trace alternant is a normal discontinuous pattern in neonates up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age. It shows alternating high-amplitude bursts and suppression, distinct from abnormal patterns.

questions.stem: A technologist understands that differential amplifiers work by:
options: Amplifying the difference between active and reference electrodes while rejecting common noise (CMRR)
questions.explanation: Differential amplifiers amplify the voltage difference between active and reference electrodes. They reject common-mode noise (signals present in both) through CMRR (common-mode rejection ratio).

questions.stem: A technologist observes 12-14 Hz rhythmic activity maximal centrally during sleep. The technologist should identify this as:
options: Sleep spindles, characteristic of N2 sleep
questions.explanation: Sleep spindles are 12-14 Hz rhythmic bursts maximal centrally, characteristic of N2 sleep. They are distinct from mu rhythm (which occurs during wakefulness) and epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: In an average reference montage, a focal sharp wave appears prominent. The technologist switches to a linked-ear reference. The sharp wave becomes less visible. The technologist should understand that:
options: Average reference can enhance focal abnormalities; linked-ear may reduce visibility depending on field distribution
Linked-ear is always superior to average reference
questions.explanation: Different reference choices affect how focal abnormalities appear. Average reference can enhance focal activity by subtracting common activity. The actual abnormality hasn't changed, only its appearance.

questions.stem: After a clinical seizure, the EEG shows diffuse suppression followed by gradual return of background. The technologist should recognize this as:
options: Postictal suppression, a normal finding after seizure termination
questions.explanation: Postictal suppression (diffuse background suppression) is a normal finding after seizure termination, followed by gradual return of background. This helps confirm a true ictal event occurred.

questions.stem: Which of the following filter changes can mask or distort important EEG findings? (Select all that apply)
options: Raising LFF too high can mask diffuse slowing
Lowering HFF too much can attenuate spikes
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: High LFF masks slow activity (slowing), and low HFF attenuates fast activity (spikes). Both can lead to misinterpretation.

questions.stem: Which of the following are characteristics of benign EEG variants that help distinguish them from epileptiform activity?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Benign variants (wicket spikes, BETS, mu rhythm) typically lack aftergoing slow waves and don't disrupt background, helping distinguish them from epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Which factors contribute to excessive EEG noise and artifact?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Large impedance differences and poor grounding are major sources of noise. Impedance balance is more critical than absolute values.

questions.stem: Which characteristics help identify epileptiform discharges?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Epileptiform discharges have pointed/sharp morphology and show physiologic field distribution (not confined to single channel like artifact).

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding age-related EEG development?
options: Theta and delta are normal in children but abnormal in awake adults
Both A and B are correct
EEG patterns are identical across all ages
questions.explanation: Both are correct: PDR frequency matures with age (slower in children), and theta/delta are normal in pediatric EEG but abnormal in fully awake adults.

questions.stem: Which conditions are relative or absolute contraindications for hyperventilation?
options: Recent stroke or increased intracranial pressure
Both A and B are correct
All patients can safely perform HV
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Recent stroke, increased ICP, and sickle cell disease are contraindications for HV due to risk of complications.

questions.stem: Which graphoelements are characteristic of N2 sleep?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: N2 sleep is characterized by both sleep spindles (12-14 Hz central) and K-complexes. REMs occur in REM sleep, not N2.

questions.stem: Which montage characteristics are true?
options: Bipolar montages help localize through phase reversal
Referential montages can enhance focal abnormalities
Both A and B are correct
Only one montage type is ever needed
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Bipolar montages use phase reversal for localization, while referential montages (especially average reference) can enhance focal abnormalities by subtracting common activity.

questions.stem: Which features distinguish ictal from interictal EEG activity?
options: Evolution in frequency, amplitude, or distribution
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal activity shows evolution (changes over time) and clinical correlation. Isolated sharp waves without evolution are interictal.

questions.stem: Which artifacts can be identified by their characteristic features?
options: ECG: Regular, 1 Hz, time-locked to pulse, all channels
Eye blink: Frontal maximum, time-locked to visible blinks
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Each artifact type has characteristic features. ECG is regular and pulse-locked; eye blinks are frontal and blink-locked. Recognition helps avoid misinterpretation.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of normal posterior dominant rhythm (PDR)?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Normal adult PDR is 8-13 Hz and should attenuate with eye opening. PDR may be absent or poorly formed in some patients (elderly, encephalopathy).

questions.stem: A technologist should understand that sensitivity settings affect:
options: The vertical scaling (amplitude display) of waveforms
The actual brain voltage (which remains unchanged)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sensitivity controls display scaling (vertical amplitude), not actual brain voltage. Lower sensitivity values (μV/mm) mean higher gain (larger display).

questions.stem: Which factors help assess the severity of diffuse encephalopathy on EEG?
options: Degree of background slowing (theta vs delta)
Presence or absence of PDR reactivity
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Severity is assessed by degree of slowing (delta worse than theta) and reactivity (preserved reactivity is favorable). Age provides context but isn't the only factor.

questions.stem: Which statements correctly distinguish photic driving from photosensitivity?
options: Photic driving: Occipital activity follows flash rate (time-locked)
Photosensitivity: Spike-and-wave NOT time-locked, may persist after stimulation
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Photic driving is normal (time-locked following). Photosensitivity is abnormal (epileptiform, not time-locked, may persist). These are distinct.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG localization?
options: EEG reflects superficial cortical activity, not deep structures
Localization is regional, not exact anatomical pinpointing
Both A and B are correct
EEG can precisely localize subcortical lesions
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EEG is limited to cortical surface activity and provides regional localization, not exact pinpointing. Deep structures are poorly represented.

questions.stem: Which features characterize generalized spike-and-wave complexes?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Generalized spike-and-wave shows bilateral synchrony, symmetric distribution, and often frontal maximum. This distinguishes it from focal patterns.

questions.stem: Which sweep speed settings are appropriate for different purposes?
options: 30 mm/s: Better for identifying spikes and fast activity
10 mm/s: Better for viewing slow waves and overall background
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Faster speeds (30 mm/s) spread waveforms for spike identification; slower speeds (10 mm/s) compress for viewing slow waves and background patterns.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of mu rhythm?
options: Attenuates with contralateral movement or movement intention
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Mu rhythm is central, arch-shaped, and blocks with contralateral movement. It's a normal variant, not pathology.

questions.stem: Which practices improve electrode contact and signal quality?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Good scalp prep and adequate conductive medium are essential for low impedance and stable recordings. Impedance checks are necessary, not optional.

questions.stem: Which activation procedures can increase diagnostic yield in epilepsy?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: HV activates absence seizures; sleep-deprived EEG increases likelihood of capturing interictal/ictal activity. Both improve diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: Which are common causes of 60 Hz line noise in EEG?
options: Poor ground electrode contact or high impedance
Nearby electrical equipment or poor room grounding
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 60 Hz artifact commonly results from poor ground contact/impedance or environmental electrical interference. Fix source first before using notch filter.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG signal measurement?
options: EEG measures voltage differences, not current flow
Polarity depends on electrode orientation and montage
Both A and B are correct
EEG delivers electricity to the brain
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EEG measures voltage (potential differences), not current. Polarity is relative and depends on montage/electrode orientation. EEG is passive recording, not stimulation.

questions.stem: Which criteria are used to classify epileptiform transients?
options: Duration: spikes (20-70 ms), sharp waves (70-200 ms)
Morphology: pointed, sharp, distinct from background
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Classification uses duration (spikes vs sharp waves) and morphology (pointed, sharp). Amplitude alone is insufficient; morphology and field are critical.

questions.stem: Which features help identify muscle (EMG) artifact?
options: Maximal in temporal/frontal regions, increases with movement
Both A and B are correct
Always appears in all channels equally
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EMG is high-frequency, typically maximal temporally/frontally, and increases with movement or tension. It's not uniform across all channels.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding prominent frontal beta activity?
options: Commonly seen with benzodiazepines and CNS depressants
Is a medication effect, not necessarily abnormal brain activity
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Prominent frontal beta is a common medication effect (benzodiazepines, barbiturates) and should be documented but not overinterpreted as abnormal.

questions.stem: Which graphoelements are seen during N1 and N2 sleep stages?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vertex waves occur in N1/N2; K-complexes and spindles characterize N2. REMs occur in REM sleep, not N1/N2.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding montage selection?
options: Multiple montages should be used for comprehensive interpretation
Bipolar helps with localization; referential helps with field assessment
Both A and B are correct
Only one montage is ever needed
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Using multiple montages (bipolar and referential) provides complementary information. Bipolar aids localization; referential aids field assessment.

questions.stem: Which changes indicate ictal evolution (seizure progression)?
options: Changes in frequency (e.g., fast to slower)
Changes in amplitude or spatial distribution
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal evolution shows changes in frequency, amplitude, or spatial spread over time. Static patterns without evolution are interictal, not ictal.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding neonatal EEG patterns?
options: Discontinuity (trace alternant) is normal in premature/young neonates
Normal patterns vary significantly with post-conceptual age
Both A and B are correct
Neonatal EEG should always be continuous
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Discontinuity is normal in neonates up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age. Normal patterns are highly age-dependent in neonates.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding notch filter use?
options: Should be used only if source of 60 Hz noise cannot be fixed
Can distort spikes and activity near 60 Hz
Both A and B are correct
Should always be left on for all recordings
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Notch filter should be last resort after fixing source (ground, impedance). It can distort activity near 60 Hz, including spikes.

questions.stem: Which factors help determine if amplitude asymmetry is significant?
options: Degree of asymmetry (<50% may be normal variant)
Consistency across montages and correlation with other findings
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Mild asymmetry (<50%) can be normal, but significance depends on degree, consistency across montages, and correlation with other EEG/clinical findings.

questions.stem: Which medications commonly affect EEG background activity?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Benzodiazepines cause prominent beta; AEDs can suppress epileptiform discharges. Accurate medication documentation is essential for proper interpretation.

questions.stem: Which features characterize classic 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave of absence epilepsy?
options: Perfect bilateral synchrony and symmetric distribution
Activation by hyperventilation, especially in children
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 3 Hz spike-and-wave shows perfect synchrony and symmetry, and is classically activated by HV in children with absence epilepsy.

questions.stem: Which features help identify electrode pop artifact?
options: Brief, high-amplitude, sharp deflections, not time-locked to movement
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Electrode pop is single-channel, brief, high-amplitude, sharp, and random (not movement-locked). This distinguishes it from cerebral activity or other artifacts.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding theta activity in adults?
options: Normal during drowsiness and light sleep
Abnormal in fully awake, alert adults
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Theta is state-dependent in adults - normal during drowsiness/sleep but abnormal when fully awake. Patient state must be documented.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding sampling rate and frequency representation?
options: Frequencies above Nyquist will alias (appear as lower frequencies)
Both A and B are correct
Sampling rate doesn't affect frequency representation
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Nyquist theorem states max frequency = sampling rate / 2. Higher frequencies alias (fold back) as lower frequencies, causing distortion.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of 14&6 Hz positive spikes?
options: Maximal over posterior temporal regions during drowsiness
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 14&6 Hz positive spikes are benign, seen in children/adolescents during drowsiness, maximal posterior temporally. Should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding phase reversal in bipolar montages?
options: Phase reversal localizes to the electrode common to both channels
Requires the abnormality to be present in both channels showing reversal
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Phase reversal localizes to the common electrode, and the abnormality must be visible in both channels for reversal to occur. This is a key localization tool.

questions.stem: Which features distinguish REM sleep from NREM sleep?
options: REM: Desynchronized low-amplitude background, rapid eye movements
NREM: Contains spindles and K-complexes (N2), or slow waves (N3)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: REM shows desynchronized background with REMs; NREM shows synchronized activity (spindles/K-complexes in N2, slow waves in N3). These are distinct sleep stages.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding electrode impedance?
options: Impedance balance between electrodes is more critical than absolute values
Large differences (>5 kΩ) can cause artifact even if both values are individually acceptable
Both A and B are correct
Only absolute values matter, balance is irrelevant
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Balance is critical. A 5 kΩ difference can cause significant artifact even if both electrodes are under 10 kΩ individually. Balance > absolute values.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding PDR frequency and age?
options: PDR frequency increases with brain maturation
Slower PDR in children is normal and age-appropriate
Both A and B are correct
PDR frequency is identical at all ages
questions.explanation: Both are correct: PDR frequency matures with age (slower in children, faster in adults). Age-appropriate slower PDR in children is normal, not abnormal.

questions.stem: Which patterns are characteristic of ictal onset?
options: Rhythmic fast activity or rhythmic theta/delta
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal onset can show electrodecremental response or rhythmic activity (fast, theta, or delta). Evolution distinguishes ictal from interictal.

questions.stem: A technologist raises LFF from 0.1 Hz to 1.0 Hz and observes that diffuse slowing appears reduced. The technologist should understand that:
options: This is a filter artifact, not a real change in brain activity
The original recording with standard LFF (0.1-0.3 Hz) should be interpreted
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: High LFF artificially attenuates slow activity. This is technical artifact, not clinical change. Always interpret with standard filter settings.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of lambda waves?
options: Associated with saccadic eye movements during wakefulness with eyes open
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Lambda waves are positive occipital transients that occur with saccadic eye movements during wakefulness. They are normal, not epileptiform.

questions.stem: Which conditions require caution or contraindicate hyperventilation?
options: Recent stroke or increased intracranial pressure
Sickle cell disease or severe respiratory conditions
Both A and B are correct
All patients can safely perform HV
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Recent stroke, increased ICP, sickle cell disease, and severe respiratory conditions are contraindications. Safety requires recognizing these conditions.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG localization limitations?
options: EEG primarily reflects superficial cortical activity
Deep structures (hippocampus, thalamus) are poorly represented on scalp EEG
Both A and B are correct
EEG can precisely localize all brain structures
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EEG is limited to cortical surface. Deep structures are poorly represented. This is a fundamental limitation of scalp EEG.

questions.stem: Which factors are favorable prognostic indicators in diffuse encephalopathy?
options: Preserved PDR reactivity to eye opening
Both A and B are correct
Complete absence of all background activity
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Preserved reactivity and milder slowing (theta vs delta) are favorable signs. Complete background suppression is ominous, not favorable.

questions.stem: Which features help identify sweat artifact?
options: Worse in hairy areas, affects multiple channels
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sweat artifact shows slow, irregular drift due to salt bridging, worse in hairy areas, affecting multiple channels. This can mimic slowing.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding aftergoing slow waves in epileptiform discharges?
options: Common but not required for epileptiform classification
Morphology, field, and context are more important than presence of slow wave
Both A and B are correct
Always present in all epileptiform discharges
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Aftergoing slow waves are common but not required. Classification depends on morphology (pointed, sharp), physiologic field, and context.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding average reference montage?
options: Can enhance focal abnormalities by subtracting common activity
May make focal sharp waves more prominent than in bipolar montage
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Average reference subtracts common activity, enhancing focal abnormalities. A focal sharp wave may be more visible in average reference than bipolar.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of normal PDR reactivity?
options: Both A and B are correct
PDR should never change with eye state
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Normal PDR attenuates with eye opening and returns with eye closure. Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medication, or encephalopathy.

questions.stem: Which activation procedures increase likelihood of capturing epileptiform activity?
options: Sleep-deprived EEG (increases sleep and interictal activity)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep-deprived EEG increases sleep and interictal discharges. Sleep itself activates some seizure types. Both improve diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding differential amplifiers?
options: Amplify voltage difference between active and reference electrodes
Reject common-mode noise through CMRR (common-mode rejection ratio)
Both A and B are correct
Amplify all signals equally without discrimination
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Differential amplifiers amplify differences between electrodes and reject common noise (present in both) through CMRR. This is fundamental to EEG signal quality.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of sleep spindles?
options: Maximal centrally (C3-C4 region), characteristic of N2 sleep
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep spindles are 12-14 Hz, central, and characteristic of N2 sleep. They are normal graphoelements, not pathology.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding high-frequency filter (HFF) settings?
options: Excessively low HFF (<20 Hz) can attenuate spikes and sharp waves
Both A and B are correct
HFF settings don't affect spike visibility
