questions.explanation: Both are correct: Low HFF attenuates fast activity including spikes. Standard HFF (35-70 Hz) preserves spikes while reducing very high-frequency noise. Too low HFF masks important findings.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding focal polymorphic delta slowing?
options: Suggests underlying structural or functional abnormality in that region
Persists across montages, helping distinguish from artifact
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Focal polymorphic delta is abnormal and suggests pathology. Persistence across montages confirms it's not artifact. This is a significant finding.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG as a measurement system?
options: Measures voltage differences (potential differences), not electrical current flow
EEG is a passive recording system (measures, doesn't deliver electricity)
EEG delivers current to the brain
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both A and B are correct: EEG measures voltage differences (potential differences), not electrical current flow. EEG is a passive recording system - it measures electrical activity but does NOT deliver current to the brain (Option C is false). This is a fundamental distinction from stimulation or power delivery systems.

questions.stem: Which practices are essential for good electrode contact?
options: Proper scalp preparation (abrasion/cleaning to reduce impedance)
Adequate conductive paste/gel and secure electrode attachment
Both A and B are correct
Electrode placement doesn't affect signal quality
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Good scalp prep reduces impedance; adequate conductive medium and secure attachment ensure stable contact. These are fundamental for quality recordings.

questions.stem: Which patterns are commonly seen after seizure termination?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Postictal period commonly shows suppression followed by slowing before gradual return of background. This helps confirm a true ictal event occurred.

questions.stem: Which features indicate photosensitivity (IPS) rather than normal photic driving?
options: Spike-and-wave complexes NOT time-locked to flash rate
Epileptiform activity that may persist after stimulation stops
Both A and B are correct
Occipital activity that follows flash rate exactly
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Photosensitivity shows epileptiform activity (spike-and-wave) not time-locked to flash, may persist. Normal driving follows flash rate exactly. These are distinct.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of BETS (benign epileptiform transients of sleep)?
options: Occur during drowsiness/sleep, temporal regions, no aftergoing slow wave
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: BETS are brief, low-amplitude, temporal, occur during drowsiness/sleep, and lack aftergoing slow waves. They are benign, not epileptiform.

questions.stem: Which filter settings can lead to misinterpretation of EEG findings?
options: High LFF (>0.5 Hz) masking diffuse slowing
Low HFF (<20 Hz) attenuating spikes, or notch filter distorting 60 Hz activity
Both A and B are correct
Standard filter settings always preserve all findings
questions.explanation: Both are correct: High LFF masks slowing; low HFF attenuates spikes; notch distorts activity near 60 Hz. All can cause misinterpretation. Standard settings (LFF 0.1-0.3 Hz, HFF 35-70 Hz) are recommended.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding neonatal EEG discontinuity?
options: Trace alternant (discontinuous pattern) is normal up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age
Discontinuity decreases with increasing post-conceptual age
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Trace alternant is normal in neonates up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age. Continuity increases with maturation. Discontinuity in older infants/children is abnormal.

questions.stem: Which features help distinguish true epileptiform discharges from artifact?
options: Physiologic field distribution (not confined to single channel)
Pointed, sharp morphology distinct from background
Both A and B are correct
Artifact always looks identical to epileptiform activity
questions.explanation: Both are correct: True epileptiform shows physiologic field (spreads appropriately) and pointed morphology. Artifact is often single-channel or non-physiologic. Both features help distinguish.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding using multiple montages?
options: Bipolar and referential montages provide complementary information
Using both helps confirm findings and improve localization accuracy
Both A and B are correct
Only one montage type is ever needed
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Bipolar aids localization via phase reversal; referential aids field assessment. Using both confirms findings and improves accuracy. Multiple montages are standard practice.

questions.stem: Which graphoelements must be present to identify N2 sleep?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: N2 sleep requires both spindles and K-complexes. REMs occur in REM sleep, not N2. Both elements are necessary for N2 identification.

questions.stem: Which steps should be taken when 60 Hz artifact appears in all channels?
options: Check ground electrode impedance and contact first
Check room electrical environment and nearby equipment
Both A and B are correct
Immediately use notch filter without checking source
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 60 Hz affecting all channels suggests ground or environmental issue. Check ground contact/impedance and electrical environment first. Fix source before using notch filter.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding prominent frontal beta activity?
options: Is a medication effect, not necessarily abnormal brain activity
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Prominent frontal beta is commonly medication-induced and should be documented but not overinterpreted. It's an effect, not necessarily abnormal brain activity.

questions.stem: Which features distinguish ictal from interictal epileptiform activity?
options: Both A and B are correct
Isolated sharp waves without evolution are ictal
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal shows evolution and clinical correlation. Isolated sharp waves without evolution are interictal, not ictal. Evolution is the key distinguishing feature.

questions.stem: Which features help identify eye blink artifact?
options: Both A and B are correct
Always appears in all channels equally
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Eye blinks are frontal, out-of-phase, and time-locked to visible blinks. Correlation with visible movement confirms it's artifact, not cerebral activity.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding diffuse slowing severity?
options: Delta slowing (1-3 Hz) indicates more severe encephalopathy than theta (4-7 Hz)
Degree of slowing correlates with encephalopathy severity
Both A and B are correct
Theta and delta slowing indicate equal severity
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Delta slowing is more severe than theta. Degree of slowing (theta vs delta) correlates with encephalopathy severity. This is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: Which sweep speed settings are appropriate for different viewing purposes?
options: 30 mm/s: Spreads waveforms for better spike identification
10 mm/s: Compresses for viewing slow waves and overall background
Both A and B are correct
Sweep speed doesn't affect what you can see
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Faster speeds (30 mm/s) spread for spike viewing; slower speeds (10 mm/s) compress for slow wave/background viewing. Both are useful for different purposes.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG electrode localization?
options: Electrodes correspond to underlying cortical regions (e.g., T5 = posterior temporal cortex)
Localization is regional, not exact anatomical pinpointing
Both A and B are correct
EEG can pinpoint exact submillimeter locations
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Electrodes map to cortical regions, but localization is regional approximation, not exact pinpointing. Understanding this limitation is important.

questions.stem: Which features characterize generalized epileptiform patterns?
options: Frontal maximum is common in generalized spike-and-wave
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Generalized patterns show bilateral synchrony, symmetry, and often frontal maximum. This distinguishes them from focal patterns which are asymmetric.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding hyperventilation activation?
options: More effective in children than adults for activating absence seizures
Can activate 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave in absence epilepsy
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: HV is more effective in children and classically activates 3 Hz spike-and-wave in absence epilepsy. This is a well-established activation procedure.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of wicket spikes?
options: Arch-shaped, occur in trains, temporal region
No aftergoing slow wave, no background disruption
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Wicket spikes are arch-shaped, temporal, occur in trains, lack aftergoing slow waves, and don't disrupt background. They are benign, not epileptiform.

questions.stem: A technologist changes sensitivity from 7 μV/mm to 14 μV/mm. The technologist should understand that:
options: Waveforms will appear smaller on the display
Actual brain voltage is unchanged; only display scaling changed
Both A and B are correct
The brain activity has actually decreased
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Higher sensitivity value (14 μV/mm) means lower gain (smaller display). Actual brain voltage is unchanged; only the display scale changed.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old child's EEG shows a 7 Hz posterior rhythm that is reactive. The technologist should:
options: Recognize this is age-appropriate; PDR frequency increases with age, and 7 Hz is normal for a 4-year-old
Increase filters to see if faster activity is hidden
questions.explanation: A 7 Hz posterior rhythm in a 4-year-old is within normal limits. PDR frequency matures with age. Reactivity confirms it's genuine PDR. This is age-appropriate, not abnormal.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of vertex waves?
options: High-amplitude, sharp transients maximal at Cz
Occur during N1 and N2 sleep stages
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vertex waves are high-amplitude, sharp, maximal at Cz, and occur during N1/N2 sleep. They are normal sleep graphoelements, not pathology.

questions.stem: All electrodes show 3-4 kΩ impedance except T3 at 12 kΩ. The EEG shows noise. The technologist should:
options: Proceed; all values are under 20 kΩ
Re-prep T3 to balance impedance; the 8-9 kΩ difference causes artifact
Use notch filter to eliminate noise
questions.explanation: The 8-9 kΩ difference between T3 and other electrodes causes artifact, even though both values are individually 'acceptable'. Impedance balance is critical. Re-prepping T3 is correct.

questions.stem: A technologist observes a sharp transient with 90 ms duration. The technologist should classify this as:
questions.explanation: Sharp waves are defined as 70-200 ms duration. A 90 ms transient is a sharp wave, not a spike (20-70 ms) or slow wave (>200 ms). Duration is key for classification.

questions.stem: A focal sharp wave is subtle in bipolar montage but prominent in average reference. The technologist should understand that:
options: Average reference enhances focal activity by subtracting common activity; this is a montage effect
questions.explanation: Average reference can enhance focal abnormalities by subtracting common-mode activity. This is a technical effect of montage choice, not a change in the actual abnormality.

questions.stem: An awake adult's PDR shows poor reactivity to eye opening. The technologist should consider:
options: Normal PDR should attenuate with eye opening; poor reactivity should be documented
Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medication effects, or encephalopathy depending on context
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both A and B are correct: Normal PDR should attenuate with eye opening, and poor reactivity should be documented. Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medications, or encephalopathy depending on context - it is NOT always normal (Option C is false). Context (patient state, medications) is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: Which activation procedures can improve diagnostic yield in epilepsy evaluation?
options: Sleep-deprived EEG (increases sleep and interictal activity)
Sleep recording (activates some seizure types, especially frontal lobe)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep-deprived EEG increases sleep and interictal discharges. Sleep itself activates some seizure types (especially frontal). Both improve diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: Which features help identify ECG artifact?
options: Regular, ~1 Hz (60-100 bpm), time-locked to pulse
Appears in all channels, sharp deflections
Both A and D are correct
questions.explanation: Both A and D are correct: ECG artifact is regular (~1 Hz, 60-100 bpm) and time-locked to pulse (option A). ECG artifact can appear in a single channel, especially when there's an electrode issue or poor contact near the heart (option D). While ECG can appear in multiple channels, single-channel appearance is also a common identifying feature.

questions.stem: Which changes indicate ictal evolution during a seizure?
options: Changes in frequency (e.g., fast to slower, or slower to faster)
Changes in amplitude or spatial distribution (spreading)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal evolution shows changes in frequency, amplitude, or spatial distribution over time. Static patterns without evolution are interictal, not ictal.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG polarity and deflections?
options: Polarity is relative and depends on montage and electrode orientation
Negative deflections indicate relative negativity at the active electrode
Both A and B are correct
Polarity is always absolute and never changes
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Polarity is relative to montage choice. Negative deflection means relative negativity at active electrode. Understanding this is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding subdermal needle electrodes?
options: Require strict sterile technique and have higher infection risk
Should only be used when scalp access is truly limited
Both A and B are correct
Are always preferred over cup electrodes
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Needle electrodes have higher infection risk, require sterile technique, and should only be used when scalp prep is not possible. Cup electrodes are generally preferred.

questions.stem: Which factors determine if amplitude asymmetry is clinically significant?
options: Degree of asymmetry (<50% may be normal variant)
Consistency across montages and correlation with other findings (slowing, epileptiform)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Significance depends on degree (<50% may be normal), consistency across montages, and correlation with other findings. Not all asymmetry is abnormal.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of normal photic driving?
options: Occipital activity that follows flash rate (time-locked)
Both A and B are correct
Spike-and-wave complexes that persist after stimulation
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Normal photic driving shows occipital activity time-locked to flash rate, symmetric, maximal occipitally. Spike-and-wave or persistence indicates photosensitivity, not driving.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of triphasic waves?
options: Periodic, high-amplitude waves with three-phase morphology
Commonly seen in metabolic/toxic encephalopathies (e.g., hepatic)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Triphasic waves are periodic, high-amplitude, three-phase waves seen in metabolic/toxic encephalopathies. They are NOT epileptiform and should not be treated as seizures.

questions.stem: Which medications should be documented as they affect EEG interpretation?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Benzodiazepines cause beta; AEDs can suppress epileptiform. Many medications affect EEG. Accurate documentation is essential for proper interpretation.

questions.stem: Which features characterize classic 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave of absence epilepsy?
options: Perfect bilateral synchrony, symmetric distribution, frontal maximum
Activated by hyperventilation, especially in children
Both A and B are correct
Always focal in one temporal lobe
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 3 Hz spike-and-wave shows perfect synchrony, symmetry, frontal max, and is classically activated by HV in children with absence epilepsy.

questions.stem: Which features distinguish electrode pop from cerebral activity?
options: Isolated to single channel (not physiologic field)
Brief, high-amplitude, random timing (not time-locked to movement)
Both A and B are correct
Appears in all channels with physiologic distribution
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Electrode pop is single-channel, brief, high-amplitude, and random. Cerebral activity shows physiologic field distribution. These features distinguish artifact from real activity.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding theta activity in adults?
options: Normal during drowsiness and light sleep
Abnormal in fully awake, alert adults
Both A and B are correct
Always indicates pathology regardless of state
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Theta is state-dependent in adults - normal during drowsiness/sleep but abnormal when fully awake. Patient state must be accurately documented.

questions.stem: An EEG system samples at 500 Hz. The technologist should understand that:
options: Maximum accurately representable frequency is 250 Hz (Nyquist = sampling/2)
Frequencies above 250 Hz will alias (fold back as lower frequencies)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Nyquist frequency = sampling rate / 2. At 500 Hz sampling, max is 250 Hz. Higher frequencies alias (fold back), causing distortion. This is fundamental to digital signal processing.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of 14&6 Hz positive spikes?
options: Benign variant, common in children and adolescents
Maximal over posterior temporal regions during drowsiness
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 14&6 Hz positive spikes are benign, seen in children/adolescents during drowsiness, maximal posterior temporally. Should not be confused with epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, phase reversal occurs between F3-Fz and Fz-F4. The technologist should localize the abnormality to:
options: Fz (the electrode common to both channels showing reversal)
questions.explanation: Phase reversal localizes to the electrode common to both channels. Fz is common to F3-Fz and Fz-F4, so the abnormality is at Fz. This is a key localization principle.

questions.stem: Which features distinguish REM sleep from NREM sleep?
options: REM: Desynchronized low-amplitude background, rapid eye movements, low muscle tone
NREM: Synchronized activity (spindles/K-complexes in N2, slow waves in N3)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: REM shows desynchronized background with REMs and low tone; NREM shows synchronized activity (spindles/K-complexes or slow waves). These are distinct sleep stages.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding electrode impedance balance?
options: Balance between electrodes is more critical than absolute values
Large differences (>5 kΩ) cause artifact even if both values are individually acceptable
Both A and B are correct
Only absolute values matter, balance is irrelevant
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Impedance balance is critical. A 5+ kΩ difference causes significant artifact even if both electrodes are under 10 kΩ individually. Balance > absolute values.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding PDR frequency maturation?
options: PDR frequency increases with brain maturation and age
Slower PDR in children is normal and age-appropriate, not abnormal
Both A and B are correct
PDR frequency is identical at all ages
questions.explanation: Both are correct: PDR frequency matures with age (slower in children, faster in adults). Age-appropriate slower PDR in children is normal, not abnormal. This is critical for pediatric interpretation.

questions.stem: Which patterns can indicate ictal onset?
options: Rhythmic fast activity, rhythmic theta, or rhythmic delta
Both A and B are correct
Only isolated sharp waves without change
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal onset can show electrodecremental response or various rhythmic patterns (fast, theta, delta). Evolution distinguishes ictal from interictal. Isolated sharp waves without evolution are interictal.

questions.stem: A technologist raises LFF from 0.1 Hz to 0.5 Hz and observes that diffuse slowing appears less prominent. The technologist should:
options: Report that the encephalopathy has improved
Recognize this is filter artifact; interpret the original recording with standard LFF (0.1-0.3 Hz)
Lower the sensitivity to make it even less visible
Document that the patient's condition normalized
questions.explanation: High LFF artificially attenuates slow activity. This is technical artifact, not clinical change. Always interpret with standard filter settings (LFF 0.1-0.3 Hz). This is a common ABRET trap.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of lambda waves?
options: Occur with saccadic eye movements during wakefulness with eyes open
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Lambda waves are positive occipital transients associated with saccadic eye movements during wakefulness. They are normal, not epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Which conditions require caution or contraindicate hyperventilation?
options: Recent stroke, increased intracranial pressure, sickle cell disease
Severe respiratory conditions or inability to cooperate
Both A and B are correct
All patients can safely perform HV
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Recent stroke, increased ICP, sickle cell disease, and severe respiratory conditions are contraindications. Safety requires recognizing these and consulting with physician when uncertain.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG's ability to detect deep brain structures?
options: EEG primarily reflects superficial cortical activity
Deep structures (hippocampus, thalamus, brainstem) are poorly represented on scalp EEG
Both A and B are correct
EEG can detect all brain structures equally well
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EEG is limited to cortical surface activity. Deep structures are poorly represented due to distance and skull attenuation. This is a fundamental limitation of scalp EEG.

questions.stem: Which factors are favorable prognostic indicators in diffuse encephalopathy?
options: Preserved PDR reactivity to eye opening
Both A and B are correct
Complete absence of all background activity
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Preserved reactivity and milder slowing (theta vs delta) are favorable signs. Complete background suppression is ominous, not favorable. These factors help assess severity.

questions.stem: Which features help identify sweat artifact?
options: Worse in hairy areas, affects multiple channels due to salt bridging
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sweat artifact shows slow, irregular drift due to salt bridging between electrodes, worse in hairy areas, affecting multiple channels. This can mimic slowing but is technical artifact.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding aftergoing slow waves in epileptiform discharges?
options: Common but not required for epileptiform classification
Morphology (pointed, sharp), field (physiologic), and context are more important
Both A and B are correct
Always present in all epileptiform discharges
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Aftergoing slow waves are common but not required. Classification depends on morphology, physiologic field, and context. Absence of slow wave doesn't exclude epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding average reference montage effects?
options: Can enhance focal abnormalities by subtracting common-mode activity
May make focal sharp waves more prominent than in bipolar montage
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Average reference subtracts common activity, enhancing focal abnormalities. A focal sharp wave may be more visible in average reference. This is a technical effect, not a change in the abnormality.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of normal PDR reactivity?
options: Both A and B are correct
PDR should never change with eye state
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Normal PDR attenuates with eye opening and returns with eye closure. This reactivity is a key feature of normal PDR. Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medication, or encephalopathy.

questions.stem: Which activation procedures can improve diagnostic yield in epilepsy?
options: Sleep-deprived EEG (increases sleep and interictal activity)
Sleep recording (activates some seizure types, especially frontal lobe epilepsy)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep-deprived EEG increases sleep and interictal discharges. Sleep itself activates some seizure types, especially frontal lobe. Both significantly improve diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding differential amplifiers?
options: Amplify voltage difference between active and reference electrodes
Reject common-mode noise (present in both electrodes) through CMRR
Both A and B are correct
Amplify all signals equally without discrimination
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Differential amplifiers amplify differences between electrodes and reject common noise through CMRR (common-mode rejection ratio). This is fundamental to EEG signal quality and noise reduction.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of sleep spindles?
options: Maximal centrally (C3-C4), characteristic of N2 sleep
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep spindles are 12-14 Hz, central, and characteristic of N2 sleep. They are normal graphoelements, not pathology. Their presence helps identify N2 sleep stage.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding high-frequency filter (HFF) settings?
options: Excessively low HFF (<20 Hz) can attenuate spikes and sharp waves
Standard HFF is typically 35-70 Hz to preserve spikes while reducing very high-frequency noise
Both A and B are correct
HFF settings don't affect spike visibility
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Low HFF attenuates fast activity including spikes. Standard HFF (35-70 Hz) preserves spikes while reducing noise. Too low HFF masks important epileptiform findings - a common ABRET trap.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding focal polymorphic delta slowing?
options: Suggests underlying structural or functional abnormality in that region
Persists across montages, helping distinguish from artifact
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Focal polymorphic delta is abnormal and suggests pathology (structural lesion, seizure focus, etc.). Persistence across montages confirms it's not artifact. This is a significant finding requiring documentation.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG as a measurement system?
options: EEG is a passive recording system (measures, doesn't deliver electricity)
Measures voltage differences (potential differences), not electrical current flow
Both A and B are correct
EEG delivers current to the brain
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EEG is passive (records voltage differences, doesn't deliver current). This is a fundamental distinction from stimulation or power delivery systems. Understanding this is important for safety and interpretation.

questions.stem: Which practices are essential for achieving good electrode contact and signal quality?
options: Proper scalp preparation (abrasion/cleaning to reduce impedance)
Adequate conductive paste/gel and secure electrode attachment
Both A and B are correct
Electrode placement doesn't affect signal quality
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Good scalp prep reduces impedance; adequate conductive medium and secure attachment ensure stable contact. These are fundamental practices for quality recordings.

questions.stem: Which patterns are commonly seen in the postictal period?
options: Postictal slowing (delta/theta) before gradual return of background
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Postictal period commonly shows suppression followed by slowing before gradual return of background. This helps confirm a true ictal event occurred and distinguishes from artifact.

questions.stem: Which features indicate photosensitivity (IPS) rather than normal photic driving?
options: Spike-and-wave complexes NOT time-locked to flash rate
Epileptiform activity that may persist after stimulation stops
Both A and B are correct
Occipital activity that follows flash rate exactly
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Photosensitivity shows epileptiform activity (spike-and-wave) not time-locked to flash and may persist. Normal driving follows flash rate exactly. These are distinct phenomena with different clinical significance.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of BETS (benign epileptiform transients of sleep)?
options: Brief duration (50-100 ms), low amplitude, temporal location
Occur during drowsiness/sleep, lack aftergoing slow waves
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: BETS are brief, low-amplitude, temporal, occur during drowsiness/sleep, and lack aftergoing slow waves. They are benign variants, not epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Which filter settings can lead to misinterpretation of EEG findings?
options: High LFF (>0.5 Hz) masking diffuse slowing
Low HFF (<20 Hz) attenuating spikes, or notch filter distorting activity near 60 Hz
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: High LFF masks slowing; low HFF attenuates spikes; notch distorts activity near 60 Hz. All can cause misinterpretation. Standard settings (LFF 0.1-0.3 Hz, HFF 35-70 Hz) minimize distortion.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding neonatal EEG discontinuity?
options: Trace alternant (discontinuous pattern) is normal up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age
Discontinuity decreases with increasing post-conceptual age as brain matures
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Trace alternant is normal in neonates up to ~44 weeks post-conceptual age. Continuity increases with maturation. Discontinuity in older infants/children is abnormal.

questions.stem: Which features help distinguish true epileptiform discharges from artifact?
options: Physiologic field distribution (not confined to single channel, spreads appropriately)
Pointed, sharp morphology distinct from background
Both A and B are correct
Artifact always looks identical to epileptiform activity
questions.explanation: Both are correct: True epileptiform shows physiologic field (spreads appropriately) and pointed morphology. Artifact is often single-channel or non-physiologic. Both features are essential for accurate identification.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding using multiple montages for interpretation?
options: Bipolar and referential montages provide complementary information
Using both helps confirm findings and improve localization accuracy
Both A and B are correct
Only one montage type is ever needed
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Bipolar aids localization via phase reversal; referential aids field assessment. Using both confirms findings and improves accuracy. Multiple montages are standard practice for comprehensive interpretation.

questions.stem: Which graphoelements must be present to identify N2 sleep?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: N2 sleep requires both spindles and K-complexes. REMs occur in REM sleep, not N2. Both elements are necessary for accurate N2 sleep stage identification.

questions.stem: Which steps should be taken when 60 Hz artifact appears in all channels?
options: Check ground electrode impedance and contact first
Check room electrical environment and nearby equipment
Both A and B are correct
Immediately use notch filter without checking source
questions.explanation: Both are correct: 60 Hz affecting all channels suggests ground or environmental issue. Check ground contact/impedance and electrical environment first. Fix source before using notch filter to avoid distortion.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding prominent frontal beta activity?
options: Commonly medication-induced (benzodiazepines, barbiturates, other CNS depressants)
Is a medication effect, not necessarily abnormal brain activity
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Prominent frontal beta is commonly medication-induced and should be documented but not overinterpreted. It's an effect of medications, not necessarily abnormal brain activity.

questions.stem: Which features distinguish ictal from interictal epileptiform activity?
options: Ictal shows evolution (frequency/amplitude/distribution changes over time)
Both A and B are correct
Isolated sharp waves without evolution are ictal
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ictal shows evolution and clinical correlation. Isolated sharp waves without evolution are interictal, not ictal. Evolution is the key distinguishing feature.

questions.stem: Which features help identify eye blink artifact?
options: Both A and B are correct
Always appears in all channels equally
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Eye blinks are frontal, out-of-phase, and time-locked to visible blinks. Correlation with visible movement confirms it's artifact, not cerebral activity.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding diffuse slowing severity?
options: Delta slowing (1-3 Hz) indicates more severe encephalopathy than theta (4-7 Hz)
Degree of slowing correlates with encephalopathy severity
Both A and B are correct
Theta and delta slowing indicate equal severity
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Delta slowing is more severe than theta. Degree of slowing (theta vs delta) correlates with encephalopathy severity. This is important for interpretation and prognosis.

questions.stem: Which sweep speed settings are appropriate for different viewing purposes?
options: 30 mm/s: Spreads waveforms for better spike identification
10 mm/s: Compresses for viewing slow waves and overall background
Both A and B are correct
Sweep speed doesn't affect what you can see
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Faster speeds (30 mm/s) spread for spike viewing; slower speeds (10 mm/s) compress for slow wave/background viewing. Both are useful for different purposes in comprehensive interpretation.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG electrode localization?
options: Electrodes correspond to underlying cortical regions (e.g., T5 = posterior temporal cortex)
Localization is regional, not exact anatomical pinpointing
Both A and B are correct
EEG can pinpoint exact submillimeter locations
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Electrodes map to cortical regions, but localization is regional approximation, not exact pinpointing. Understanding this limitation is important for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: Which features characterize generalized epileptiform patterns?
options: Frontal maximum is common in generalized spike-and-wave
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Generalized patterns show bilateral synchrony, symmetry, and often frontal maximum. This distinguishes them from focal patterns which are asymmetric and localized.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding hyperventilation activation?
options: More effective in children than adults for activating absence seizures
Can activate 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave in absence epilepsy
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: HV is more effective in children and classically activates 3 Hz spike-and-wave in absence epilepsy. This is a well-established, highly effective activation procedure for absence seizures.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of wicket spikes?
options: Arch-shaped, occur in trains, temporal region
No aftergoing slow wave, no background disruption
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Wicket spikes are arch-shaped, temporal, occur in trains, lack aftergoing slow waves, and don't disrupt background. They are benign variants, not epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: A technologist changes sensitivity from 7 μV/mm to 14 μV/mm. The technologist should understand that:
options: Waveforms will appear smaller on the display
Actual brain voltage is unchanged; only display scaling changed
Both A and B are correct
The brain activity has actually decreased
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Higher sensitivity value (14 μV/mm) means lower gain (smaller display). Actual brain voltage is unchanged; only the display scale changed. This is a display setting, not a change in brain activity.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old child's EEG shows a 7.5 Hz posterior rhythm that is reactive. The technologist should:
options: Recognize this is age-appropriate; PDR frequency increases with age, and 7.5 Hz is normal for a 5-year-old
Increase filters to see if faster activity is hidden
questions.explanation: A 7.5 Hz posterior rhythm in a 5-year-old is within normal limits. PDR frequency matures with age. Reactivity confirms it's genuine PDR. This is age-appropriate, not abnormal. Understanding age norms is critical.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of vertex waves?
options: High-amplitude, sharp transients maximal at Cz
Occur during N1 and N2 sleep stages
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vertex waves are high-amplitude, sharp, maximal at Cz, and occur during N1/N2 sleep. They are normal sleep graphoelements, not pathology. Their presence helps identify sleep stages.

questions.stem: All electrodes show 2-3 kΩ impedance except P3 at 11 kΩ. The EEG shows noise. The technologist should:
options: Proceed; all values are under 20 kΩ
Re-prep P3 to balance impedance; the 8-9 kΩ difference causes artifact
Use notch filter to eliminate noise
questions.explanation: The 8-9 kΩ difference between P3 and other electrodes causes artifact, even though both values are individually 'acceptable'. Impedance balance is critical. Re-prepping P3 is the correct approach.

questions.stem: A technologist observes a sharp transient with 75 ms duration. The technologist should classify this as:
questions.explanation: Sharp waves are defined as 70-200 ms duration. A 75 ms transient is a sharp wave, not a spike (20-70 ms) or slow wave (>200 ms). Duration is key for accurate classification.

questions.stem: A focal sharp wave is subtle in bipolar montage but prominent in average reference. The technologist should understand that:
options: Average reference enhances focal activity by subtracting common activity; this is a montage effect
questions.explanation: Average reference can enhance focal abnormalities by subtracting common-mode activity. This is a technical effect of montage choice, not a change in the actual abnormality. Both montages are valuable.

questions.stem: An awake adult's PDR shows poor reactivity to eye opening. The technologist should consider:
options: Normal PDR should attenuate with eye opening; poor reactivity should be documented
Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medication effects, or encephalopathy depending on context
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both A and B are correct: Normal PDR should attenuate with eye opening, and poor reactivity should be documented. Poor reactivity may indicate drowsiness, medications, or encephalopathy depending on context - it is NOT always normal (Option C is false). Context (patient state, medications, clinical history) is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: Which activation procedures can improve diagnostic yield in epilepsy evaluation?
options: Sleep-deprived EEG (increases sleep and interictal activity)
Sleep recording (activates some seizure types, especially frontal lobe epilepsy)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep-deprived EEG increases sleep and interictal discharges. Sleep itself activates some seizure types, especially frontal lobe. Both significantly improve diagnostic yield in epilepsy evaluation.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding differential amplifiers?
options: Amplify voltage difference between active and reference electrodes
Reject common-mode noise (present in both electrodes) through CMRR
Both A and B are correct
Amplify all signals equally without discrimination
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Differential amplifiers amplify differences between electrodes and reject common noise through CMRR (common-mode rejection ratio). This is fundamental to EEG signal quality and noise reduction.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of sleep spindles?
options: Maximal centrally (C3-C4), characteristic of N2 sleep
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Sleep spindles are 12-14 Hz, central, and characteristic of N2 sleep. They are normal graphoelements, not pathology. Their presence helps identify N2 sleep stage.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding high-frequency filter (HFF) settings?
options: Excessively low HFF (<20 Hz) can attenuate spikes and sharp waves
Standard HFF is typically 35-70 Hz to preserve spikes while reducing very high-frequency noise
Both A and B are correct
HFF settings don't affect spike visibility
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Low HFF attenuates fast activity including spikes. Standard HFF (35-70 Hz) preserves spikes while reducing noise. Too low HFF masks important epileptiform findings - a common ABRET trap.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding focal polymorphic delta slowing?
options: Suggests underlying structural or functional abnormality in that region
Persists across montages, helping distinguish from artifact
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Focal polymorphic delta is abnormal and suggests pathology (structural lesion, seizure focus, etc.). Persistence across montages confirms it's not artifact. This is a significant finding.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG as a measurement system?
options: EEG is a passive recording system (measures, doesn't deliver electricity)
Measures voltage differences (potential differences), not electrical current flow
Both A and B are correct
EEG delivers current to the brain
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EEG is passive (records voltage differences, doesn't deliver current). This is a fundamental distinction from stimulation or power delivery systems. Understanding this is important for safety and interpretation.

questions.stem: Which practices are essential for achieving good electrode contact and signal quality?
options: Proper scalp preparation (abrasion/cleaning to reduce impedance)
Adequate conductive paste/gel and secure electrode attachment
Both A and B are correct
Electrode placement doesn't affect signal quality
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Good scalp prep reduces impedance; adequate conductive medium and secure attachment ensure stable contact. These are fundamental practices for quality recordings.

questions.stem: An EEG shows intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta activity maximal over the temporal regions, occurring in brief bursts. The technologist should identify this as:
questions.explanation: TIRDA is intermittent, rhythmic delta (1-3 Hz) maximal temporally. It occurs in brief bursts and is associated with temporal lobe dysfunction. It should not be confused with spindles (12-14 Hz, central) or epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta activity appears maximal over the frontal regions in brief bursts. The technologist should recognize this as:
questions.explanation: FIRDA is intermittent, rhythmic delta (1-3 Hz) maximal frontally. It occurs in bursts and is associated with deep midline or frontal dysfunction. It differs from vertex waves (sharp, sleep-related) and epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Brief bursts of intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta activity appear maximal over the occipital regions. The technologist should identify this as:
questions.explanation: OIRDA is intermittent, rhythmic delta (1-3 Hz) maximal occipitally. It occurs in bursts and is often seen in children. It differs from PDR (8-13 Hz, continuous), photic driving (time-locked to flash), and lambda waves (positive transients with eye movement).

questions.stem: Intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta activity appears diffusely without clear regional maximum. The technologist should classify this as:
questions.explanation: IRDA without clear regional maximum is generalized IRDA. TIRDA, FIRDA, and OIRDA have specific regional maxima (temporal, frontal, occipital respectively). The regional maximum determines the classification.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding TIRDA?
options: Intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta, maximal temporally
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: TIRDA is intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta maximal temporally and is associated with temporal lobe dysfunction. It is abnormal, not a normal variant.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding FIRDA?
options: Associated with deep midline or frontal dysfunction
Intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta, maximal frontally
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: FIRDA is intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta maximal frontally and is associated with deep midline or frontal dysfunction. It is abnormal, not a normal sleep pattern.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding OIRDA?
options: More common in children, intermittent rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta maximal occipitally
Can be seen in association with occipital dysfunction or metabolic conditions
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: OIRDA is more common in children, shows intermittent rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta maximal occipitally, and can be associated with occipital dysfunction or metabolic conditions. It is abnormal, not a normal PDR variant.

questions.stem: Which feature is MOST important for distinguishing TIRDA, FIRDA, and OIRDA?
questions.explanation: Regional maximum is the key distinguishing feature: TIRDA (temporal), FIRDA (frontal), OIRDA (occipital). All have similar frequency (1-3 Hz) and intermittent nature. Regional maximum determines classification.

questions.stem: Which are characteristics of IRDA patterns (TIRDA, FIRDA, OIRDA)?
options: Intermittent (occur in brief bursts, not continuous)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA patterns are intermittent (brief bursts) and show rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta. They are not continuous background activity. The intermittent nature is a key feature.

questions.stem: A technologist observes TIRDA in a patient with temporal lobe epilepsy. The technologist should understand that:
options: TIRDA is slowing, not epileptiform activity, but may indicate underlying temporal dysfunction
TIRDA and temporal epileptiform discharges can coexist but are distinct patterns
Both A and B are correct
TIRDA is the same as temporal spikes
questions.explanation: Both are correct: TIRDA is slowing (delta), not epileptiform, but indicates temporal dysfunction. It can coexist with temporal spikes but they are distinct patterns with different clinical significance.

questions.stem: Which statements help distinguish FIRDA from other frontal patterns?
options: FIRDA is intermittent rhythmic delta (1-3 Hz), not continuous
FIRDA is associated with deep midline/frontal dysfunction, not surface cortical
Both A and B are correct
FIRDA is identical to frontal spikes
questions.explanation: Both are correct: FIRDA is intermittent rhythmic delta (not continuous) and associated with deep midline/frontal dysfunction. It differs from frontal spikes (epileptiform) and continuous frontal slowing.

questions.stem: Which features help distinguish OIRDA from normal PDR?
options: OIRDA is slower (1-3 Hz delta) and intermittent; PDR is faster (8-13 Hz alpha) and continuous
OIRDA occurs in bursts; PDR is relatively continuous and reactive to eye opening
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: OIRDA is slower (1-3 Hz), intermittent bursts; PDR is faster (8-13 Hz), continuous, and reactive. These are distinct patterns with different clinical significance.

questions.stem: Which conditions are commonly associated with IRDA patterns?
options: Deep midline dysfunction (for FIRDA) or temporal dysfunction (for TIRDA)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA patterns can be associated with metabolic/toxic encephalopathies or regional dysfunction (deep midline for FIRDA, temporal for TIRDA). They are abnormal, not normal variants.

questions.stem: Which are key characteristics for identifying IRDA patterns?
options: Rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta frequency with regional maximum
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA patterns are intermittent (brief bursts) and show rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta with regional maximum. They are not continuous background slowing. Both features are essential for identification.

questions.stem: A technologist observes intermittent rhythmic delta activity but cannot determine a clear regional maximum. The technologist should classify this as:
questions.explanation: If no clear regional maximum is evident, classify as generalized IRDA. TIRDA, FIRDA, and OIRDA require clear regional maxima (temporal, frontal, occipital respectively). Don't assume a location.

questions.stem: Which feature distinguishes IRDA from polymorphic delta slowing?
options: IRDA is rhythmic and intermittent; polymorphic delta is irregular and may be continuous
IRDA has specific regional maximum; polymorphic delta may be focal or diffuse
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA is rhythmic and intermittent; polymorphic delta is irregular and may be continuous. IRDA has regional maximum; polymorphic delta may be focal or diffuse. These are distinct patterns.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding OIRDA in pediatric patients?
options: More commonly seen in children than adults
May be associated with occipital dysfunction or metabolic conditions
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: OIRDA is more common in children and may be associated with occipital dysfunction or metabolic conditions. It is abnormal, not a normal developmental pattern.

questions.stem: FIRDA is thought to reflect dysfunction of which structures?
options: Deep midline structures (thalamus, brainstem) or frontal dysfunction
questions.explanation: FIRDA is associated with deep midline structures (thalamus, brainstem) or frontal dysfunction, not just superficial frontal cortex. This reflects the pattern's origin from deep structures projecting to frontal regions.

questions.stem: A patient's EEG shows both TIRDA and temporal sharp waves. The technologist should:
options: Document both patterns; TIRDA is slowing, sharp waves are epileptiform - they are distinct but can coexist
Choose only one pattern to document
Ignore TIRDA and only document sharp waves
Report that they are the same pattern
questions.explanation: TIRDA (slowing) and temporal sharp waves (epileptiform) are distinct patterns that can coexist. Both should be documented. TIRDA indicates temporal dysfunction; sharp waves indicate epileptiform activity. They have different clinical significance.

questions.stem: Which frequency range characterizes IRDA patterns?
questions.explanation: IRDA patterns are characterized by 1-3 Hz delta frequency. They are slower than theta (4-7 Hz), alpha (8-13 Hz), or beta (14-30 Hz). The delta frequency is a key identifying feature.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the intermittent nature of IRDA?
options: IRDA occurs in brief bursts, not as continuous background
The intermittent nature helps distinguish it from continuous polymorphic delta
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA occurs in brief, intermittent bursts, not continuous background. This intermittent nature helps distinguish it from continuous polymorphic delta slowing. Intermittency is a key feature.

questions.stem: An occipital rhythm at 2 Hz appears intermittently in bursts. The technologist should identify this as:
questions.explanation: OIRDA is intermittent, rhythmic 1-3 Hz delta maximal occipitally. A 2 Hz occipital rhythm in bursts is OIRDA, not PDR (which is 8-13 Hz and continuous). The frequency and intermittent nature are key.

questions.stem: Which clinical conditions are commonly associated with FIRDA?
options: Deep midline lesions, thalamic dysfunction, or frontal pathology
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: FIRDA is associated with deep midline lesions, thalamic dysfunction, frontal pathology, or metabolic/toxic encephalopathies. It is abnormal, not a normal sleep pattern.

questions.stem: Which clinical conditions are commonly associated with TIRDA?
options: Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: TIRDA is associated with temporal lobe dysfunction, epilepsy, or metabolic conditions affecting temporal regions. It is abnormal, not a normal variant.

questions.stem: Which montage characteristics help identify the regional maximum of IRDA patterns?
options: Maximum should be consistent across montages (bipolar and referential)
Regional maximum determines classification (TIRDA vs FIRDA vs OIRDA)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Regional maximum should be consistent across montages. The maximum determines classification (temporal = TIRDA, frontal = FIRDA, occipital = OIRDA). Montage choice affects visibility but maximum should be consistent.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the 'rhythmic' nature of IRDA?
options: IRDA shows regular, rhythmic delta waves (not irregular/polymorphic)
The rhythmic quality helps distinguish it from polymorphic delta slowing
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA shows regular, rhythmic delta waves (not irregular). The rhythmic quality distinguishes it from polymorphic delta slowing, which is irregular. Rhythmicity is a key feature.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding OIRDA prevalence?
options: More common in children than adults
Can occur in adults but is less frequent
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: OIRDA is more common in children but can occur in adults (less frequent). It is not limited to neonates. Understanding age-related prevalence helps with interpretation.

questions.stem: When documenting IRDA patterns, the technologist should:
options: Specify the regional maximum (TIRDA, FIRDA, or OIRDA) if clear
Document as generalized IRDA if no clear regional maximum
Both A and B are correct
Always use generic 'IRDA' term regardless of maximum
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Specify regional maximum (TIRDA/FIRDA/OIRDA) if clear. If no clear maximum, document as generalized IRDA. Accurate classification aids clinical interpretation.

questions.stem: Which features help distinguish IRDA from triphasic waves?
options: IRDA is intermittent rhythmic delta; triphasic waves are periodic with three-phase morphology
IRDA has regional maximum; triphasic waves are often generalized with frontal maximum
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA is intermittent rhythmic delta; triphasic waves are periodic with characteristic three-phase morphology. IRDA has regional maximum; triphasic waves are often generalized. These are distinct patterns.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the clinical significance of IRDA patterns?
options: IRDA patterns are abnormal and indicate underlying dysfunction
Regional maximum (TIRDA/FIRDA/OIRDA) helps localize the dysfunction
Both A and B are correct
IRDA patterns are always normal variants
questions.explanation: Both are correct: IRDA patterns are abnormal and indicate underlying dysfunction. The regional maximum helps localize the dysfunction (temporal, frontal, or occipital). They are not normal variants.

questions.stem: A patient presents with progressive loss of peripheral vision, night blindness, and eventual tunnel vision. Fundoscopy shows bone-spicule pigmentation. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Retinitis pigmentosa: Classic triad includes nyctalopia (night blindness), peripheral field loss, and pigmentary retinal changes. Central vision is preserved until late stages. Macular degeneration affects central vision first.

questions.stem: Which condition primarily affects central vision and interferes with fine detail discrimination?
questions.explanation: Macular degeneration: The macula is responsible for high-acuity central vision. Peripheral vision is usually preserved. Retinitis pigmentosa affects peripheral vision first.

questions.stem: Sudden, painless, severe loss of vision in one eye is MOST characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Retinal artery occlusion: Acute ischemia to the retina often described as a 'curtain coming down.' This is an ophthalmologic emergency. Conjunctivitis and blepharitis cause irritation, not sudden vision loss.

questions.stem: Inflammation limited to the eyelid margins, often associated with crusting and irritation, is termed:
questions.explanation: Blepharitis: Affects eyelid margins specifically. Conjunctivitis affects the conjunctival membrane covering the eye. Ptosis is drooping, not inflammation.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding ocular vs optic terminology?
options: Ocular is a general term related to the eye; optic refers specifically to the optic nerve/vision pathways
Optic can be used interchangeably with ocular for all eye conditions
Both terms mean exactly the same thing
Ocular refers only to the optic nerve
questions.explanation: Ocular is a general term related to the eye; optic refers specifically to the optic nerve or vision pathways. They are not interchangeable. Using 'optic' for general eye conditions is a common exam trap.

questions.stem: A perception that occurs when there is actually nothing there to cause it, such as hearing noises when there are none, is termed:
questions.explanation: Hallucination: A false sensory perception in the absence of an external stimulus. Delusion is a false belief. Illusion is a misinterpretation of a real stimulus. These are distinct terms.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding acute vs chronic conditions?
options: Acute describes a condition that begins suddenly and is usually short-lasting
Chronic describes a condition that persists over a long period
Both A and B are correct
Acute and chronic mean the same thing
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Acute = sudden onset + short duration. Chronic = persistent over long period. This distinction is critical for medical terminology and clinical interpretation.

questions.stem: A bluish discoloration of the skin caused by low levels of oxygen in the blood is termed:
questions.explanation: Cyanosis: Bluish discoloration due to low oxygen saturation. Jaundice is yellowing (bilirubin). Pallor is paleness. These are distinct clinical signs with different causes.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding hepatitis vs cirrhosis?
options: Hepatitis refers to inflammation of the liver; cirrhosis refers to chronic scarring and architectural distortion
Both can result from viral infection, but cirrhosis represents end-stage changes
Both A and B are correct
Hepatitis and cirrhosis are the same condition
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Hepatitis = inflammation. Cirrhosis = chronic scarring/fibrosis. Cirrhosis can result from chronic hepatitis but represents end-stage architectural changes. They are distinct stages.

questions.stem: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes due to excess bilirubin in the blood, usually a sign of liver disorder, is termed:
questions.explanation: Jaundice: Yellowing due to excess bilirubin, often indicating liver dysfunction. Cyanosis is bluish (low oxygen). These are distinct clinical signs with different pathophysiologies.

questions.stem: Which form of hepatitis is transmitted through contaminated food or water?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A: Fecal-oral transmission via contaminated food/water. Hepatitis B/C are blood and sexual contact. Hepatitis D requires co-infection with Hepatitis B. Transmission routes are critical distinctions.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Parkinson disease vs Alzheimer disease?
options: Parkinson disease presents with movement disorder first (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia); Alzheimer disease presents with memory loss first
Parkinson disease EEG is usually normal early; Alzheimer disease shows diffuse slowing
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Parkinson = movement disorder first (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), normal EEG early. Alzheimer = memory loss first, diffuse slowing on EEG. First symptom is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: A young adult (age 35) presents with dementia, chorea (involuntary movements), and psychiatric symptoms. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Huntington disease: Young adult + dementia + chorea + psychiatric symptoms is classic. Alzheimer and Parkinson typically present later. Age + movement disorder + dementia = Huntington.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding vascular dementia vs Alzheimer disease?
options: Vascular dementia shows stepwise deterioration (worsens after each stroke); Alzheimer shows smooth, gradual decline
Vascular dementia may show focal slowing on EEG; Alzheimer shows diffuse slowing
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vascular dementia = stepwise decline after strokes, may show focal slowing. Alzheimer = smooth gradual decline, diffuse slowing. Progression pattern is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: A patient presents with rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months), myoclonus, and EEG shows periodic sharp wave complexes. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: Rapidly progressive dementia (weeks-months) + myoclonus + periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG is classic CJD. The periodic EEG pattern is highly specific. Other dementias progress more slowly.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding encephalitis vs meningitis?
options: Encephalitis is inflammation of brain tissue; meningitis is inflammation of meningeal coverings
Encephalitis often shows diffuse slowing ± epileptiform on EEG; meningitis may show diffuse slowing
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Encephalitis = brain tissue inflammation, often shows diffuse slowing ± epileptiform. Meningitis = meningeal inflammation, may show diffuse slowing. Brain vs coverings is the key distinction.

questions.stem: A patient develops rapidly ascending weakness, absent reflexes, and recent flu-like illness. EEG is normal. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Guillain-Barré syndrome: Peripheral nervous system disorder, immune-mediated demyelination, often post-infectious, ascending weakness, absent reflexes, normal EEG (peripheral disorder). ALS is progressive motor neuron degeneration.

questions.stem: A child has motor impairment and abnormal posture since infancy. Symptoms do not worsen over time. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Cerebral palsy: Non-progressive motor disorder due to early brain injury. Muscular dystrophies are progressive and worsen over time. Non-progressive nature is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: A possibly life-threatening condition in which breathing stops, for either a short or long period of time, is termed:
questions.explanation: Apnea: Complete cessation of breathing. Dyspnea is difficulty breathing. Tachypnea is rapid breathing. Bradypnea is slow breathing. Apnea is the most serious, potentially life-threatening.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding asthma vs COPD?
options: Asthma is reversible airway inflammation; COPD is chronic, irreversible airflow obstruction
COPD is a combination of emphysema and chronic bronchitis
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Asthma = reversible inflammation. COPD = chronic irreversible obstruction (emphysema + chronic bronchitis). Reversibility is the key discriminator for treatment and prognosis.

questions.stem: Increased blood pressure in the arteries supplying blood to the lungs, caused by increased resistance of blood flow in the lungs, usually the result of lung disease, is termed:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary hypertension: Increased pressure in pulmonary arteries, often due to lung disease. Can lead to right heart strain (cor pulmonale). Distinct from systemic hypertension.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding myositis vs myopathy?
options: Myositis is muscle inflammation causing pain and weakness; myopathy is a general term for muscle disease
Myositis has '-itis' suffix indicating inflammation; myopathy is broader and not necessarily inflammatory
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Myositis = inflammation (suffix '-itis'). Myopathy = general muscle disease (may or may not be inflammatory). The '-itis' suffix specifically indicates inflammation.

questions.stem: Inflammation of the spinal cord which can cause headaches, fever, muscle stiffness, pain, weakness and eventually paralysis is termed:
questions.explanation: Myelitis: Spinal cord inflammation (suffix '-itis'). Myelopathy is broader spinal cord disease. Myositis is muscle inflammation. Multiple sclerosis is demyelination, not primarily inflammation.

questions.stem: A disease in which the protective coverings of nerve fibers in the brain are gradually destroyed with symptoms of numbness to paralysis and loss of control of bodily function is termed:
questions.explanation: Multiple sclerosis: CNS demyelination affecting brain and spinal cord. ALS is motor neuron degeneration. Guillain-Barré is peripheral demyelination. MS is central nervous system specific.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding vertebra vs spine?
options: Vertebra refers to a single bone (one of 33); spine refers to the entire column
The spine is made up of multiple vertebrae
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vertebra = single bone (one of 33). Spine = entire column of bones and cartilage. This distinction prevents confusion in medical terminology and clinical documentation.

questions.stem: The slipping of a vertebra in the spine over the one below it is termed:
questions.explanation: Spondylolisthesis: Vertebra slipping forward over the one below. Disk prolapse is herniated disk. Spondylolysis is vertebral defect. Laminectomy and spinal fusion are surgical procedures.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding laminectomy vs spinal fusion?
options: Laminectomy removes part of the vertebra to relieve pressure; spinal fusion joins vertebrae together
Laminectomy is decompressive surgery; spinal fusion is stabilizing surgery
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Laminectomy = bone removal (decompressive). Spinal fusion = bone joining (stabilizing). Different surgical goals: decompression vs stabilization.

questions.stem: A condition in which the spine curves to one side producing an S-shaped curve is termed:
questions.explanation: Scoliosis: Side-to-side curve (S-shaped). Kyphosis is excessive outward thoracic curve (hump). Lordosis is excessive inward lumbar curve. These are distinct spinal deformities.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding kyphosis vs lordosis?
options: Kyphosis is excessive outward curvature of the upper spine (hump); lordosis is excessive inward curvature of the lower spine
Kyphosis affects thoracic region; lordosis affects lumbar region
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Kyphosis = outward thoracic curve (hump). Lordosis = inward lumbar curve. Direction (outward vs inward) and location (thoracic vs lumbar) are key distinctions.

questions.stem: A procedure in which a needle is inserted into the lower region of the spinal canal to take out a sample of spinal fluid or inject a drug is termed:
options: Both A and B are correct (same procedure)
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Lumbar puncture and spinal tap are the same procedure. Laminectomy and spinal fusion are surgical procedures, not diagnostic/therapeutic needle procedures.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding retinitis pigmentosa vs macular degeneration?
options: Retinitis pigmentosa affects peripheral vision first; macular degeneration affects central vision first
Retinitis pigmentosa shows bone-spicule pigmentation; macular degeneration shows drusen deposits
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Retinitis pigmentosa = peripheral field loss first, bone-spicule pigmentation. Macular degeneration = central vision loss first, drusen deposits. Field of vision affected is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: Drooping of the upper eyelid is termed:
questions.explanation: Ptosis: Drooping of upper eyelid. Blepharitis is eyelid inflammation. Conjunctivitis is conjunctival inflammation. These are distinct conditions with different causes and treatments.

questions.stem: Persistent, rapid, involuntary movement of the eye is termed:
questions.explanation: Nystagmus: Involuntary rhythmic eye movements. Strabismus is misalignment. Diplopia is double vision. Amblyopia is lazy eye. These are distinct ophthalmologic terms.

questions.stem: A term describing a condition that affects both sides of the body or two paired organs, such as deafness in both ears, is:
questions.explanation: Bilateral: Affecting both sides. Unilateral = one side. Ipsilateral = same side. Contralateral = opposite side. This terminology is critical for accurate medical documentation.

questions.stem: An unaware clenching or grinding of the teeth, usually during sleep, is termed:
questions.explanation: Bruxism: Unconscious teeth grinding/clenching, often during sleep. Trismus is jaw locking. Dyskinesia is abnormal movement. These are distinct movement disorders.

questions.stem: A slow heart rate, usually below 60 beats per minute in adults, is termed:
questions.explanation: Bradycardia: Slow heart rate (<60 bpm in adults). Tachycardia is fast (>100 bpm). Arrhythmia is irregular rhythm. These are distinct cardiac rhythm terms.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Hepatitis B vs Hepatitis C?
options: Both are transmitted through blood and sexual contact
Both A and B are correct
Only Hepatitis A can become chronic
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Hepatitis B and C are both blood/sexual transmission and can become chronic. Hepatitis A does not become chronic. Chronicity is a key distinction between hepatitis types.

questions.stem: A form of hepatitis that only causes symptoms when the individual is already infected with Hepatitis B is:
questions.explanation: Hepatitis D: Requires co-infection with Hepatitis B (defective virus). Cannot exist independently. This is a critical distinction for understanding hepatitis transmission and treatment.

questions.stem: A cancerous tumor of the liver is termed:
questions.explanation: Hepatoma: Malignant liver tumor (hepatocellular carcinoma). Hepatitis is inflammation. Cirrhosis is scarring. Hepatic adenoma is benign. These are distinct liver conditions.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Parkinson disease pathophysiology?
options: Parkinson disease involves degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra
Core features include resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity
Both A and B are correct
Parkinson disease primarily affects memory first
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Parkinson = substantia nigra dopamine neuron degeneration, classic triad (tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity). Memory loss is NOT the primary feature (that's Alzheimer).

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Alzheimer disease pathophysiology?
options: Alzheimer disease involves cortical neuron degeneration, especially hippocampus and temporal lobes
Progressive memory loss is the first and dominant symptom
Both A and B are correct
Alzheimer disease primarily affects movement first
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Alzheimer = cortical/hippocampal degeneration, memory loss FIRST. Movement disorders are NOT primary (that's Parkinson). First symptom is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Huntington disease?
options: Huntington disease involves basal ganglia (caudate nucleus) degeneration
Classic triad includes chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and dementia
Both A and B are correct
Huntington disease only affects older adults
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Huntington = basal ganglia degeneration, classic triad (chorea + psychiatric + dementia). Onset is typically 30-50 years, NOT just older adults. Age + movement + dementia = Huntington.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding vascular dementia?
options: Vascular dementia is caused by multiple strokes or chronic ischemia
Key hallmark is stepwise deterioration (worsens after each stroke)
Both A and B are correct
Vascular dementia shows smooth, gradual decline like Alzheimer
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vascular dementia = multiple strokes/ischemia, STEPWISE decline (not smooth). Smooth decline = Alzheimer. Progression pattern is the critical discriminator.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)?
options: CJD is a prion disease with rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months)
EEG shows periodic sharp wave complexes, which is highly specific
Both A and B are correct
CJD progresses slowly over years like Alzheimer
questions.explanation: Both are correct: CJD = prion disease, RAPID progression (weeks-months), periodic sharp waves on EEG. Slow progression = Alzheimer. Speed + EEG pattern = CJD.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding HIV-associated dementia?
options: HIV dementia is a subcortical dementia with slowed thinking and poor concentration
Both A and B are correct
HIV dementia presents identically to Alzheimer disease
questions.explanation: Both are correct: HIV dementia = subcortical (slowed cognition), diffuse slowing on EEG. Alzheimer is cortical (memory loss first). Subcortical vs cortical is the key distinction.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis)?
options: ALS involves degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons
EEG is usually normal (motor neuron disease, not cortical)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: ALS = UMN + LMN degeneration, normal EEG (peripheral/motor neuron disease). Cognition is usually preserved. This distinguishes ALS from cortical dementias.

questions.stem: Poisoning from poorly preserved food contaminated with dangerous bacterial toxin that results in paralysis is termed:
questions.explanation: Botulism: Bacterial toxin (Clostridium botulinum) blocks acetylcholine release, causing descending paralysis. Tetanus causes spastic paralysis. Guillain-Barré is immune-mediated. Food source is key.

questions.stem: A genetic disorder in which a person's cells have one too many chromosomes, causing moderate to severe mental handicap and characteristic appearance, is:
questions.explanation: Down's syndrome: Trisomy 21 (extra chromosome 21). Huntington is autosomal dominant (not extra chromosome). Duchenne is X-linked. Chromosome count is the key identifier.

questions.stem: A disorder of the inner ear, causing hearing loss, ringing in the ear, and sensation that one's surroundings are spinning, is:
questions.explanation: Ménière's disease: Inner ear disorder with classic triad (hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo/spinning). Bell's palsy is facial nerve. Trigeminal neuralgia is facial pain. Inner ear + triad = Ménière's.

questions.stem: The medical term for suffocation that can be caused by choking on an object, lack of oxygen in the air, or chemicals such as carbon monoxide which reduce the amount of oxygen in the blood, is:
questions.explanation: Asphyxia: Suffocation from various causes (choking, low oxygen, CO poisoning). Apnea is cessation of breathing. Dyspnea is difficulty breathing. Hypoxia/anoxia are oxygen deficiency states.

questions.stem: The throat, the tube connecting the back of the mouth and nose to the esophagus and windpipe. Inflammation of the throat causing sore throat, fever, earache and swollen glands is:
questions.explanation: Pharynx / Pharyngitis: Throat connecting mouth/nose to esophagus/windpipe. Larynx is voice box. Trachea is windpipe. Esophagus is food tube. Anatomical location is critical.

questions.stem: A usually mild and temporary condition common in children under the age of 4 in which the walls of the airways become inflamed and narrow resulting in wheezing and coughing is:
questions.explanation: Croup: Pediatric condition (<4 years), airway inflammation, wheezing, barking cough. Asthma is chronic/recurrent. Bronchitis is lower airway. Age + acute + wheezing = croup.

questions.stem: Protrusion of the spinal cord and its coverings out from the spine, one of the more severe forms of spina bifida, is termed:
questions.explanation: Myelomeningocele: Spinal cord + meninges protrusion (most severe spina bifida). Myelocele = cord only. Meningocele = meninges only. Spina bifida occulta = no protrusion. Components determine severity.

questions.stem: Build up of fibrous connective tissue in the bone marrow affecting the production of blood components is termed:
questions.explanation: Myelofibrosis: Fibrous replacement of bone marrow, affects hematopoiesis. Myelosclerosis is sometimes used but myelofibrosis is preferred. Multiple myeloma is cancer. Myelitis is inflammation.

questions.stem: A nerve that carries messages to a muscle that cause the muscle to move is termed:
questions.explanation: Motor nerve: Carries efferent signals to muscles (causes movement). Sensory nerve carries afferent signals (sensation). Mixed nerves do both. Direction of signal is key.
