questions.stem: A cancer affecting cells in the bone marrow is termed:
questions.explanation: Myeloma: Malignant plasma cell cancer in bone marrow. Myelofibrosis is fibrous replacement. Myelitis is inflammation. Myelopathy is general spinal cord disease. '-oma' suffix indicates tumor.

questions.stem: A disorder in which the lower part of the spine is weakened by an abnormally soft vertebra, often involving a defect or stress fracture in the pars interarticularis, is termed:
questions.explanation: Spondylolysis: Vertebral defect/stress fracture (pars interarticularis). Spondylolisthesis is vertebra slipping. Spondylitis is inflammation. Defect vs slipping is the distinction.

questions.stem: A birth defect in which a section of the baby's spine fails to develop completely, leaving the spinal cord exposed. The least dangerous form in which bones fail to close but there is no protrusion is:
questions.explanation: Spina bifida / Spina bifida occulta: Least severe form, no protrusion. Myelomeningocele = cord + meninges (most severe). Meningocele = meninges only. Severity increases with protrusion.

questions.stem: Inflammation of the joints between the bones of the spine is termed:
questions.explanation: Spondylitis: Inflammation of spinal joints. Spondylolysis = defect. Spondylolisthesis = slipping. Spondylosis = degenerative. '-itis' suffix indicates inflammation.

questions.stem: Pain along the sciatic nerve which runs down the length of the leg to the foot, usually caused by pressure on the nerve due to disk prolapse, tumor, abscess or blood clot, is termed:
questions.explanation: Sciatica: Sciatic nerve pain (leg distribution). Radiculopathy is general nerve root. Neuropathy is peripheral nerve. Neuralgia is nerve pain. Sciatic nerve specific = sciatica.

questions.stem: Episodes of dizziness and weakness caused by insufficient blood flow to the brain are termed:
questions.explanation: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency: Insufficient blood flow through vertebral/basilar arteries to brainstem/cerebellum, causing dizziness/weakness. TIA is transient focal deficit. Syncope is fainting. Specific artery involvement is key.

questions.stem: A disorder in which one of the disks located between the vertebrae breaks down and the pulpy interior squeezes out, causing pressure on a nerve, also called a slipped or ruptured disk, is:
questions.explanation: Disk prolapse: Herniated/ruptured disk with nucleus pulposus extrusion, causing nerve compression. Spondylolisthesis is vertebra slipping. Spondylolysis is vertebral defect. Disk vs bone is the distinction.

questions.stem: The shrinkage or near disappearance of a tissue or organ is termed:
questions.explanation: Atrophy: Tissue/organ shrinkage. Hypertrophy = increased size. Hyperplasia = increased cell number. Metaplasia = cell type change. Dysplasia = abnormal cell development. Direction of change is key.

questions.stem: An accumulation of pus in a body tissue, usually caused by bacterial infection, is termed:
questions.explanation: Abscess: Localized pus collection in tissue. Cellulitis is diffuse inflammation. Empyema is pus in body cavity. Fistula is abnormal connection. Gangrene is tissue death. Localized pus = abscess.

questions.stem: A hollow flexible tube inserted into the body to put in or take out fluid or to open up or close blood vessels is termed:
questions.explanation: Catheter: Flexible tube for fluid access/vessel manipulation. Cannula is rigid needle. Stent keeps vessel open. Shunt diverts flow. Drain removes fluid. Flexibility + access = catheter.

questions.stem: A waste product that is filtered from the blood by the kidneys and expelled in urine is:
questions.explanation: Creatinine: Muscle metabolism waste product, filtered by kidneys, excreted in urine. Urea is also kidney waste. Uric acid is purine breakdown. Bilirubin is heme breakdown. Creatinine is muscle-specific.

questions.stem: Term meaning 'in place' that is used to describe a cancer that has not spread is:
questions.explanation: In situ: Cancer confined to original location, has not spread (invaded or metastasized). Metastatic = spread. Invasive = penetrated tissue. Malignant = cancerous. In situ = localized.

questions.stem: Another term for fatty tissue that stores energy, insulates and cushions the body is:
questions.explanation: Adipose tissue: Fat tissue with energy storage, insulation, cushioning functions. Connective tissue is broader category. Epithelial is lining. Muscle is contractile. Nervous is neural. Fat-specific = adipose.

questions.stem: Difficulty falling and remaining asleep is termed:
questions.explanation: Insomnia: Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. Narcolepsy is excessive daytime sleepiness. Sleep apnea is breathing cessation. Hypersomnia is excessive sleep. Parasomnia is abnormal sleep behaviors.

questions.stem: Surgical removal of dead, damaged or infected tissue or some foreign material from a wound or burn is termed:
questions.explanation: Debridement: Removal of necrotic/infected tissue or foreign material from wounds. Excision is general removal. Incision is cutting. Drainage removes fluid. Irrigation is washing. Wound cleaning = debridement.

questions.stem: Anything that can cause cancer is termed:
questions.explanation: Carcinogen: Cancer-causing agent. Mutagen causes mutations (may or may not cause cancer). Teratogen causes birth defects. Oncogene promotes cancer. Tumor suppressor prevents cancer. Cancer-specific = carcinogen.

questions.stem: Related to fever is termed:
questions.explanation: Febrile: Fever-related. Afebrile = no fever. Hyperthermic = elevated temperature. Hypothermic = low temperature. Pyretic also means fever-related but febrile is more common. Fever-specific = febrile.

questions.stem: An unintended and unwanted side effect of some sort of treatment, usually drug therapy, is termed:
questions.explanation: Adverse reaction: Unintended harmful effect of treatment/drug. Therapeutic effect is intended benefit. Placebo effect is psychological. Drug interaction is drug-drug effect. Contraindication is reason to avoid.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding epilepsy?
options: Epilepsy is a disorder of the nervous system in which abnormal electrical activity in the brain causes recurrent seizures
EEG is central to diagnosis and shows epileptiform discharges
Both A and B are correct
Epilepsy always requires structural brain damage
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Epilepsy = recurrent unprovoked seizures from abnormal brain electrical activity. EEG is diagnostic cornerstone. Structural damage is NOT always required (idiopathic epilepsy exists).

questions.stem: Excess cerebrospinal fluid within the brain is termed:
questions.explanation: Hydrocephalus: Excess CSF accumulation in ventricles. Encephalitis is brain inflammation. Meningitis is meningeal inflammation. Intracranial hypertension is elevated pressure. Cerebral edema is brain swelling. CSF-specific = hydrocephalus.

questions.stem: Another name for facial palsy, the usually one-sided, temporary numbing of facial muscles caused by an inflamed nerve, is:
questions.explanation: Bell's palsy: Idiopathic facial nerve (CN VII) paralysis, usually unilateral, temporary. Trigeminal neuralgia is facial pain (CN V). Hemifacial spasm is involuntary movement. Bell's palsy is specific idiopathic form.

questions.stem: A virus that is the cause of mononucleosis and is involved in Burkitt's lymphoma is:
questions.explanation: Epstein-Barr virus: Causes infectious mononucleosis, associated with Burkitt's lymphoma. CMV causes mononucleosis-like illness. HSV causes cold sores. VZV causes chickenpox. HIV causes AIDS. Mononucleosis + lymphoma = EBV.

questions.stem: A disorder causing thickening and hardening of artery walls is termed:
questions.explanation: Arteriosclerosis: General term for arterial wall thickening/hardening. Atherosclerosis is a subtype (plaque buildup). Stenosis is narrowing. Aneurysm is dilation. Thrombosis is clot. Arteriosclerosis is broader term.

questions.stem: A dangerous accumulation of chemicals called ketones in the blood, occurring as a complication of diabetes mellitus, also called ketosis, is:
questions.explanation: Ketoacidosis: Dangerous ketone accumulation in blood, diabetic complication. Hyperglycemia is high blood sugar. Hypoglycemia is low blood sugar. Neuropathy is nerve damage. Retinopathy is eye damage. Ketones = ketoacidosis.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding meningitis?
options: Meningitis is inflammation of the meninges usually caused by infection
Viral forms are milder; bacterial forms are life-threatening
Both A and B are correct
Meningitis always affects brain tissue directly
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Meningitis = meningeal inflammation, usually infectious. Viral = milder. Bacterial = life-threatening. Meningitis affects coverings, NOT brain tissue directly (that's encephalitis).

questions.stem: Rare genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, causing abnormalities of joints, bones, tendons, ligaments, arteries and/or the heart, is:
questions.explanation: Marfan syndrome: Connective tissue disorder affecting multiple systems (skeletal, cardiovascular, ocular). Ehlers-Danlos also affects connective tissue but different features. Down's is chromosomal. Huntington is neurodegenerative.

questions.stem: A hereditary disease in which the muscles weaken and waste away, similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy but starts later in life and advances more slowly, is:
questions.explanation: Becker muscular dystrophy: X-linked, later onset, slower progression than Duchenne. Duchenne = early severe. ALS = motor neuron. Myasthenia = neuromuscular junction. Guillain-Barré = peripheral demyelination. Onset + progression = Becker.

questions.stem: A genetic condition in boys in which nerves degenerate and muscles get progressively weaker is:
questions.explanation: Duchenne muscular dystrophy: X-linked, boys affected, early severe onset, progressive muscle weakness. Becker is milder/later. ALS is motor neuron. SMA is spinal motor neuron. X-linked + early severe = Duchenne.

questions.stem: A disorder in which the body's immune system attacks itself is termed:
questions.explanation: Autoimmune disease: Immune system attacks self-tissues. Immunodeficiency is weakened immunity. Allergy is immune overreaction to external antigen. Hypersensitivity is exaggerated immune response. Immunosuppression is reduced immunity.

questions.stem: A dangerous eating disorder mainly affecting young girls in which the sufferer has an intense fear of looking fat, avoids food and loses weight excessively is:
questions.explanation: Anorexia nervosa: Eating disorder with fear of weight gain, food avoidance, excessive weight loss. Bulimia involves binge-purge cycles. Binge eating is overeating without purging. Obesity is excess weight. Cachexia is wasting from disease.

questions.stem: A method of determining focusing errors of the eye in which light is shined through the pupil and the reflected beam is measured is:
questions.explanation: Retinoscopy: Objective refraction test using light reflection through pupil to determine refractive error. Ophthalmoscopy views retina. Slit lamp examines anterior eye. Tonometry measures pressure. Visual acuity tests vision.

questions.stem: A clear dome-shaped front portion of the eye's outer covering is:
questions.explanation: Cornea: Clear dome-shaped anterior covering, refracts light. Sclera is white outer layer. Iris is colored portion. Lens is behind iris. Conjunctiva is membrane covering. Dome-shaped + clear + anterior = cornea.

questions.stem: The colored portion of the eye is:
questions.explanation: Iris: Colored portion controlling pupil size. Cornea is clear anterior. Sclera is white. Retina is light-sensitive back. Choroid is vascular layer. Colored + pupil control = iris.

questions.stem: A membrane lining the inside of the back of the eye that contains light-sensitive nerve cells that convert focused light into nerve impulses making vision possible is:
questions.explanation: Retina: Light-sensitive inner layer with photoreceptors (rods/cones) converting light to neural signals. Choroid is vascular. Sclera is outer white. Cornea is anterior clear. Iris is colored. Light-sensitive + back of eye = retina.

questions.stem: Final state of liver disease, in which liver function becomes so impaired that other areas of the body are affected, most commonly the brain, is:
questions.explanation: Liver failure: End-stage functional collapse affecting multiple organs (especially brain - hepatic encephalopathy). Cirrhosis is scarring (may not be failure). Hepatitis is inflammation. Hepatoma is cancer. Steatosis is fat accumulation. Functional collapse = failure.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding EEG patterns in different dementias?
options: Alzheimer disease shows diffuse slowing, worsening over time; Parkinson disease EEG is usually normal early
CJD shows periodic sharp wave complexes; vascular dementia may show focal slowing
Both A and B are correct
All dementias show identical EEG patterns
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Alzheimer = diffuse slowing (worsening). Parkinson = normal early. CJD = periodic sharp waves (highly specific). Vascular = focal slowing (stroke-related). EEG patterns help differentiate dementias.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes Parkinson disease from Alzheimer disease?
options: Parkinson disease presents with movement disorder first (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia); Alzheimer disease presents with memory loss first
Parkinson disease always includes dementia at onset
questions.explanation: Parkinson = movement first (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia). Alzheimer = memory first. First symptom is the CRITICAL discriminator. Parkinson dementia occurs late, not at onset.

questions.stem: Which features are MOST characteristic of Huntington disease?
options: Young adult onset (30-50 years), chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and dementia
Older adult onset, memory loss first, no movement disorder
Childhood onset, progressive weakness, no cognitive changes
All ages, identical to Alzheimer disease
questions.explanation: Huntington = young adult (30-50), chorea + psychiatric + dementia. Alzheimer = older, memory first. Duchenne = childhood, weakness. Age + movement + dementia = Huntington.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes vascular dementia from Alzheimer disease?
options: Vascular dementia shows stepwise deterioration after strokes; Alzheimer shows smooth, gradual decline
Vascular dementia always presents with memory loss first
questions.explanation: Vascular dementia = STEPWISE decline (worsens after each stroke). Alzheimer = SMOOTH gradual decline. Progression pattern is the key discriminator. Stepwise = vascular.

questions.stem: Which features are MOST characteristic of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)?
options: Rapidly progressive dementia (weeks to months), myoclonus, and periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG
Slow progression over years, no movement disorder, normal EEG
Stepwise decline, focal neurological deficits, focal slowing on EEG
Gradual memory loss, normal EEG, responds to treatment
questions.explanation: CJD = RAPID progression (weeks-months), myoclonus, periodic sharp waves on EEG (highly specific). Slow = Alzheimer. Stepwise = vascular. Rapid + periodic EEG = CJD.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes encephalitis from meningitis?
options: Encephalitis is inflammation of brain tissue; meningitis is inflammation of meningeal coverings
Meningitis always affects brain tissue directly
questions.explanation: Encephalitis = brain tissue inflammation. Meningitis = meningeal coverings inflammation. Brain vs coverings is the CRITICAL distinction. Location determines symptoms and complications.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome?
options: Guillain-Barré is a peripheral nervous system disorder with ascending weakness
EEG is usually normal because it's a peripheral, not central, disorder
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Guillain-Barré = peripheral demyelination, ascending weakness. EEG normal (peripheral disorder, not cortical). Abnormal EEG would suggest central nervous system involvement.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis)?
options: ALS involves degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons
EEG is usually normal because ALS affects motor neurons, not cortical function
Both A and B are correct
ALS always shows epileptiform discharges on EEG
questions.explanation: Both are correct: ALS = UMN + LMN degeneration, normal EEG (motor neuron disease, not cortical). Epileptiform discharges would indicate cortical dysfunction, not motor neuron disease.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes cerebral palsy from muscular dystrophy?
options: Cerebral palsy is non-progressive (symptoms don't worsen); muscular dystrophy is progressive (symptoms worsen over time)
Cerebral palsy always includes cognitive impairment
questions.explanation: Cerebral palsy = NON-PROGRESSIVE (early brain injury, symptoms stable). Muscular dystrophy = PROGRESSIVE (worsens over time). Progression pattern is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding retinitis pigmentosa?
options: Retinitis pigmentosa affects peripheral vision first, eventually causing tunnel vision
Fundoscopy shows bone-spicule pigmentation; central vision is preserved until late
Both A and B are correct
Retinitis pigmentosa affects central vision first like macular degeneration
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Retinitis pigmentosa = peripheral field loss first, bone-spicule pigmentation, central vision preserved until late. Macular degeneration = central vision first. Field affected is key.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding macular degeneration?
options: Macular degeneration affects central vision first, interfering with fine detail discrimination
Peripheral vision is usually preserved; fundoscopy shows drusen deposits
Both A and B are correct
Macular degeneration affects peripheral vision first
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Macular degeneration = central vision loss first, peripheral preserved, drusen deposits. Retinitis pigmentosa = peripheral first. Central vs peripheral is the key distinction.

questions.stem: Sudden, painless, severe loss of vision in one eye is MOST characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Retinal artery occlusion: Acute ischemia, sudden painless vision loss ('curtain coming down'), ophthalmologic emergency. Conjunctivitis causes irritation. Cataract is gradual. Macular degeneration is progressive. Sudden + painless = occlusion.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes blepharitis from conjunctivitis?
options: Blepharitis affects eyelid margins; conjunctivitis affects the conjunctival membrane
Blepharitis always affects the entire eye
questions.explanation: Blepharitis = eyelid margin inflammation (crusting, irritation). Conjunctivitis = conjunctival membrane inflammation (red eye, discharge). Location (eyelid vs membrane) is the key distinction.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes hepatitis from cirrhosis?
options: Hepatitis refers to liver inflammation; cirrhosis refers to chronic scarring and architectural distortion
Hepatitis always leads to cirrhosis immediately
questions.explanation: Hepatitis = inflammation. Cirrhosis = chronic scarring/fibrosis (end-stage architectural changes). Inflammation vs scarring is the key distinction. Cirrhosis can result from chronic hepatitis but represents different stages.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes Hepatitis A from Hepatitis B?
options: Hepatitis A is transmitted via contaminated food/water (fecal-oral); Hepatitis B is transmitted via blood/sexual contact
Hepatitis B is only transmitted via food
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A = fecal-oral (contaminated food/water), does NOT become chronic. Hepatitis B = blood/sexual, CAN become chronic. Transmission route is the key distinction.

questions.stem: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes due to excess bilirubin in the blood is:
questions.explanation: Jaundice: Yellowing from excess bilirubin (liver dysfunction). Cyanosis = bluish (low oxygen). Pallor = paleness. Erythema = redness. Ecchymosis = bruising. Color + cause = jaundice.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes asthma from COPD?
options: Asthma is reversible airway inflammation; COPD is chronic, irreversible airflow obstruction
questions.explanation: Asthma = reversible inflammation. COPD = chronic irreversible obstruction (emphysema + chronic bronchitis). Reversibility is the CRITICAL discriminator for treatment and prognosis.

questions.stem: A possibly life-threatening condition in which breathing stops completely is:
questions.explanation: Apnea: Complete cessation of breathing (life-threatening). Dyspnea = difficulty breathing. Tachypnea = rapid breathing. Bradypnea = slow breathing. Hyperpnea = deep breathing. Complete stop = apnea.

questions.stem: Increased blood pressure in the arteries supplying blood to the lungs, usually the result of lung disease, can lead to:
options: Pulmonary hypertension and right heart strain (cor pulmonale)
questions.explanation: Pulmonary hypertension: Increased pulmonary artery pressure from lung disease, leads to right heart strain (cor pulmonale). Left heart failure is from systemic hypertension. Right heart = pulmonary hypertension.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes myositis from myopathy?
options: Myositis is muscle inflammation (suffix '-itis'); myopathy is general muscle disease (may or may not be inflammatory)
questions.explanation: Myositis = inflammation (suffix '-itis' indicates inflammation). Myopathy = general muscle disease (broader term, may or may not be inflammatory). '-itis' suffix is the key indicator.

questions.stem: Inflammation of the spinal cord causing headaches, fever, muscle stiffness, pain, weakness and eventually paralysis is:
questions.explanation: Myelitis: Spinal cord inflammation (suffix '-itis'). Myelopathy is broader spinal cord disease. Myositis is muscle inflammation. Motor neuron disease is degeneration. Multiple sclerosis is demyelination.

questions.stem: A disease in which the protective coverings of nerve fibers in the brain are gradually destroyed, causing symptoms from numbness to paralysis, is:
questions.explanation: Multiple sclerosis: CNS demyelination (brain and spinal cord). ALS = motor neuron degeneration. Guillain-Barré = peripheral demyelination. Myasthenia = neuromuscular junction. MS = central nervous system specific.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes vertebra from spine?
options: Vertebra refers to a single bone (one of 33); spine refers to the entire column of bones and cartilage
Spine refers to a single bone
Vertebra refers to the entire column
questions.explanation: Vertebra = single bone (one of 33 bones). Spine = entire column (all vertebrae + cartilage). Single vs entire column is the key distinction for accurate medical terminology.

questions.stem: The slipping of a vertebra in the spine over the one below it is:
questions.explanation: Spondylolisthesis: Vertebra slipping forward. Disk prolapse = herniated disk. Spondylolysis = vertebral defect. Laminectomy and spinal fusion are surgical procedures. Bone slipping vs disk herniation is key.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes laminectomy from spinal fusion?
options: Laminectomy removes bone to relieve pressure (decompressive); spinal fusion joins vertebrae together (stabilizing)
questions.explanation: Laminectomy = bone removal (decompressive surgery). Spinal fusion = bone joining (stabilizing surgery). Different surgical goals: decompression vs stabilization.

questions.stem: A condition in which the spine curves to one side producing an S-shaped curve is:
questions.explanation: Scoliosis: Side-to-side curve (S-shaped). Kyphosis = excessive outward thoracic curve (hump). Lordosis = excessive inward lumbar curve. Direction of curve is the key distinction.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding kyphosis vs lordosis?
options: Kyphosis is excessive outward curvature of the upper spine (hump); lordosis is excessive inward curvature of the lower spine
Kyphosis affects thoracic region; lordosis affects lumbar region
Both A and B are correct
They curve in the same direction
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Kyphosis = outward thoracic (hump). Lordosis = inward lumbar. Direction (outward vs inward) AND location (thoracic vs lumbar) are both key distinctions.

questions.stem: A procedure in which a needle is inserted into the lower region of the spinal canal to take out a sample of spinal fluid or inject a drug is:
questions.explanation: Lumbar puncture = spinal tap (same procedure, diagnostic/therapeutic needle procedure). Laminectomy, fusion, diskectomy, foraminotomy are surgical procedures. Needle vs surgery is key.

questions.stem: A disorder in which the lower part of the spine is weakened by a defect or stress fracture in the pars interarticularis is:
questions.explanation: Spondylolysis: Vertebral defect/stress fracture (pars interarticularis). Spondylolisthesis = vertebra slipping (can result from spondylolysis). Spondylitis = inflammation. Defect vs slipping is distinction.

questions.stem: Pain along the sciatic nerve running down the leg, usually caused by pressure on the nerve due to disk prolapse, is:
questions.explanation: Sciatica: Sciatic nerve-specific pain (leg distribution). Radiculopathy is general nerve root. Neuropathy is peripheral nerve. Neuralgia is nerve pain. Sciatic nerve specific = sciatica.

questions.stem: A tunnel-like passage in the body is termed:
questions.explanation: Canal: General tunnel-like passageway. Duct is usually glandular. Fistula is abnormal connection. Sinus is cavity. Foramen is opening. Canal is the general term for passageways.

questions.stem: The tension in the main arteries created by the beating of the heart, resistance to flow, and elasticity of blood vessels is:
questions.explanation: Blood pressure: Arterial tension from heart contraction, vascular resistance, and vessel elasticity. Cardiac output is volume pumped. Stroke volume is per-beat volume. Heart rate is beats/minute. BP = combination of factors.

questions.stem: A clear membrane covering the white of the eye and inside of the eyelid that produces fluid lubricating the cornea and eyelid. Inflammation of this membrane is also called 'Pinkeye':
questions.explanation: Conjunctiva / Conjunctivitis: Membrane covering eye white and eyelid inner surface, produces lubricating fluid. Inflammation = conjunctivitis (pinkeye). Cornea is clear dome. Sclera is white. Iris is colored. Retina is light-sensitive.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding epilepsy diagnosis?
options: Epilepsy requires recurrent unprovoked seizures from abnormal brain electrical activity
EEG is central to diagnosis and shows epileptiform discharges
Both A and B are correct
A single seizure always indicates epilepsy
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Epilepsy = recurrent unprovoked seizures, EEG is diagnostic cornerstone showing epileptiform discharges. Single seizure does NOT equal epilepsy. Recurrence + EEG = epilepsy diagnosis.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding hydrocephalus?
options: Hydrocephalus is excess cerebrospinal fluid within the brain ventricles
It leads to increased intracranial pressure and can cause enlarged head in infants
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Hydrocephalus = excess CSF in ventricles, causes increased ICP, enlarged head in infants (bulging fontanelles). Does NOT resolve spontaneously - requires treatment. CSF accumulation = hydrocephalus.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Bell's palsy?
options: Bell's palsy is usually one-sided, temporary facial nerve paralysis
It is idiopathic (unknown cause) inflammation of the facial nerve (CN VII)
Both A and B are correct
Bell's palsy always affects both sides
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Bell's palsy = idiopathic unilateral facial nerve (CN VII) paralysis, usually temporary. Bilateral involvement is rare. Unilateral + temporary + idiopathic = Bell's palsy.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)?
options: EBV is associated with Burkitt's lymphoma
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: EBV causes infectious mononucleosis AND is associated with Burkitt's lymphoma. EBV has multiple disease associations. Mononucleosis + lymphoma association = EBV.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding arteriosclerosis?
options: Arteriosclerosis is a general term for arterial wall thickening and hardening
Atherosclerosis is a subtype of arteriosclerosis involving plaque buildup
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Arteriosclerosis = general term (arterial hardening). Atherosclerosis = subtype (plaque buildup). Atherosclerosis is a form of arteriosclerosis. General vs specific is the relationship.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding ketoacidosis?
options: Ketoacidosis is dangerous accumulation of ketones in the blood
It occurs as a complication of diabetes mellitus and is a medical emergency
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Ketoacidosis = dangerous ketone accumulation, diabetic complication, medical emergency. NOT benign - requires immediate treatment. Ketones + diabetes + dangerous = ketoacidosis.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding meningitis?
options: Meningitis is inflammation of the meninges, usually caused by infection
Viral forms are milder; bacterial forms are life-threatening
Both A and B are correct
All forms of meningitis are equally severe
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Meningitis = meningeal inflammation, usually infectious. Viral = milder. Bacterial = life-threatening emergency. Severity differs by cause. Meningeal inflammation + severity varies = meningitis.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Marfan syndrome?
options: Marfan syndrome is a rare genetic disorder affecting connective tissue
It causes abnormalities of joints, bones, tendons, ligaments, arteries, and/or heart
Both A and B are correct
Marfan syndrome only affects one body system
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Marfan = genetic connective tissue disorder affecting MULTIPLE systems (skeletal, cardiovascular, ocular). NOT single-system. Genetic + connective tissue + multisystem = Marfan.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Becker vs Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
options: Both are X-linked genetic conditions affecting boys
Duchenne starts earlier and is more severe; Becker starts later and progresses more slowly
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Both are X-linked, boys affected. Duchenne = early severe. Becker = later milder. Same gene, different severity. X-linked + severity difference = Duchenne vs Becker.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding autoimmune disease?
options: Autoimmune disease occurs when the body's immune system attacks itself
Multiple sclerosis, Guillain-Barré, and myasthenia gravis are examples
Both A and B are correct
Autoimmune disease never affects the nervous system
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Autoimmune = immune system attacks self. MS, Guillain-Barré, myasthenia gravis are autoimmune neurological disorders. Autoimmune DOES affect nervous system. Self-attack + examples = autoimmune.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding anorexia nervosa?
options: Anorexia nervosa is a dangerous eating disorder mainly affecting young girls
It involves intense fear of looking fat, food avoidance, and excessive weight loss
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Anorexia nervosa = dangerous eating disorder, young women, fear of weight gain, food avoidance, excessive weight loss. NOT benign - can be life-threatening. Eating disorder + fear + weight loss = anorexia.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding retinoscopy?
options: Retinoscopy is a method of determining focusing errors of the eye
Light is shined through the pupil and the reflected beam is measured
Both A and B are correct
Retinoscopy is a subjective test requiring patient responses
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Retinoscopy = objective refraction test using light reflection through pupil to determine refractive error. NOT subjective - objective measurement. Objective + light reflection = retinoscopy.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the cornea?
options: The cornea is a clear dome-shaped front portion of the eye's outer covering
It refracts light and is the first structure light passes through
Both A and B are correct
The cornea is the colored portion of the eye
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Cornea = clear dome-shaped anterior covering, refracts light, first structure. Iris is colored portion. Clear + dome + anterior + refracts = cornea.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the iris?
options: The iris is the colored portion of the eye
It controls pupil size and regulates light entering the eye
Both A and B are correct
The iris is the clear dome-shaped covering
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Iris = colored portion, controls pupil size, regulates light. Cornea is clear dome. Colored + pupil control + light regulation = iris.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the retina?
options: The retina contains light-sensitive nerve cells (rods and cones) that convert light into nerve impulses
It lines the inside of the back of the eye and makes vision possible
Both A and B are correct
The retina is the clear dome-shaped covering
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Retina = light-sensitive inner layer with photoreceptors (rods/cones), converts light to neural signals, makes vision possible. Cornea is clear dome. Light-sensitive + back of eye + vision = retina.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding hepatoma?
options: Hepatoma is a cancerous (malignant) tumor of the liver
It is also called hepatocellular carcinoma
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Hepatoma = malignant liver tumor (hepatocellular carcinoma). NOT benign - it's cancer. Malignant + liver + tumor = hepatoma.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Hepatitis D?
options: Hepatitis D only causes symptoms when the individual is already infected with Hepatitis B
Hepatitis D is a defective virus that requires Hepatitis B for replication
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Hepatitis D = defective virus requiring Hepatitis B co-infection, cannot exist independently. Requires Hep B = key characteristic. Defective + requires Hep B = Hepatitis D.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding croup?
options: Croup is a usually mild and temporary condition common in children under age 4
It involves inflamed and narrowed airways resulting in wheezing and coughing
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Croup = pediatric (<4 years), mild temporary, airway inflammation, wheezing, barking cough. NOT adult condition. Pediatric + airway + wheezing = croup.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding asphyxia?
options: Asphyxia is the medical term for suffocation
It can be caused by choking, lack of oxygen in air, or chemicals like carbon monoxide
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Asphyxia = suffocation from multiple causes (choking, low oxygen, CO poisoning). NOT single cause. Suffocation + multiple causes = asphyxia.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the pharynx?
options: The pharynx is the throat, connecting the back of the mouth and nose to the esophagus and windpipe
Inflammation of the pharynx (pharyngitis) causes sore throat, fever, earache, and swollen glands
Both A and B are correct
The pharynx is only part of the digestive system
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Pharynx = throat connecting mouth/nose to esophagus/windpipe (both digestive and respiratory). Pharyngitis = inflammation with characteristic symptoms. Throat + dual function = pharynx.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding motor nerves?
options: Motor nerves carry messages to muscles that cause muscle movement
They are efferent nerves (carrying signals away from CNS to muscles)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Motor nerves = efferent (CNS to muscles), cause movement. Sensory nerves = afferent (sensation to CNS). Direction of signal is key. Efferent + muscle movement = motor nerve.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding myelofibrosis?
options: Myelofibrosis is buildup of fibrous connective tissue in the bone marrow
It affects the production of blood components (hematopoiesis)
Both A and B are correct
Myelofibrosis only affects the spinal cord
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Myelofibrosis = fibrous replacement of bone marrow, affects hematopoiesis. NOT spinal cord - it's bone marrow. Bone marrow + fibrosis + hematopoiesis = myelofibrosis.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding multiple myeloma?
options: Multiple myeloma is a cancer affecting cells in the bone marrow
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Multiple myeloma = malignant plasma cell cancer in bone marrow. NOT benign - it's cancer. Bone marrow + plasma cells + malignant = multiple myeloma.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding spina bifida?
options: Spina bifida is a birth defect in which a section of the baby's spine fails to develop completely
Spina bifida occulta is the least dangerous form with no protrusion
Both A and B are correct
All forms of spina bifida are equally severe
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Spina bifida = birth defect, incomplete spine development. Occulta = least severe (no protrusion). Myelomeningocele = most severe (cord + meninges protrusion). Severity varies by type.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding spondylitis?
options: Spondylitis is inflammation of the joints between the bones of the spine
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Spondylitis = spinal joint inflammation (suffix '-itis' = inflammation). Spondylolisthesis = vertebra slipping. '-itis' suffix is key indicator of inflammation.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding the lumbar spine?
options: The lumbar spine is the lower part of the spine between the lowest pair of ribs and the pelvis
It is made up of five vertebrae
Both A and B are correct
The lumbar spine has seven vertebrae like the cervical spine
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Lumbar spine = lower back (ribs to pelvis), five vertebrae. Cervical = 7 vertebrae. Thoracic = 12 vertebrae. Sacral = 5 fused. Number varies by region.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding lordosis?
options: Lordosis is the inward curvature of the spine at the lower back
It is normal to a certain degree but abnormal when excessive (due to overweight, muscle problems, etc.)
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Lordosis = inward lumbar curve, normal in degree but abnormal when excessive. Some curvature is normal. Excessive = abnormal. Inward + lumbar + normal vs excessive = lordosis.

questions.stem: A 65-year-old patient presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, and rigidity. EEG is normal. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with Parkinson disease, where movement disorder precedes cognitive changes and EEG is usually normal early
This is Alzheimer disease because memory loss always comes first
EEG abnormality is required for Parkinson diagnosis
This pattern is inconsistent with any known neurological disorder
questions.explanation: Parkinson disease: Movement disorder (tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity) FIRST, normal EEG early, cognition preserved initially. Alzheimer = memory first. Normal EEG is expected in early Parkinson.

questions.stem: A 72-year-old patient presents with progressive memory loss as the first symptom, followed by language difficulties. EEG shows diffuse slowing. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with Alzheimer disease, where memory loss is the first symptom and EEG shows diffuse slowing
This is Parkinson disease because movement always comes first
Normal EEG would be expected in Alzheimer disease
Memory loss never occurs first in any dementia
questions.explanation: Alzheimer disease: Memory loss FIRST, then language/visuospatial, diffuse slowing on EEG. Parkinson = movement first. EEG slowing is characteristic of Alzheimer. First symptom is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: A 38-year-old patient presents with involuntary movements (chorea), depression, and progressive dementia. Family history is positive. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with Huntington disease: young adult, chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and dementia
This is Alzheimer disease because all dementias present identically
Huntington disease only affects older adults
questions.explanation: Huntington disease: Young adult (30-50), chorea + psychiatric + dementia, autosomal dominant (family history). Alzheimer = older, memory first. Age + movement + dementia + family history = Huntington.

questions.stem: A patient's cognitive function declines suddenly after a stroke, then plateaus. Six months later, another stroke causes another sudden decline. EEG shows focal slowing. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This stepwise pattern is characteristic of vascular dementia, where cognitive decline occurs after each stroke
This smooth gradual decline is characteristic of Alzheimer disease
Stepwise decline never occurs in dementia
All dementias show identical progression patterns
questions.explanation: Vascular dementia: STEPWISE decline (worsens after each stroke), then plateaus. Focal slowing on EEG (stroke-related). Alzheimer = smooth gradual decline. Stepwise pattern is the key discriminator.

questions.stem: A patient develops rapidly progressive dementia over 3 months, with myoclonus. EEG shows periodic sharp wave complexes. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: rapid progression (weeks-months), myoclonus, and periodic sharp waves on EEG
This slow progression over years is characteristic of Alzheimer disease
Periodic EEG patterns never occur in dementia
All dementias progress at the same rate
questions.explanation: CJD: RAPID progression (weeks-months), myoclonus, periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG (highly specific). Alzheimer = slow (years). Speed + periodic EEG + myoclonus = CJD.

questions.stem: A patient presents with fever, headache, and hallucinations. EEG shows diffuse slowing with epileptiform discharges. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with encephalitis: brain tissue inflammation often shows diffuse slowing ± epileptiform on EEG
This is meningitis, which always affects brain tissue directly
Encephalitis and meningitis show identical EEG patterns
EEG is always normal in brain infections
questions.explanation: Encephalitis: Brain tissue inflammation, diffuse slowing ± epileptiform on EEG. Meningitis = meningeal inflammation (may show diffuse slowing but less epileptiform). Brain vs coverings + EEG pattern = encephalitis.

questions.stem: A patient develops rapidly ascending weakness following a respiratory infection. Reflexes are absent. EEG is normal. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome: peripheral nervous system disorder, ascending weakness, normal EEG
This is ALS because EEG is always abnormal in motor disorders
Peripheral disorders always show abnormal EEG
Ascending weakness never occurs after infections
questions.explanation: Guillain-Barré: Peripheral demyelination, post-infectious, ascending weakness, absent reflexes, NORMAL EEG (peripheral, not central). ALS = motor neuron, also normal EEG. Peripheral = normal EEG.

questions.stem: A patient reports progressive loss of peripheral vision and night blindness. Fundoscopy shows bone-spicule pigmentation. Central vision is preserved. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with retinitis pigmentosa: peripheral field loss first, night blindness, bone-spicule pigmentation, central vision preserved until late
This is macular degeneration because central vision is always affected first
Peripheral vision loss never occurs in retinal disorders
All retinal disorders affect vision identically
questions.explanation: Retinitis pigmentosa: Peripheral field loss FIRST, night blindness (nyctalopia), bone-spicule pigmentation, central vision preserved until late. Macular degeneration = central first. Field affected is key.

questions.stem: A patient reports difficulty reading and recognizing faces, but peripheral vision is intact. Fundoscopy shows drusen deposits. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with macular degeneration: central vision loss first, fine detail discrimination affected, drusen deposits, peripheral vision preserved
This is retinitis pigmentosa because peripheral vision is always affected first
Central vision loss never occurs in retinal disorders
All retinal disorders affect the same area of vision
questions.explanation: Macular degeneration: Central vision loss FIRST (reading, faces), drusen deposits, peripheral vision preserved. Retinitis pigmentosa = peripheral first. Central vs peripheral is the key distinction.

questions.stem: A patient reports sudden, painless, severe vision loss in one eye, described as 'a curtain coming down.' Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with retinal artery occlusion: acute ischemia, sudden painless vision loss, ophthalmologic emergency
This gradual vision loss is characteristic of cataracts
Sudden vision loss never occurs in retinal disorders
questions.explanation: Retinal artery occlusion: Acute ischemia, sudden painless vision loss ('curtain'), ophthalmologic emergency. Cataracts = gradual. Conjunctivitis = irritation. Sudden + painless = occlusion (emergency).

questions.stem: A patient with chronic hepatitis B develops gradual liver function decline over years, with imaging showing architectural distortion and nodular changes. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This progression from hepatitis (inflammation) to cirrhosis (scarring/architectural distortion) is characteristic of chronic liver disease
Hepatitis and cirrhosis are the same condition
Chronic hepatitis never leads to cirrhosis
Liver function always improves with time
questions.explanation: Chronic hepatitis can progress to cirrhosis: inflammation → chronic scarring → architectural distortion. Hepatitis = inflammation. Cirrhosis = end-stage scarring. Progression is possible but they are distinct stages.

questions.stem: A patient with liver disease develops yellowing of skin and eyes, followed by confusion and altered mental status. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This progression from jaundice (bilirubin excess) to hepatic encephalopathy (brain dysfunction) indicates liver failure affecting multiple organs
Liver disease never affects the brain
questions.explanation: Liver failure: Jaundice (bilirubin excess) → hepatic encephalopathy (brain dysfunction from liver failure). Liver failure affects multiple organs, especially brain. Multi-organ involvement = liver failure.

questions.stem: A patient with airway obstruction shows improvement with bronchodilator treatment. Spirometry shows reversible airflow limitation. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This reversible obstruction is characteristic of asthma, where bronchodilators improve airflow
This is COPD because all airway obstruction is irreversible
Reversibility never occurs in airway disease
All airway disorders respond identically to treatment
questions.explanation: Asthma: Reversible airway obstruction, bronchodilators improve airflow. COPD = chronic irreversible obstruction. Reversibility is the CRITICAL discriminator. Reversible = asthma.

questions.stem: A patient reports episodes where breathing stops during sleep, sometimes for 30 seconds or longer. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with sleep apnea: a life-threatening condition where breathing stops, which can occur during sleep
questions.explanation: Sleep apnea: Breathing cessation during sleep, can be life-threatening, episodes of 30+ seconds. Apnea = complete cessation (life-threatening). Can occur awake or asleep. Complete stop = apnea.

questions.stem: A patient presents with muscle pain and weakness. Laboratory tests show elevated inflammatory markers. Muscle biopsy shows inflammation. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with myositis: muscle inflammation causing pain and weakness, indicated by elevated inflammatory markers and biopsy findings
This is myopathy because all muscle diseases involve inflammation
questions.explanation: Myositis: Muscle inflammation, pain + weakness, elevated inflammatory markers, biopsy shows inflammation. Myopathy = general muscle disease (may or may not be inflammatory). Inflammation + muscle = myositis.

questions.stem: A patient presents with episodes of numbness, vision problems, and weakness that improve and then recur. MRI shows demyelinating lesions in the brain and spinal cord. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This relapsing-remitting pattern with CNS demyelination is characteristic of multiple sclerosis
This is Guillain-Barré because all demyelination is peripheral
questions.explanation: Multiple sclerosis: CNS demyelination (brain + spinal cord), relapsing-remitting course, multiple symptoms. Guillain-Barré = peripheral demyelination. CNS vs peripheral is key. CNS + demyelination = MS.

questions.stem: A patient with a history of lower back pain and a vertebral defect (spondylolysis) develops worsening symptoms. Imaging shows a vertebra has slipped forward over the one below. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This progression from spondylolysis (vertebral defect) to spondylolisthesis (vertebra slipping) can occur
questions.explanation: Spondylolisthesis can result from spondylolysis: Vertebral defect (spondylolysis) can progress to vertebra slipping (spondylolisthesis). Defect → slipping is possible progression. Related but distinct conditions.

questions.stem: A patient's spine shows a curve to one side in the thoracic region, with a compensating curve in the opposite direction in the lumbar region, producing an S-shape. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This S-shaped curve with compensation is characteristic of scoliosis
This is kyphosis because all spinal curves are outward
questions.explanation: Scoliosis: Side-to-side curve (S-shaped), often with compensating curves. Kyphosis = outward thoracic curve. Lordosis = inward lumbar curve. Direction (side-to-side) is key. S-shape = scoliosis.

questions.stem: A patient requires analysis of cerebrospinal fluid and injection of medication into the spinal canal. A needle is inserted into the lower lumbar region. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is a lumbar puncture (spinal tap): a procedure to obtain CSF sample or inject medication into the spinal canal
This is a surgical procedure requiring bone removal
Lumbar puncture only obtains samples, never injects medication
questions.explanation: Lumbar puncture = spinal tap: Diagnostic (CSF analysis) and therapeutic (medication injection) procedure via needle in lower lumbar region. NOT surgery. Needle procedure vs surgery is key.

questions.stem: A patient reports hearing voices when no one is present and seeing objects that others cannot see. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with hallucinations: false sensory perceptions in the absence of external stimuli
This is a delusion because all false perceptions are beliefs
Hallucinations only occur in one sensory modality
questions.explanation: Hallucination: False sensory perception (hearing, seeing) without external stimulus. Delusion = false belief. Illusion = misinterpretation of real stimulus. Sensory perception vs belief is key.

questions.stem: A patient develops sudden onset of symptoms that resolve within 2 weeks. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This sudden onset and short duration is characteristic of an acute condition
This gradual onset over months is characteristic of a chronic condition
questions.explanation: Acute: Sudden onset + short duration. Chronic = persistent over long period. Onset (sudden vs gradual) + duration (short vs long) are key distinctions. Sudden + short = acute.

questions.stem: A patient with respiratory distress shows bluish discoloration of the lips and fingertips. Pulse oximetry shows low oxygen saturation. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This bluish discoloration from low oxygen is consistent with cyanosis
This yellowing is consistent with jaundice
All skin color changes are identical
questions.explanation: Cyanosis: Bluish discoloration from low oxygen saturation (hypoxia). Jaundice = yellowing (bilirubin). Pallor = paleness. Color + cause is key. Bluish + low oxygen = cyanosis.

questions.stem: A patient has hearing loss affecting both ears. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This affects both sides, which is described as bilateral
This affects one side, which is described as unilateral
Bilateral means affecting only one side
All conditions affect the same number of sides
questions.explanation: Bilateral: Affecting both sides or paired organs. Unilateral = one side. Ipsilateral = same side. Contralateral = opposite side. Number of sides affected is key. Both sides = bilateral.

questions.stem: A patient with prolonged immobility shows muscle shrinkage and weakness. Imaging confirms decreased muscle mass. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This tissue shrinkage is consistent with atrophy: the shrinkage or near disappearance of a tissue or organ
This is hypertrophy because all tissue changes involve growth
questions.explanation: Atrophy: Tissue/organ shrinkage (decreased size/mass). Hypertrophy = increased size. Hyperplasia = increased cell number. Direction of change is key. Shrinkage = atrophy.

questions.stem: A patient has a localized collection of pus in soft tissue, surrounded by inflamed tissue. Culture shows bacterial infection. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This localized pus collection is consistent with an abscess: accumulation of pus in body tissue, usually from bacterial infection
This is cellulitis because all infections are diffuse
questions.explanation: Abscess: Localized pus collection in tissue, usually bacterial, surrounded by inflammation. Cellulitis = diffuse inflammation. Empyema = pus in body cavity. Localized vs diffuse is key. Localized pus = abscess.

questions.stem: A flexible hollow tube is inserted into a blood vessel to administer medication and monitor pressure. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is a catheter: a hollow flexible tube inserted into the body to put in or take out fluid or manipulate vessels
This is a stent because all tubes keep vessels open
questions.explanation: Catheter: Flexible hollow tube for fluid access/vessel manipulation. Stent = keeps vessel open. Cannula = rigid needle. Shunt = diverts flow. Flexibility + access = catheter.

questions.stem: A patient's blood test shows elevated levels of a waste product from muscle metabolism. This substance is filtered by the kidneys and excreted in urine. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is creatinine: a waste product filtered from blood by kidneys and expelled in urine
This is bilirubin because all waste products are from the liver
questions.explanation: Creatinine: Muscle metabolism waste, filtered by kidneys, excreted in urine. Bilirubin = liver waste. Urea = also kidney waste. Source (muscle) is key. Muscle waste + kidney filtered = creatinine.

questions.stem: A cancer is found confined to its original location with no evidence of spread to other tissues. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is described as 'in situ': meaning 'in place,' used for cancer that has not spread
This is metastatic because all cancers spread immediately
All cancers are identical in staging
questions.explanation: In situ: Cancer confined to original location, has not spread (invaded or metastasized). Metastatic = spread. Invasive = penetrated tissue. Localization is key. Localized + no spread = in situ.

questions.stem: A tissue that stores energy, insulates the body, and provides cushioning is examined. Histology shows fat cells. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is adipose tissue: fatty tissue that stores energy, insulates, and cushions the body
This is muscle tissue because all tissues store energy
questions.explanation: Adipose tissue: Fat tissue with energy storage, insulation, cushioning functions. Muscle = contractile. Connective = structural. Epithelial = lining. Function is key. Fat + storage/insulation = adipose.

questions.stem: A patient reports persistent difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep, leading to daytime fatigue. Which statement is MOST likely true?
options: This is consistent with insomnia: difficulty falling and remaining asleep
This is narcolepsy because all sleep disorders involve excessive sleep
questions.explanation: Insomnia: Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. Narcolepsy = excessive daytime sleepiness. Sleep apnea = breathing cessation. Hypersomnia = excessive sleep. Type of sleep problem is key. Difficulty sleeping = insomnia.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding tumor vs cancer vs neoplasm?
options: Tumor and neoplasm are terms for an abnormal mass that can be benign or malignant
Cancer refers specifically to malignant tumors that can spread and destroy tissue
Both A and B are correct
Tumor, cancer, and neoplasm all mean exactly the same thing
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Tumor/neoplasm = abnormal mass (benign OR malignant). Cancer = malignant only (spreads, destroys). Tumor is broader term. Benign vs malignant is the key distinction.

questions.stem: A tumor that is not cancerous, meaning it does not spread through the body but may grow and become dangerous, is termed:
questions.explanation: Benign tumor: Non-cancerous, does NOT spread (metastasize), but may grow and cause problems by compression. Malignant = spreads. Metastasis = spread process. Benign = no spread.

questions.stem: The spreading of a cancerous tumor to another part of the body through lymph, blood, or across a cavity is termed:
questions.explanation: Metastasis: Spread of cancer to distant sites via lymph, blood, or direct extension. Neoplasm = any tumor. Benign = no spread. Primary = original location. In situ = localized. Spread = metastasis.

questions.stem: A group of bone marrow cancers in which white blood cells divide uncontrollably, affecting the production of normal white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets, is termed:
questions.explanation: Leukemia: Bone marrow cancer, uncontrolled white blood cell division, affects all blood cell production. Lymphoma = lymph tissue. Sarcoma = connective tissue. Carcinoma = epithelium. Bone marrow + blood cells = leukemia.

questions.stem: A group of cancers of the lymph nodes and spleen that spread to other parts of the body, causing lymph node enlargement and symptoms like fever, weight loss, and loss of appetite, is termed:
questions.explanation: Lymphoma: Cancer of lymphoid tissue (lymph nodes, spleen), spreads to other parts, causes lymph node enlargement, B symptoms (fever, weight loss). Hodgkin vs Non-Hodgkin are subtypes. Lymph tissue = lymphoma.

questions.stem: A cancer in connective tissue, fibrous tissue, or blood vessels is termed:
questions.explanation: Sarcoma: Cancer of connective tissue, fibrous tissue, or blood vessels. Carcinoma = epithelium. Leukemia = bone marrow. Lymphoma = lymph tissue. Glioma = glial cells. Connective tissue = sarcoma.

questions.stem: A cancer that grows on the surface or lining of an organ is termed:
questions.explanation: Carcinoma: Cancer of epithelium (surface/lining of organs). Sarcoma = connective tissue. Leukemia = bone marrow. Lymphoma = lymph tissue. Glioma = glial cells. Epithelium/lining = carcinoma.

questions.stem: A brain tumor arising from cells that support nerve cells (glial cells), often fast-growing and cancerous, is termed:
questions.explanation: Glioma/Glioblastoma: Brain tumor from glial (supporting) cells, fast-growing, malignant. Medulloblastoma = cerebellum (children). Neuroblastoma = adrenal/sympathetic. Meningioma = meninges. Pituitary adenoma = pituitary. Glial cells = glioma.

questions.stem: A type of cancerous tumor occurring in the section of the brain that controls posture and balance (cerebellum), found mainly in children, is termed:
questions.explanation: Medulloblastoma: Cerebellum tumor (posture/balance), mainly children, malignant. Glioblastoma = cerebrum (adults). Neuroblastoma = adrenal. Meningioma = meninges. Pituitary adenoma = pituitary. Cerebellum + children = medulloblastoma.

questions.stem: A cancerous childhood tumor located in the adrenal glands or the sympathetic nervous system is termed:
questions.explanation: Neuroblastoma: Childhood cancer, adrenal glands or sympathetic nervous system. Medulloblastoma = cerebellum. Retinoblastoma = retina. Glioblastoma = cerebrum. Lymphoma = lymph tissue. Adrenal/sympathetic + children = neuroblastoma.

questions.stem: A hereditary cancerous tumor of the retina affecting infants and children is termed:
questions.explanation: Retinoblastoma: Hereditary retinal cancer, infants/children. Neuroblastoma = adrenal. Medulloblastoma = cerebellum. Glioblastoma = cerebrum. Melanoma = skin. Retina + hereditary + children = retinoblastoma.

questions.stem: The most serious type of skin cancer, in which a mole changes shape, darkens, becomes painful and/or bleeds easily, composed of cells called melanocytes, is termed:
questions.explanation: Malignant Melanoma: Most serious skin cancer, from melanocytes, mole changes, can metastasize. Basal cell = less aggressive. Squamous cell = moderate. Melanocytes = melanoma.

questions.stem: A type of cancer caused by exposure to large amounts of sunlight, commonly found on the neck, face, and arms, is:
questions.explanation: Basal Cell Carcinoma: Sun exposure-related skin cancer, common on sun-exposed areas (face, neck, arms), less aggressive than melanoma. Melanoma = more serious. Sun exposure + common locations = basal cell.

questions.stem: A cancerous tumor occurring in the lining of the lungs and chest cavity, often associated with exposure to asbestos dust, is termed:
questions.explanation: Mesothelioma: Cancer of lung/chest cavity lining (pleura), asbestos exposure association. Lung carcinoma = lung tissue itself. Sarcoma = connective tissue. Asbestos + lining = mesothelioma.

questions.stem: A cancer of lymph tissue that most frequently occurs in the abdomen, ovaries, and bones of the face, associated with malaria and Epstein-Barr virus, is termed:
questions.explanation: Burkitt's Lymphoma: Lymph tissue cancer, abdomen/ovaries/facial bones, associated with malaria and EBV. Hodgkin = different subtype. Non-Hodgkin = broader category. Malaria + EBV + locations = Burkitt's.

questions.stem: A non-cancerous tumor of the pituitary gland is termed:
questions.explanation: Pituitary adenoma: Benign pituitary tumor. Pituitary carcinoma = malignant (rare). Glioblastoma = cerebrum. Meningioma = meninges. Craniopharyngioma = different pituitary region. Pituitary + benign = adenoma.

questions.stem: A condition in which connective tissue tumors occur on nerves in the skin, also called Von Recklinghausen's disease, is termed:
questions.explanation: Neurofibromatosis: Connective tissue tumors on skin nerves, Von Recklinghausen's disease. Neuroblastoma = malignant childhood tumor. Neurofibroma = single tumor (part of neurofibromatosis). Nerve tumors + skin = neurofibromatosis.

questions.stem: A term describing a condition from which cancer is likely to develop is:
questions.explanation: Pre-cancerous: Condition with increased cancer risk (e.g., dysplasia, certain polyps). Benign = non-cancerous. Malignant = cancerous. Metastatic = spread. In situ = localized cancer. Increased risk = pre-cancerous.

questions.stem: A disorder that causes excessive sleepiness during the day and frequent, uncontrollable episodes of falling asleep, with onset of sleep directly into REM sleep, is termed:
questions.explanation: Narcolepsy: Excessive daytime sleepiness, uncontrollable sleep attacks, direct entry into REM sleep. Insomnia = difficulty sleeping. Sleep apnea = breathing cessation. Hypersomnia = excessive sleep. REM intrusion = narcolepsy.

questions.stem: A disorder caused partly or completely by a defect in the patient's genes which carry hereditary information is termed:
questions.explanation: Genetic Disorder: Caused by gene defects carrying hereditary information. Degenerative = progressive tissue loss. Prion = protein misfolding. Infectious = pathogen-caused. Autoimmune = self-attack. Genes = genetic.

questions.stem: A fatal birth defect in which the brain and spinal cord have failed to develop, resulting in the absence of a portion of the skull and brain, is termed:
questions.explanation: Anencephaly: Fatal birth defect, absence of skull and brain (neural tube defect). Microcephaly = small head. Hydrocephalus = excess CSF. Encephalocele = brain protrusion. Spina bifida = spine defect. No brain = anencephaly.

questions.stem: A birth defect in which the patient has a very small head is termed:
questions.explanation: Microcephaly: Abnormally small head (birth defect). Anencephaly = absence of brain. Hydrocephalus = enlarged head. Macrocephaly = large head. Encephalocele = brain protrusion. Small head = microcephaly.

questions.stem: General term for problems in the development of the spinal cord and brain in an embryo, such as failure of the spine to enclose the spinal cord (spina bifida) and failure of the brain to develop (anencephaly), is:
questions.explanation: Neural tube defects: Embryologic defects of brain/spinal cord development (spina bifida, anencephaly). Chromosomal = chromosome abnormalities. Teratogenic = drug/toxin-caused. Genetic = gene mutations. Congenital = broader term. Neural tube = specific.

questions.stem: A rare disorder mainly affecting those under age 15, characterized by brain and liver damage following a viral infection such as chickenpox or flu, and may be linked to taking aspirin, is termed:
questions.explanation: Reye's Syndrome: Childhood disorder (<15 years), brain + liver damage, post-viral (chickenpox/flu), aspirin association. Guillain-Barré = peripheral nerve. Encephalitis = brain inflammation. Hepatitis = liver inflammation. Child + aspirin + virus = Reye's.

questions.stem: A severe headache usually accompanied by vision problems and/or nausea and vomiting, typically recurring, is termed:
questions.explanation: Migraine: Recurrent severe headache, often with visual aura, nausea, vomiting. Tension = pressure. Cluster = unilateral severe. Sinus = sinus-related. Trigeminal neuralgia = facial pain. Headache + aura + nausea = migraine.

questions.stem: A temporary paralysis of the arm after extended pressure on a nerve in the armpit is termed:
questions.explanation: Saturday night palsy: Radial nerve compression in armpit, temporary arm paralysis. Bell's = facial nerve. Third nerve = oculomotor. Bulbar = brainstem. Cerebral = early brain injury. Armpit compression = Saturday night palsy.

questions.stem: A disease of the nerve roots caused by disk prolapse, arthritis, or other problems is termed:
questions.explanation: Radiculopathy: Nerve root disease, often from disk prolapse or arthritis. Myelopathy = spinal cord. Peripheral neuropathy = peripheral nerves. Myelitis = cord inflammation. Neuritis = nerve inflammation. Nerve roots = radiculopathy.

questions.stem: A nerve running down the arm to the hand that controls muscle movement in the forearm and hand, also conveying sensation to part of the hand, thumb, and index finger, is:
questions.explanation: Median Nerve: Arm to hand, motor (forearm/hand), sensory (thumb, index finger, part of hand). Ulnar = pinky/ring finger. Radial = back of hand. Sciatic = leg. Peroneal = lower leg. Thumb + index = median.

questions.stem: A protrusion of the meninges through an opening in the skull or spinal cord due to a genetic defect is termed:
questions.explanation: Meningocele: Meninges protrusion through skull/spine defect (genetic). Myelomeningocele = meninges + spinal cord. Encephalocele = brain. Myelocele = cord only. Spina bifida occulta = no protrusion. Meninges only = meningocele.

questions.stem: Surgical removal of just the protruding part of a prolapsed disk is termed:
questions.explanation: Microdiskectomy: Removal of only the protruding portion of herniated disk (minimally invasive). Laminectomy = bone removal. Spinal fusion = bone joining. ACDF = cervical procedure. Full diskectomy = entire disk. 'Micro' = partial removal.

questions.stem: A term used to describe a disease, disorder, or medical condition that is the direct result of medical treatment is:
questions.explanation: Iatrogenic: Disease/condition caused by medical treatment. Idiopathic = unknown cause. Ileum = small intestine. Ileostomy = surgical opening. Ichthyosis = skin condition. Treatment-caused = iatrogenic.

questions.stem: A term used to describe something that occurs with no known cause is:
questions.explanation: Idiopathic: Unknown cause. Iatrogenic = treatment-caused. Ileum = small intestine. Ileostomy = surgical opening. Immunostimulant = immune system booster. Unknown cause = idiopathic.

questions.stem: An abnormal swelling of the wall of an artery caused by weakening in the vessel wall is termed:
questions.explanation: Aneurysm: Abnormal arterial wall swelling from weakness (ballooning). Stenosis = narrowing. Angioplasty = procedure. Infarction = tissue death. Embolism = blockage. Swelling + weakness = aneurysm.

questions.stem: A condition in which the fingers and toes become pale when exposed to cold or emotional stress, due to sudden narrowing of the arteries that supply them with blood, is termed:
questions.explanation: Raynaud's Disease: Vasospastic disorder, fingers/toes turn pale (white→blue→red) from cold/emotional stress, artery narrowing. Pericarditis = heart sac inflammation. Narcolepsy = sleep disorder. Radiculopathy = nerve root. Nephritis = kidney. Cold + fingers white = Raynaud's.

questions.stem: Determination of the amount of oxygen in the blood by measuring the amount of light transmitted through an area of skin is termed:
questions.explanation: Oximetry: Measuring blood oxygen using light through skin (pulse oximeter). Otitis media = middle ear infection. Osteophyte = bone spur. Osteoporosis = bone loss. Ozone = gas. Oxygen + light = oximetry.

questions.stem: Infection by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) which causes weakening of the immune system is termed:
questions.explanation: AIDS: HIV infection causing immune system weakening (acquired immunodeficiency). Autoimmune = self-attack. Burkitt's = lymphoma. ALS = motor neuron. Anorexia = eating disorder. HIV + immune failure = AIDS.

questions.stem: Nerves involved in smell are:
questions.explanation: Olfactory: Cranial nerve I, sense of smell. Abducens = CN VI (eye movement). Median = peripheral nerve (arm). Trochlear = CN IV (eye movement). Trigeminal = CN V (facial sensation). Smell = olfactory (CN I).

questions.stem: The feeling that one or one's surroundings are spinning is termed:
questions.explanation: Vertigo: Sensation of spinning (self or surroundings), vestibular system symptom. Hemothorax = blood in chest. Eclampsia = pregnancy complication. Hydrocephalus = excess CSF. Dizziness = broader term. Spinning = vertigo.

questions.stem: A life-threatening allergic reaction resulting in difficulty breathing and low blood pressure is termed:
questions.explanation: Anaphylactic shock: Life-threatening allergic reaction, breathing difficulty, hypotension. Fibrillation = irregular heart rhythm. Anencephaly = birth defect. Dystrophy = tissue degeneration. Aneurysm = artery swelling. Allergy + hypotension = anaphylaxis.

questions.stem: Informed consent is an agreement to undergo a medical procedure after the technique, its risks, and its possible complications have been explained. This statement is:
questions.explanation: True: Informed consent requires explanation of procedure, risks, and complications before agreement. This applies to all medical procedures, not just surgery. Procedure + risks explained = informed consent.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding tumor classification by cell of origin?
options: Carcinoma arises from epithelium (surface/lining of organs); sarcoma arises from connective tissue
Leukemia arises from bone marrow; lymphoma arises from lymph tissue
Both A and B are correct
All tumors arise from the same cell type
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Carcinoma = epithelium. Sarcoma = connective tissue. Leukemia = bone marrow. Lymphoma = lymph tissue. Cell of origin determines tumor type. This classification system is critical for understanding tumors.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding brain tumors?
options: Medulloblastoma occurs in cerebellum (children); glioblastoma occurs in cerebrum (adults)
Neuroblastoma occurs in adrenal/sympathetic (children); pituitary adenoma occurs in pituitary (any age)
Both A and B are correct
All brain tumors occur in the same location
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Medulloblastoma = cerebellum + children. Glioblastoma = cerebrum + adults. Neuroblastoma = adrenal + children. Pituitary adenoma = pituitary + any age. Location + age are key discriminators.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding benign vs malignant tumors?
options: Benign tumors do not spread (metastasize); malignant tumors can spread and destroy tissue
Benign tumors may still grow and become dangerous by compression; malignant tumors spread and invade
Both A and B are correct
Benign and malignant tumors behave identically
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Benign = no spread, but may compress. Malignant = spreads, invades, destroys. Spread capability is the key distinction. No spread = benign. Spreads = malignant.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Burkitt's lymphoma?
options: Burkitt's lymphoma is associated with malaria and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
It frequently occurs in abdomen, ovaries, and bones of the face
Both A and B are correct
Burkitt's lymphoma has no known associations
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Burkitt's lymphoma = malaria + EBV association, abdomen/ovaries/facial bones. These associations are HIGH-YIELD exam material. Malaria + EBV + locations = Burkitt's.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding mesothelioma?
options: Mesothelioma is cancer of the lining of the lungs and chest cavity
It is often associated with exposure to asbestos dust
Both A and B are correct
Mesothelioma has no known risk factors
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Mesothelioma = lung/chest cavity lining cancer, asbestos exposure association. This is a HIGH-YIELD occupational exposure association. Asbestos + lining = mesothelioma.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding retinoblastoma?
options: Retinoblastoma is a hereditary cancerous tumor of the retina
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Retinoblastoma = hereditary retinal cancer, infants/children. NOT adult condition. Hereditary + retina + children = retinoblastoma.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding neurofibromatosis?
options: Neurofibromatosis is a condition with connective tissue tumors on nerves in the skin
It is also called Von Recklinghausen's disease
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Neurofibromatosis = connective tissue tumors on skin nerves, Von Recklinghausen's disease. Can affect multiple systems, not just brain. Nerve tumors + skin + genetic = neurofibromatosis.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Raynaud's disease?
options: Raynaud's disease causes fingers and toes to become pale when exposed to cold or emotional stress
It is due to sudden narrowing of arteries supplying the digits
Both A and B are correct
Raynaud's disease only affects the heart
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Raynaud's = vasospastic disorder, fingers/toes pale from cold/stress, artery narrowing. NOT heart disease - it's peripheral vascular. Cold + digits pale = Raynaud's.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding vertigo?
options: Vertigo is the feeling that one or one's surroundings are spinning
It is a vestibular system symptom, often associated with inner ear disorders
Both A and B are correct
Vertigo is the same as dizziness
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Vertigo = spinning sensation (self or surroundings), vestibular symptom, often inner ear-related (e.g., Ménière's). Dizziness is broader term. Spinning + vestibular = vertigo.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding migraine?
options: Migraine is a severe headache usually accompanied by vision problems and/or nausea and vomiting
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Migraine = severe headache + visual aura + nausea/vomiting, typically recurrent. Single episode would be different. Recurrent + aura + nausea = migraine.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding Reye's syndrome?
options: Reye's syndrome mainly affects those under age 15
It is characterized by brain and liver damage following viral infection, and may be linked to aspirin
Both A and B are correct
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Reye's = childhood (<15 years), brain + liver damage, post-viral (chickenpox/flu), aspirin association. NOT adult condition. Child + aspirin + virus = Reye's.

questions.stem: Which statements are true regarding neural tube defects?
options: Neural tube defects are problems in development of spinal cord and brain in an embryo
Examples include spina bifida (spine fails to enclose cord) and anencephaly (brain fails to develop)
Both A and B are correct
Neural tube defects only affect adults
questions.explanation: Both are correct: Neural tube defects = embryologic brain/spinal cord development problems, examples include spina bifida and anencephaly. These are BIRTH defects, not adult conditions. Embryo + CNS defects = neural tube defects.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes anencephaly from microcephaly?
options: Anencephaly is absence of brain/skull (fatal); microcephaly is abnormally small head
questions.explanation: Anencephaly = absence of brain/skull (fatal birth defect). Microcephaly = small head (may be compatible with life). Absence vs small is the key distinction. No brain vs small brain = different conditions.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST distinguishes radiculopathy from myelopathy?
