Use objective, standardized terminology.

questions.stem: A patient with active COVID-19 requires EEG. The technologist should:
options: Use airborne and contact precautions (N95 respirator, gown, gloves, eye protection) per facility protocol
questions.explanation: COVID-19 requires airborne and contact precautions (N95 respirator, gown, gloves, eye protection) per current facility protocol. Standard precautions are insufficient. Follow facility infection control protocols for airborne/contact precautions. Patient and healthcare worker safety require appropriate precautions.

questions.stem: A technologist increases the low-frequency filter (LFF) from 0.5 Hz to 5 Hz. This will:
options: Reduce slow activity (delta, theta) and may distort spike morphology
Have no effect on the tracing
questions.explanation: Increasing LFF (high-pass filter) reduces slow activity (delta, theta) and can distort spike morphology by removing slow components. This is a critical ABRET trap - high LFF can make spikes appear sharper or alter their appearance. Understanding filter effects on waveform morphology is essential.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, a phase reversal at F3-Fz and Fz-C3 indicates the maximum activity is at:
questions.explanation: Phase reversal in bipolar montage occurs at the electrode with maximum activity. Phase reversal at F3-Fz and Fz-C3 means the maximum is at Fz (the common electrode in both chains). Understanding phase reversal is critical for localization in bipolar montages.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, a patient develops chest pain and shortness of breath. The technologist should:
options: Stop hyperventilation immediately, assess patient condition, and notify physician
Only stop if the patient requests
questions.explanation: Chest pain and shortness of breath during hyperventilation may indicate cardiac or respiratory distress. Stop immediately, assess patient condition, and notify physician. Patient safety overrides diagnostic yield. Hyperventilation can cause vasoconstriction and should be stopped if patient experiences distress.

questions.stem: Optimal electrode impedance for EEG recording should be:
options: Less than 5 kΩ (ideally <2 kΩ) with balanced impedances
questions.explanation: Optimal impedance is less than 5 kΩ (ideally <2 kΩ) with balanced impedances across electrodes. High or unbalanced impedance increases noise, artifacts, and signal distortion. Low, balanced impedance ensures optimal signal quality and reduces common-mode rejection issues.

questions.stem: A technologist increases sensitivity from 7 μV/mm to 14 μV/mm. This will:
options: Make waveforms appear larger (amplify the signal)
questions.explanation: Increasing sensitivity (decreasing μV/mm) amplifies the signal, making waveforms appear larger on the display. Sensitivity controls the vertical scale - lower μV/mm = higher sensitivity = larger display. Understanding sensitivity is critical for proper signal display and amplitude measurement.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation at 10 Hz, a normal response would be:
options: Photic driving (posterior rhythm at 10 Hz matching the flash frequency)
questions.explanation: Photic driving is a normal response - posterior rhythm matches the flash frequency (e.g., 10 Hz flashes produce 10 Hz posterior rhythm). This is normal entrainment. Spike-and-wave or spikes are abnormal (photosensitive response). Understanding normal vs abnormal photic responses is critical.

questions.stem: Muscle artifact (EMG) is best identified by:
options: High-frequency, irregular, spiky activity that obscures underlying EEG, maximal in temporal/frontal regions
questions.explanation: Muscle artifact (EMG) is high-frequency (20-300 Hz), irregular, spiky activity that obscures underlying EEG, maximal in temporal/frontal regions. It's caused by muscle tension. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for accurate EEG interpretation and troubleshooting.

questions.stem: A technologist decreases the high-frequency filter (HFF) from 70 Hz to 35 Hz. This will:
options: Reduce fast activity (beta, muscle artifact) and may smooth spikes
Have no effect on the tracing
questions.explanation: Decreasing HFF (low-pass filter) reduces fast activity (beta, muscle artifact) and can smooth spikes by removing fast components. This is a critical ABRET trap - low HFF can alter spike appearance. Understanding filter effects on waveform morphology is essential for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: In a referential montage using ear reference (A1/A2), activity appearing in all channels suggests:
options: Reference contamination (activity in the reference electrode)
questions.explanation: Activity appearing in all channels in a referential montage suggests reference contamination - the activity is in the reference electrode (A1/A2), not the brain. This is a common pitfall. Understanding reference contamination is critical for accurate interpretation in referential montages.

questions.stem: To accurately record a 30 Hz signal, the minimum sampling rate should be:
questions.explanation: Nyquist theorem: sampling rate must be at least 2x the highest frequency to avoid aliasing. For 30 Hz signal, minimum sampling rate is 60 Hz (2 × 30). Sampling at lower rates causes aliasing (false frequencies). Understanding Nyquist is critical for digital EEG recording.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, a normal response in children/adolescents is:
options: Build-up of slow activity (theta/delta) in posterior regions
questions.explanation: Normal hyperventilation response in children/adolescents includes build-up of slow activity (theta/delta) in posterior regions. This is normal physiologic response to hypocapnia. Spike-and-wave or spikes are abnormal. Understanding normal vs abnormal hyperventilation responses is critical.

questions.stem: ECG artifact in EEG is best identified by:
options: Regular, rhythmic deflections occurring at heart rate (60-100/min), often maximal in temporal regions
questions.explanation: ECG artifact appears as regular, rhythmic deflections at heart rate (60-100/min), often maximal in temporal regions due to proximity to neck vessels. It's synchronous with the heartbeat. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for accurate EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Time constant (TC) and low-frequency filter (LFF) are related by:
questions.explanation: Time constant (TC) and LFF are inversely related: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF). Longer TC = lower LFF cutoff. Understanding this relationship is critical for filter selection and understanding how filters affect signal. This is a high-yield ABRET topic.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage chain Fp1-F3-C3-P3-O1, a phase reversal at F3-C3 and C3-P3 indicates maximum activity at:
questions.explanation: Phase reversal in bipolar montage occurs at the electrode with maximum activity. Phase reversal at F3-C3 and C3-P3 means the maximum is at C3 (the common electrode in both adjacent chains). Understanding phase reversal is critical for localization.

questions.stem: Unbalanced electrode impedances (e.g., 2 kΩ vs 10 kΩ) can cause:
options: Increased noise, artifacts, and reduced common-mode rejection
questions.explanation: Unbalanced impedances reduce common-mode rejection, increase noise and artifacts, and can cause signal distortion. Balanced impedances (<5 kΩ, ideally <2 kΩ) are essential for optimal signal quality. Understanding impedance balance is critical for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: To measure a 50 μV spike accurately, the technologist should use:
options: Low sensitivity (high μV/mm) to see the full spike
Appropriate sensitivity (e.g., 7 μV/mm) to display the spike clearly without clipping
Very high sensitivity (low μV/mm) to make it larger
questions.explanation: Appropriate sensitivity (e.g., 7 μV/mm) displays the spike clearly without clipping (signal going off-screen) or being too small. Too high sensitivity causes clipping; too low makes spikes hard to see. Understanding sensitivity selection is critical for accurate amplitude measurement.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, generalized spike-and-wave discharges that are time-locked to the flash frequency indicate:
questions.explanation: Generalized spike-and-wave discharges time-locked to flash frequency indicate photosensitive epileptiform response (abnormal). Normal photic driving is posterior rhythm matching flash frequency without spikes. Understanding abnormal photic responses is critical for identifying photosensitivity.

questions.stem: Eye blink artifact is best identified by:
options: High-amplitude deflections, frontally maximal (Fp1/Fp2), synchronous with blinking
questions.explanation: Eye blink artifact appears as high-amplitude deflections, frontally maximal (Fp1/Fp2), synchronous with blinking. It's caused by eye movement and corneoretinal potential. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for accurate EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: The notch filter (60 Hz) should be used:
options: Only when 60 Hz artifact cannot be eliminated by other means (proper grounding, electrode preparation)
questions.explanation: Notch filter should be used only when 60 Hz artifact cannot be eliminated by other means (proper grounding, electrode preparation, environmental changes). Notch filter can distort signals near 60 Hz. First attempt to eliminate the source, then use notch if necessary. Understanding proper filter use is critical.

questions.stem: Average reference montage is useful for:
options: Localizing focal activity when the reference may be contaminated
questions.explanation: Average reference montage is useful for localizing focal activity when a single reference (like ear) may be contaminated. It averages all electrodes as reference, reducing reference contamination effects. Understanding montage selection is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: Increasing timebase (paper speed) from 30 mm/s to 60 mm/s will:
options: Make waveforms appear compressed (more time per page)
Make waveforms appear stretched (less time per page, better temporal resolution)
questions.explanation: Increasing timebase (paper speed) stretches waveforms horizontally, showing less time per page but providing better temporal resolution for fast activity. Understanding timebase effects is critical for proper display and interpretation of temporal patterns.

questions.stem: Sleep activation is particularly useful for:
options: Focal epileptiform discharges (especially temporal lobe), some generalized epilepsies, and sleep-specific patterns
questions.explanation: Sleep activation is particularly useful for focal epileptiform discharges (especially temporal lobe), some generalized epilepsies, and sleep-specific patterns (spindles, K-complexes). Understanding activation procedures and their diagnostic yield is critical for EEG strategy.

questions.stem: Electrode pop artifact is best identified by:
options: Sudden, high-amplitude, brief deflections in a single electrode, often with return to baseline
questions.explanation: Electrode pop artifact appears as sudden, high-amplitude, brief deflections in a single electrode, often with return to baseline. It's caused by poor electrode contact or impedance changes. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 1 Hz and HFF 70 Hz. A spike appears sharp and well-defined. If LFF is increased to 5 Hz, the spike may:
questions.explanation: Increasing LFF removes slow components, making spikes appear sharper. High LFF can distort spike morphology by removing aftergoing slow waves. Understanding filter effects on spike morphology is a critical ABRET trap - filters can alter waveform appearance.

questions.stem: For localizing a focal spike, the technologist should:
options: Use both bipolar and referential montages to confirm localization
questions.explanation: For accurate localization, use both bipolar (for phase reversal) and referential (to confirm, but watch for reference contamination) montages. Comparing montages confirms localization and helps identify reference contamination. Understanding montage strategy is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: To achieve optimal impedance (<5 kΩ), the technologist should:
options: Clean skin, abrade if necessary, apply conductive paste/gel, and ensure good contact
questions.explanation: Optimal impedance requires proper skin preparation: clean skin, abrade if necessary (remove dead skin cells, oils), apply conductive paste/gel, and ensure good contact. Proper preparation reduces impedance and improves signal quality. Understanding electrode application is foundational.

questions.stem: If a waveform is 'clipping' (going off-screen), the technologist should:
options: Decrease sensitivity (increase μV/mm) to bring signal on-screen
questions.explanation: Clipping (signal going off-screen) means sensitivity is too high. Decrease sensitivity (increase μV/mm) to bring signal on-screen and prevent signal distortion. Clipping causes signal loss and inaccurate amplitude measurement. Understanding sensitivity adjustment is critical.

questions.stem: Hyperventilation is contraindicated in patients with:
options: Recent stroke, severe cardiac disease, sickle cell disease, severe asthma
questions.explanation: Hyperventilation is contraindicated in recent stroke (vasoconstriction risk), severe cardiac disease, sickle cell disease (sickling crisis), severe asthma (bronchospasm). Understanding contraindications is critical for patient safety. Always assess contraindications before activation procedures.

questions.stem: 60 Hz artifact is best resolved by:
options: Checking grounding, electrode impedance, and eliminating environmental sources (unshielded equipment, fluorescent lights) before using notch filter
questions.explanation: 60 Hz artifact should be resolved by checking grounding, electrode impedance, and eliminating environmental sources (unshielded equipment, fluorescent lights) before using notch filter. Notch filter should be last resort. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical for signal quality.

questions.stem: A time constant of 0.1 seconds corresponds to an LFF cutoff of approximately:
options: 0.16 Hz (TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × 0.1) ≈ 1.6 Hz, but this is a trick - 0.1s TC is very short)
questions.explanation: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × TC). For TC = 0.1s: LFF = 1 / (2π × 0.1) ≈ 1.6 Hz. However, 0.1s TC is very short (high LFF cutoff), which removes slow activity. Understanding TC-LFF relationship is a critical ABRET topic.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, a spike shows phase reversal at T3-T5 and T5-O1. The maximum activity is at:
questions.explanation: Phase reversal occurs at the electrode with maximum activity. Phase reversal at T3-T5 and T5-O1 means T5 is the common electrode in both chains, indicating maximum activity at T5. Understanding complex phase reversals is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: A spike with aftergoing slow wave appears normal with LFF 0.5 Hz. If LFF is increased to 10 Hz, the aftergoing slow wave will:
options: Be reduced or eliminated (high LFF removes slow components)
questions.explanation: High LFF (10 Hz) removes slow components, so the aftergoing slow wave will be reduced or eliminated. This can make spikes appear isolated without their slow component, altering morphology. Understanding filter effects on spike-and-wave complexes is critical.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, a 6-year-old child shows build-up of posterior slow activity. This is:
options: Normal - children/adolescents show posterior slow build-up during hyperventilation
questions.explanation: Posterior slow build-up during hyperventilation is normal in children/adolescents. It's a physiologic response to hypocapnia. Understanding age-related normal responses is critical - what's normal in children may differ from adults.

questions.stem: For neonatal EEG, electrode placement should:
options: Use modified 10-20 system with fewer electrodes (typically 9-11) appropriate for head size
Electrode placement doesn't matter for neonates
questions.explanation: Neonatal EEG uses modified 10-20 system with fewer electrodes (typically 9-11) appropriate for smaller head size. Standard adult placement is not appropriate. Understanding age-specific protocols is critical for special populations.

questions.stem: Sweat artifact is best identified by:
options: Slow, irregular baseline drift, often affecting multiple electrodes, worse in warm conditions
questions.explanation: Sweat artifact appears as slow, irregular baseline drift, often affecting multiple electrodes, worse in warm conditions. It's caused by sweat changing electrode impedance. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: Laplacian (source derivation) montage is useful for:
options: Localizing focal activity by reducing effects of distant sources
questions.explanation: Laplacian montage localizes focal activity by reducing effects of distant sources through weighted averaging of surrounding electrodes. It enhances local activity. Understanding different montage types and their uses is critical for localization.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, normal photic driving is most prominent at flash frequencies:
options: 8-16 Hz (alpha range), where it's most prominent
questions.explanation: Normal photic driving is most prominent at 8-16 Hz (alpha range), where posterior rhythm naturally occurs. Understanding frequency-specific responses is critical for interpreting photic stimulation results.

questions.stem: If HFF is decreased from 70 Hz to 35 Hz, beta activity (20-30 Hz) will:
options: Be reduced or eliminated (low HFF removes fast activity)
questions.explanation: Decreasing HFF (low-pass filter) removes fast activity above the cutoff. Beta activity (20-30 Hz) will be reduced or eliminated with HFF 35 Hz. Understanding filter effects on different frequency bands is critical.

questions.stem: Posterior dominant rhythm (PDR) in a normal awake adult should:
options: Be 8-13 Hz, symmetric, reactive to eye opening
questions.explanation: Normal PDR in awake adults is 8-13 Hz, symmetric, and reactive to eye opening (attenuates). Understanding normal background rhythms is foundational for EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: During continuous EEG monitoring in ICU, the technologist notices a pattern concerning for nonconvulsive status epilepticus. The technologist should:
options: Continue monitoring and document at end of shift
Notify medical team immediately per protocol while continuing monitoring
Stop monitoring to focus on patient
Only notify if physician is present
questions.explanation: ICU monitoring requires immediate notification of concerning patterns (like nonconvulsive status) to medical team per protocol. Continue monitoring if it doesn't interfere with care. Patient safety requires prompt communication of critical findings.

questions.stem: In a referential montage, if activity appears in all channels with equal amplitude, the technologist should:
options: Suspect reference contamination and switch to different reference or bipolar montage
questions.explanation: Activity appearing equally in all channels in referential montage suggests reference contamination. Switch to different reference (average, Cz) or bipolar montage to confirm. Understanding reference contamination is critical for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: A time constant of 1.0 second corresponds to an LFF cutoff of approximately:
questions.explanation: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × TC). For TC = 1.0s: LFF = 1 / (2π × 1.0) ≈ 0.16 Hz. Longer TC = lower LFF cutoff, preserving slow activity. Understanding TC-LFF relationship is a critical ABRET topic.

questions.stem: Sleep stage N2 (stage 2) is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Sleep stage N2 is characterized by sleep spindles (11-15 Hz) and K-complexes. Understanding sleep stages and their characteristic patterns is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: Movement artifact is best identified by:
options: Irregular, high-amplitude deflections affecting multiple channels, synchronous with patient movement
questions.explanation: Movement artifact appears as irregular, high-amplitude deflections affecting multiple channels, synchronous with patient movement. It can obscure underlying EEG. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: Common-mode rejection ratio (CMRR) is important for:
options: Reducing noise and artifacts that are common to both inputs (like 60 Hz)
questions.explanation: CMRR reduces noise and artifacts that are common to both inputs (like 60 Hz line noise, environmental interference). High CMRR improves signal quality by rejecting common-mode signals. Understanding amplifier characteristics is critical.

questions.stem: Longitudinal bipolar montages (e.g., Fp1-F3-C3-P3-O1) are best for:
questions.explanation: Longitudinal bipolar montages (anterior-posterior chains) localize activity in anterior-posterior direction. Transverse montages (left-right chains) localize in lateral direction. Understanding montage orientation is critical for localization strategy.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation at 10 Hz, a harmonic response at 20 Hz (2× flash frequency) is:
options: Normal - harmonics (multiples of flash frequency) can occur
questions.explanation: Harmonic responses (multiples of flash frequency, e.g., 20 Hz with 10 Hz flashes) are normal. They're subharmonics of the driving response. Understanding normal photic responses including harmonics is critical.

questions.stem: A 3 Hz spike-and-wave complex appears normal with LFF 0.5 Hz and HFF 70 Hz. If LFF is increased to 5 Hz, the slow wave component will:
options: Be reduced or eliminated (high LFF removes slow components)
questions.explanation: High LFF (5 Hz) removes slow components. The 3 Hz slow wave in spike-and-wave will be reduced or eliminated, leaving only the spike. This alters the morphology of spike-and-wave complexes. Understanding filter effects on complex waveforms is critical.

questions.stem: Sleep spindles are characterized by:
options: 11-15 Hz rhythmic activity, maximal in central regions, occurring during N2 sleep
questions.explanation: Sleep spindles are 11-15 Hz rhythmic activity, maximal in central regions, occurring during N2 sleep. They're normal sleep graphoelements. Understanding normal sleep patterns is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: In neonatal EEG, trace alternant pattern is:
options: Normal in premature and term neonates during quiet sleep
questions.explanation: Trace alternant is normal in premature and term neonates during quiet sleep - alternating periods of activity and relative quiescence. Understanding age-specific normal patterns is critical for neonatal EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Transverse bipolar montages (e.g., Fp1-Fp2, F3-F4) are best for:
options: Localizing activity in lateral direction (left-right asymmetry)
questions.explanation: Transverse bipolar montages (left-right chains) localize activity in lateral direction and detect left-right asymmetry. Longitudinal montages localize in anterior-posterior direction. Understanding montage orientation is critical for localization strategy.

questions.stem: Standard hyperventilation duration is typically:
options: 3-5 minutes (or until activation occurs or patient cannot continue)
questions.explanation: Standard hyperventilation duration is 3-5 minutes or until activation occurs or patient cannot continue safely. Understanding activation protocols is critical for proper procedure performance.

questions.stem: Pulse artifact is best identified by:
options: Regular, rhythmic deflections at pulse rate (60-100/min), often maximal near arteries (temporal, occipital)
questions.explanation: Pulse artifact appears as regular, rhythmic deflections at pulse rate (60-100/min), often maximal near arteries (temporal, occipital regions). It's caused by arterial pulsation. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: Beta activity (20-30 Hz) will be preserved with HFF set to:
options: 70 Hz or higher (HFF must be above the frequency to preserve it)
questions.explanation: HFF must be set above the frequency to preserve it. Beta activity (20-30 Hz) requires HFF 70 Hz or higher to be preserved. Lower HFF will filter out beta. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical.

questions.stem: K-complexes are characterized by:
options: High-amplitude, sharp negative wave followed by positive wave, occurring during N2 sleep, often in response to stimuli
questions.explanation: K-complexes are high-amplitude, sharp negative wave followed by positive wave, occurring during N2 sleep, often in response to stimuli. They're normal sleep graphoelements. Understanding normal sleep patterns is critical.

questions.stem: During ICU continuous EEG, burst-suppression pattern is characterized by:
options: Periods of high-amplitude activity (bursts) alternating with periods of suppression (low amplitude/flat)
questions.explanation: Burst-suppression pattern shows periods of high-amplitude activity (bursts) alternating with periods of suppression (low amplitude/flat). It's seen in severe encephalopathy, anesthesia, or coma. Understanding ICU patterns is critical for continuous monitoring.

questions.stem: Cz (vertex) reference is useful for:
options: Localizing midline activity and reducing reference contamination from lateral sources
questions.explanation: Cz reference is useful for localizing midline activity and reducing reference contamination from lateral sources. Different reference choices affect localization. Understanding reference selection is critical for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: Standard photic stimulation protocol typically includes flash frequencies:
questions.explanation: Standard photic protocol includes multiple frequencies (typically 1-30 Hz range) to test different responses. Understanding activation protocols is critical for proper procedure performance and diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: High-impedance artifact is best identified by:
options: Increased noise, baseline instability, and 60 Hz artifact in affected channels
questions.explanation: High-impedance artifact causes increased noise, baseline instability, and 60 Hz artifact in affected channels. It's resolved by reducing impedance through proper skin preparation. Understanding impedance effects is critical for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: Delta activity (1-3 Hz) will be preserved with LFF set to:
options: 0.5 Hz or lower (LFF must be below the frequency to preserve it)
questions.explanation: LFF must be set below the frequency to preserve it. Delta activity (1-3 Hz) requires LFF 0.5 Hz or lower to be preserved. Higher LFF will filter out delta. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical for preserving frequency bands.

questions.stem: Vertex waves are characterized by:
options: Sharp, high-amplitude waves, maximal at Cz (vertex), occurring during light sleep (N1/N2)
questions.explanation: Vertex waves are sharp, high-amplitude waves, maximal at Cz (vertex), occurring during light sleep (N1/N2). They're normal sleep graphoelements. Understanding normal sleep patterns is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: Glossokinetic artifact (tongue movement) is best identified by:
options: Slow, rhythmic deflections, often maximal in temporal regions, synchronous with tongue movement
questions.explanation: Glossokinetic artifact appears as slow, rhythmic deflections, often maximal in temporal regions, synchronous with tongue movement. It's caused by tongue's electrical potential. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, if a spike shows phase reversal at Fp1-F3 but not in the corresponding right chain (Fp2-F4), this suggests:
options: Focal activity on the left side (asymmetric, not generalized)
questions.explanation: Asymmetric phase reversal (present in one chain but not the corresponding opposite chain) suggests focal, lateralized activity, not generalized. Understanding asymmetry in montages is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: Theta activity (4-7 Hz) will be preserved with LFF set to:
options: 1 Hz or lower (LFF must be below the frequency to preserve it)
questions.explanation: LFF must be set below the frequency to preserve it. Theta activity (4-7 Hz) requires LFF 1 Hz or lower to be preserved. Higher LFF will filter out theta. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical for preserving frequency bands.

questions.stem: During EEG recording, a patient has a clinical event. The technologist should:
options: Only document it after the study
Mark the event immediately, note clinical description, continue recording, and document timing
Only document if physician is present
questions.explanation: Clinical events must be marked immediately, with clinical description noted, recording continued, and timing documented. Event annotation is critical for correlating EEG with clinical manifestations. Understanding event monitoring is essential.

questions.stem: POSTS (positive occipital sharp transients of sleep) are:
options: Normal sleep graphoelements, positive sharp waves in occipital regions during sleep
questions.explanation: POSTS are normal sleep graphoelements - positive sharp waves in occipital regions during sleep. They're benign variants. Understanding normal sleep patterns and benign variants is critical to avoid misinterpreting normal patterns as abnormal.

questions.stem: Chewing artifact is best identified by:
options: Irregular, high-amplitude activity, maximal in temporal regions, synchronous with jaw movement
questions.explanation: Chewing artifact appears as irregular, high-amplitude activity, maximal in temporal regions, synchronous with jaw movement. It's caused by masseter muscle activity. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: Sleep deprivation before EEG is used to:
options: Increase likelihood of sleep during study and enhance activation of epileptiform discharges
questions.explanation: Sleep deprivation increases likelihood of sleep during study and enhances activation of epileptiform discharges. It's a common activation technique. Understanding activation procedures and their mechanisms is critical.

questions.stem: Average reference montage may show false localization if:
options: Focal activity is near the edge of electrode array (edge effect)
questions.explanation: Average reference can show false localization (edge effect) if focal activity is near the edge of electrode array - the average is skewed. Understanding montage limitations is critical for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: Alpha activity (8-13 Hz) will be preserved with HFF set to:
options: 70 Hz or higher (HFF must be above the frequency to preserve it)
questions.explanation: HFF must be set above the frequency to preserve it. Alpha activity (8-13 Hz) requires HFF 70 Hz or higher to be preserved. Lower HFF will filter out alpha. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical.

questions.stem: In neonatal EEG, discontinuous pattern (trace discontinu) is:
options: Normal in premature neonates, with periods of activity alternating with periods of quiescence
questions.explanation: Discontinuous pattern (trace discontinu) is normal in premature neonates - periods of activity alternating with periods of quiescence. Understanding age-specific normal patterns is critical for neonatal EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Shiver/tremor artifact is best identified by:
options: Regular, rhythmic activity at tremor frequency (typically 4-8 Hz), affecting multiple channels, synchronous with visible tremor
questions.explanation: Shiver/tremor artifact appears as regular, rhythmic activity at tremor frequency (typically 4-8 Hz), affecting multiple channels, synchronous with visible tremor. Understanding artifact characteristics is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation at 12 Hz, a subharmonic response at 6 Hz (half the flash frequency) is:
options: Normal - subharmonics (fractions of flash frequency) can occur
questions.explanation: Subharmonic responses (fractions of flash frequency, e.g., 6 Hz with 12 Hz flashes) are normal. They're part of normal photic driving responses. Understanding normal photic responses including harmonics and subharmonics is critical.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, if a spike appears in multiple chains but shows no phase reversal, this suggests:
options: Focal activity at a specific electrode
Widespread activity or activity not maximal at a single electrode
questions.explanation: No phase reversal in bipolar montage suggests widespread activity or activity not maximal at a single electrode. Phase reversal occurs when activity is maximal at a specific electrode. Understanding phase reversal absence is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 10 Hz and HFF 15 Hz. This filter combination will:
options: Create a narrow bandpass (only 10-15 Hz preserved), removing most EEG activity
questions.explanation: LFF 10 Hz removes activity below 10 Hz; HFF 15 Hz removes activity above 15 Hz. This creates a narrow bandpass (10-15 Hz only), removing most EEG activity including delta, theta, alpha, beta. Understanding filter combinations is critical.

questions.stem: Mu rhythm is characterized by:
options: Central 8-13 Hz arch-shaped rhythm, attenuates with contralateral limb movement
questions.explanation: Mu rhythm is central 8-13 Hz arch-shaped rhythm that attenuates with contralateral limb movement. It's a normal variant. Understanding normal variants is critical to avoid misinterpreting them as abnormal.

questions.stem: Pulse artifact is most commonly seen in:
questions.explanation: Pulse artifact is most commonly seen in temporal and occipital regions due to proximity to arteries (temporal artery, occipital artery). Understanding artifact location helps with identification and troubleshooting.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, 'build-up' refers to:
options: Gradual increase in slow activity (theta/delta) in posterior regions, normal response
questions.explanation: Build-up during hyperventilation refers to gradual increase in slow activity (theta/delta) in posterior regions, which is a normal physiologic response to hypocapnia. Understanding normal hyperventilation responses is critical.

questions.stem: Linked ear reference (A1+A2) may reduce:
options: Reference contamination from unilateral ear activity (averages both ears)
questions.explanation: Linked ear reference (A1+A2) averages both ears, reducing reference contamination from unilateral ear activity. Understanding different reference options and their advantages is critical for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: Notch filter (60 Hz) affects signals:
options: At 60 Hz and nearby frequencies (narrow band around 60 Hz)
questions.explanation: Notch filter affects 60 Hz and nearby frequencies (narrow band around 60 Hz), not just exactly 60 Hz. It can distort signals near 60 Hz. Understanding notch filter characteristics is important for proper use.

questions.stem: During ICU continuous EEG, ictal patterns (seizure activity) are characterized by:
options: Rhythmic activity that evolves in frequency, amplitude, and/or distribution
questions.explanation: Ictal patterns show rhythmic activity that evolves in frequency, amplitude, and/or distribution. Evolution is key characteristic of ictal activity. Understanding ictal patterns is critical for ICU continuous monitoring and seizure detection.

questions.stem: Lambda waves are:
options: Normal variant - positive sharp waves in occipital regions during wakefulness with eye movement
questions.explanation: Lambda waves are normal variant - positive sharp waves in occipital regions during wakefulness, associated with eye movement/scanning. They're benign. Understanding normal variants is critical to avoid misinterpreting them as abnormal.

questions.stem: Electrode artifact (poor contact) is best resolved by:
options: Re-preparing electrode (clean skin, reapply paste/gel, ensure good contact)
questions.explanation: Electrode artifact from poor contact is resolved by re-preparing the electrode: clean skin, reapply paste/gel, ensure good contact. Do not compensate with filters or settings - fix the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, the technologist should:
options: Perform with eyes closed, then repeat with eyes open if needed per protocol
questions.explanation: Photic stimulation is typically performed with eyes closed (standard protocol), then may be repeated with eyes open if needed. Understanding activation protocols is critical for proper procedure performance.

questions.stem: For detecting subtle focal slowing, the technologist should:
options: Use both referential (to see amplitude) and bipolar (to confirm localization) montages
questions.explanation: For detecting subtle focal slowing, use both referential (to see amplitude differences) and bipolar (to confirm localization) montages. Comparing montages improves detection and localization. Understanding montage strategy is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 0.5 Hz and HFF 70 Hz. This filter combination will:
options: Preserve frequencies approximately 0.5-70 Hz (standard EEG range)
questions.explanation: LFF 0.5 Hz removes activity below 0.5 Hz; HFF 70 Hz removes activity above 70 Hz. This preserves frequencies approximately 0.5-70 Hz, which is the standard EEG range. Understanding standard filter settings is critical.

questions.stem: When annotating a clinical event, the technologist should document:
options: Time, clinical description (what was observed), duration, and any EEG changes
questions.explanation: Event annotation must include time, clinical description (what was observed), duration, and any EEG changes. Complete documentation is essential for correlating clinical events with EEG. Understanding event monitoring is critical.

questions.stem: Wicket spikes are:
options: Normal variant - arciform waves in temporal regions, 6-11 Hz, during drowsiness/sleep
questions.explanation: Wicket spikes are normal variant - arciform waves in temporal regions, 6-11 Hz, during drowsiness/sleep. They're benign and should not be confused with epileptiform activity. Understanding normal variants is critical.

questions.stem: ECG artifact is best reduced by:
options: Repositioning electrodes away from neck vessels, using different reference, or adding ECG channel for correlation
questions.explanation: ECG artifact is best reduced by repositioning electrodes away from neck vessels, using different reference, or adding ECG channel for correlation. Do not just filter - attempt to reduce the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, normal response in adults is typically:
options: Build-up of posterior slow activity (like children)
Minimal response or slight increase in theta activity (less prominent than children)
questions.explanation: Normal hyperventilation response in adults is typically minimal or slight increase in theta activity, less prominent than children. Children show more prominent posterior slow build-up. Understanding age-related differences is critical.

questions.stem: In the 10-20 system, the distance between Fp1 and O1 is measured as:
questions.explanation: Fp1 to O1 spans the entire nasion-inion distance (100%). The 10-20 system uses percentages of head measurements. Understanding 10-20 system measurements is foundational for electrode placement.

questions.stem: If one electrode has impedance 2 kΩ and its paired electrode has impedance 10 kΩ, this imbalance can cause:
options: Reduced common-mode rejection, increased noise, and potential signal distortion
questions.explanation: Impedance imbalance (2 kΩ vs 10 kΩ) reduces common-mode rejection, increases noise, and can cause signal distortion. Balanced impedances are essential for optimal signal quality. Understanding impedance balance is critical.

questions.stem: To accurately measure a 20 μV spike, the technologist should use sensitivity:
options: Very high (e.g., 2 μV/mm) which may cause clipping
Appropriate (e.g., 7 μV/mm) to display clearly without clipping
Very low (e.g., 20 μV/mm) which makes it hard to see
questions.explanation: Appropriate sensitivity (e.g., 7 μV/mm) displays the 20 μV spike clearly without clipping. Too high sensitivity causes clipping; too low makes spikes hard to see. Understanding sensitivity selection is critical for accurate amplitude measurement.

questions.stem: If a digital EEG system samples at 200 Hz, the highest frequency that can be accurately recorded without aliasing is:
questions.explanation: Nyquist theorem: highest frequency = sampling rate / 2. For 200 Hz sampling, highest frequency = 100 Hz. Sampling below 2× frequency causes aliasing. Understanding Nyquist is critical for digital EEG recording.

questions.stem: Before applying electrodes, skin preparation should include:
options: Cleaning skin, abrading if necessary to remove dead skin cells and oils, then applying conductive paste/gel
questions.explanation: Proper skin preparation includes cleaning skin, abrading if necessary to remove dead skin cells and oils, then applying conductive paste/gel. This reduces impedance and improves signal quality. Understanding electrode application is foundational.

questions.stem: Beta activity (20-30 Hz) in normal awake adults is typically:
options: Low amplitude, frontally predominant, may increase with anxiety or medications
questions.explanation: Beta activity (20-30 Hz) in normal awake adults is low amplitude, frontally predominant, and may increase with anxiety or medications. Understanding normal frequency bands is critical for EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Electrode pop artifact is typically caused by:
options: Poor electrode contact or sudden impedance changes
questions.explanation: Electrode pop artifact is caused by poor electrode contact or sudden impedance changes. It appears as sudden, high-amplitude deflections. Understanding artifact causes helps with troubleshooting and prevention.

questions.stem: When comparing bipolar and referential montages for the same activity, differences in appearance are:
options: Normal - different montages show activity differently, comparison helps confirm localization
questions.explanation: Different montages show activity differently - this is normal. Comparing montages helps confirm localization and identify reference contamination. Understanding montage differences is critical for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 0.1 Hz and HFF 15 Hz. This will:
options: Preserve frequencies approximately 0.1-15 Hz, removing beta and higher frequencies
questions.explanation: LFF 0.1 Hz removes activity below 0.1 Hz; HFF 15 Hz removes activity above 15 Hz. This preserves 0.1-15 Hz, removing beta (20-30 Hz) and higher frequencies. Understanding filter effects is critical.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, the patient should:
options: Breathe deeply and regularly at approximately 20-30 breaths per minute
questions.explanation: Hyperventilation requires deep, regular breathing at approximately 20-30 breaths per minute. Too fast or irregular breathing is ineffective. Understanding proper technique is critical for activation procedures.

questions.stem: Standard neonatal EEG typically uses:
options: Reduced electrode array (9-11 electrodes) appropriate for head size
questions.explanation: Neonatal EEG uses reduced electrode array (9-11 electrodes) appropriate for smaller head size. Full adult array is not appropriate. Understanding age-specific protocols is critical for special populations.

questions.stem: Lateral eye movement artifact is best identified by:
options: Deflections in Fp1/Fp2, opposite polarity for left vs right movement
questions.explanation: Lateral eye movement artifact appears as deflections in Fp1/Fp2 with opposite polarity for left vs right movement. Understanding eye movement artifacts is essential for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: For localizing temporal lobe activity, using a temporal reference (T3/T4) may:
options: Cause reference contamination if the activity is in the temporal region (reference is in the field)
questions.explanation: Using a reference in the same region as the activity (e.g., temporal reference for temporal activity) causes reference contamination - the reference is in the field. Understanding reference selection is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: A time constant of 0.3 seconds corresponds to an LFF cutoff of approximately:
questions.explanation: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × TC). For TC = 0.3s: LFF = 1 / (2π × 0.3) ≈ 0.53 Hz. Understanding TC-LFF relationship is a critical ABRET topic.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, the flash lamp should be positioned:
options: Approximately 30 cm from patient's eyes, at eye level
questions.explanation: Photic stimulation flash lamp should be positioned approximately 30 cm from patient's eyes, at eye level. Proper positioning ensures consistent stimulation. Understanding activation protocols is critical.

questions.stem: Theta activity (4-7 Hz) in normal awake adults is typically:
options: Low amplitude, may be present in temporal regions, more prominent in children
questions.explanation: Theta activity (4-7 Hz) in normal awake adults is low amplitude, may be present in temporal regions, and is more prominent in children. Understanding age-related normal patterns is critical.

questions.stem: When 60 Hz artifact is present, the technologist should FIRST:
options: Check grounding, electrode impedance, and eliminate environmental sources before using notch filter
questions.explanation: Troubleshooting hierarchy: first check grounding, electrode impedance, and eliminate environmental sources. Notch filter should be last resort. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical for signal quality.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, if activity shows maximum amplitude in a longitudinal chain but not in transverse chains, this suggests:
options: Activity localized in anterior-posterior direction (not lateralized)
questions.explanation: Activity maximum in longitudinal chains but not transverse suggests anterior-posterior localization (not lateralized). Understanding montage chain orientation is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: If LFF is set to 5 Hz, delta activity (1-3 Hz) will be:
options: Filtered out (LFF 5 Hz removes activity below 5 Hz)
questions.explanation: LFF 5 Hz removes activity below 5 Hz, so delta (1-3 Hz) will be filtered out. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical - LFF removes slow activity below the cutoff.

questions.stem: REM sleep is characterized by:
options: Low-voltage, mixed-frequency activity, rapid eye movements, muscle atonia
questions.explanation: REM sleep shows low-voltage, mixed-frequency activity, rapid eye movements, and muscle atonia. Understanding sleep stages and their characteristics is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) during ICU monitoring are characterized by:
options: Repetitive, periodic sharp waves or spikes, lateralized to one hemisphere, occurring at regular intervals
questions.explanation: PLEDs are repetitive, periodic sharp waves or spikes, lateralized to one hemisphere, occurring at regular intervals. Understanding ICU patterns is critical for continuous monitoring and interpretation.

questions.stem: Muscle artifact is best reduced by:
options: Asking patient to relax, repositioning if necessary, reducing jaw/tension
questions.explanation: Muscle artifact is best reduced by asking patient to relax, repositioning if necessary, reducing jaw/tension. Do not just filter - attempt to reduce the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: For detecting generalized activity, the technologist should:
options: Use referential montage (to see amplitude) and confirm with bipolar (to rule out reference contamination)
questions.explanation: For detecting generalized activity, use referential montage (to see amplitude distribution) and confirm with bipolar (to rule out reference contamination). Comparing montages improves accuracy. Understanding montage selection is critical.

questions.stem: Gamma activity (30-100 Hz) will be preserved with HFF set to:
options: 100 Hz or higher (HFF must be above the frequency to preserve it)
questions.explanation: HFF must be set above the frequency to preserve it. Gamma activity (30-100 Hz) requires HFF 100 Hz or higher to be preserved. Standard HFF 70 Hz will filter out gamma. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, the build-up of slow activity typically:
questions.explanation: Build-up during hyperventilation develops gradually over 1-3 minutes as hypocapnia develops. Understanding response timing is important for proper procedure performance and interpretation.

questions.stem: Delta activity (1-3 Hz) in normal awake adults is typically:
options: Absent or minimal (delta in awake adults is abnormal)
questions.explanation: Delta activity (1-3 Hz) in normal awake adults is absent or minimal. Delta in awake adults is abnormal and suggests encephalopathy or dysfunction. Understanding normal vs abnormal patterns is critical.

questions.stem: Eye blink artifact is best reduced by:
options: Asking patient to keep eyes closed or open, or repositioning Fp1/Fp2 electrodes
questions.explanation: Eye blink artifact is best reduced by asking patient to keep eyes closed or open, or repositioning Fp1/Fp2 electrodes. Do not just filter - attempt to reduce the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, a sharp phase reversal (clear maximum at one electrode) suggests:
questions.explanation: Sharp phase reversal in bipolar montage suggests focal activity with clear localization. The electrode with maximum activity shows phase reversal. Understanding phase reversal is critical for localization.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 1 Hz and HFF 35 Hz. This filter combination will:
options: Preserve frequencies approximately 1-35 Hz, removing delta below 1 Hz and beta/gamma above 35 Hz
questions.explanation: LFF 1 Hz removes activity below 1 Hz; HFF 35 Hz removes activity above 35 Hz. This preserves 1-35 Hz, removing very slow delta and beta/gamma. Understanding filter effects is critical.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, if the patient shows photic driving at 8 Hz but not at 16 Hz, this:
options: Is normal - photic driving is most prominent in alpha range (8-16 Hz), may not occur at all frequencies
questions.explanation: Photic driving is most prominent in alpha range (8-16 Hz) and may not occur at all frequencies. This is normal - not all frequencies produce driving. Understanding normal photic responses is critical.

questions.stem: Cup electrodes are typically used for:
options: Routine EEG studies, applied with conductive paste/gel
questions.explanation: Cup electrodes are standard for routine EEG studies, applied with conductive paste/gel. They're reusable and provide good signal quality. Understanding electrode types and their applications is foundational.

questions.stem: In the 10-20 system, electrode C3 is located:
options: At 20% of the distance from Cz to the left ear, along the central line
questions.explanation: C3 is located at 20% of the distance from Cz to the left ear, along the central line. Understanding 10-20 system electrode locations is foundational for EEG recording and localization.

questions.stem: Proper grounding of EEG equipment is essential for:
options: Electrical safety and signal quality (reduces noise, prevents shock)
questions.explanation: Proper grounding is essential for both electrical safety (prevents shock) and signal quality (reduces noise, improves common-mode rejection). Understanding grounding is critical for safety and signal quality.

questions.stem: Sudden impedance changes during recording can cause:
options: Artifacts (electrode pop, baseline shifts) and signal distortion
questions.explanation: Sudden impedance changes cause artifacts (electrode pop, baseline shifts) and signal distortion. Maintaining stable, low impedance is essential. Understanding impedance stability is critical for troubleshooting.

questions.stem: If reference contamination is suspected in a referential montage, the technologist should:
options: Switch to different reference (average, Cz) or bipolar montage to confirm
questions.explanation: If reference contamination is suspected, switch to different reference (average, Cz) or bipolar montage to confirm. Comparing montages helps identify reference contamination. Understanding troubleshooting strategies is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 0.5 Hz and HFF 70 Hz. This is:
options: Standard EEG filter settings (preserves 0.5-70 Hz range)
questions.explanation: LFF 0.5 Hz and HFF 70 Hz are standard EEG filter settings that preserve the 0.5-70 Hz range (delta through beta). Understanding standard settings is critical for routine EEG recording.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, the technologist should monitor:
options: Patient condition (breathing, color, distress), EEG changes, and be ready to stop if needed
questions.explanation: During hyperventilation, monitor patient condition (breathing, color, distress), EEG changes, and be ready to stop if needed. Patient safety is paramount. Understanding activation procedure monitoring is critical.

questions.stem: Sleep spindles in children are typically:
options: More prominent and longer duration than adults
questions.explanation: Sleep spindles in children are typically more prominent and longer duration than adults. Understanding age-related differences in sleep patterns is critical for pediatric EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Sweat artifact is best reduced by:
options: Cooling the environment, ensuring patient comfort, and maintaining good electrode contact
questions.explanation: Sweat artifact is best reduced by cooling the environment, ensuring patient comfort, and maintaining good electrode contact. Do not just filter - address the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: When activity appears larger in referential montage than bipolar montage, this suggests:
options: Widespread activity or activity not well-localized to a single electrode
questions.explanation: Activity appearing larger in referential than bipolar suggests widespread activity or activity not well-localized to a single electrode. Understanding montage differences helps with interpretation.

questions.stem: A time constant of 0.5 seconds corresponds to an LFF cutoff of approximately:
questions.explanation: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × TC). For TC = 0.5s: LFF = 1 / (2π × 0.5) ≈ 0.32 Hz. Understanding TC-LFF relationship is a critical ABRET topic.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, flash intensity should be:
options: Standardized and consistent (typically moderate intensity, per facility protocol)
questions.explanation: Photic stimulation flash intensity should be standardized and consistent (typically moderate intensity, per facility protocol). Understanding activation protocols ensures consistent and reproducible results.

questions.stem: For neonatal EEG, electrode placement must account for:
options: Smaller head size, using modified 10-20 system with appropriate spacing
questions.explanation: Neonatal EEG requires modified 10-20 system with appropriate spacing for smaller head size. Standard adult measurements are not appropriate. Understanding age-specific protocols is critical.

questions.stem: Movement artifact is best reduced by:
options: Ensuring patient comfort, minimizing movement, and securing electrodes/cables
questions.explanation: Movement artifact is best reduced by ensuring patient comfort, minimizing movement, and securing electrodes/cables. Do not just filter - address the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: For detecting focal slowing, bipolar montages are useful because:
options: They show phase reversal or amplitude asymmetry, helping localize the slowing
questions.explanation: Bipolar montages show phase reversal or amplitude asymmetry for focal slowing, helping localize it. Understanding montage selection for different findings is critical for accurate interpretation.

questions.stem: If HFF is set to 15 Hz, alpha activity (8-13 Hz) will be:
options: Preserved but beta (20-30 Hz) will be filtered out
questions.explanation: HFF 15 Hz preserves alpha (8-13 Hz) since it's below the cutoff, but filters out beta (20-30 Hz) which is above the cutoff. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical for preserving desired frequencies.

questions.stem: Sleep activation is most effective for:
options: All types of epileptiform activity equally
Focal temporal lobe epileptiform discharges (can increase 10-100x during sleep)
questions.explanation: Sleep activation is most effective for focal temporal lobe epileptiform discharges, which can increase 10-100x during sleep. Understanding activation effectiveness is critical for diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: K-complexes are most prominent during:
questions.explanation: K-complexes are most prominent during N2 sleep (stage 2). Understanding sleep stage characteristics is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: ECG artifact is most commonly seen in electrodes:
options: T3, T4, and sometimes O1, O2 (near temporal and occipital arteries)
questions.explanation: ECG artifact is most commonly seen in T3, T4, and sometimes O1, O2 due to proximity to temporal and occipital arteries. Understanding artifact location helps with identification and troubleshooting.

questions.stem: Average reference montage is particularly useful for:
questions.explanation: Average reference montage is particularly useful for generalized activity as it reduces reference contamination effects. Understanding montage selection for different activity types is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 2 Hz and HFF 30 Hz. This will:
options: Preserve frequencies approximately 2-30 Hz, removing very slow delta and beta/gamma
questions.explanation: LFF 2 Hz removes activity below 2 Hz; HFF 30 Hz removes activity above 30 Hz. This preserves 2-30 Hz, removing very slow delta and beta/gamma. Understanding filter effects is critical.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, the response may vary based on:
options: Patient age, level of cooperation, baseline EEG, and individual variability
questions.explanation: Hyperventilation response varies based on patient age, level of cooperation, baseline EEG, and individual variability. Understanding response variability is important for proper interpretation.

questions.stem: Generalized periodic discharges (GPDs) during ICU monitoring are characterized by:
options: Repetitive, periodic sharp waves or spikes, generalized (bilateral), occurring at regular intervals
questions.explanation: GPDs are repetitive, periodic sharp waves or spikes, generalized (bilateral), occurring at regular intervals. Understanding ICU patterns is critical for continuous monitoring and interpretation.

questions.stem: Cable artifact (movement of electrode cables) is best reduced by:
options: Securing cables to prevent movement, using cable management
questions.explanation: Cable artifact is best reduced by securing cables to prevent movement and using cable management. Do not just filter - address the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: For routine EEG recording, the technologist should:
options: Use multiple montages (bipolar and referential) to provide comprehensive view
questions.explanation: Routine EEG should use multiple montages (bipolar and referential) to provide comprehensive view and allow comparison. Understanding montage strategy is critical for complete EEG recording.

questions.stem: If LFF is set to 10 Hz, theta activity (4-7 Hz) will be:
options: Filtered out (LFF 10 Hz removes activity below 10 Hz)
questions.explanation: LFF 10 Hz removes activity below 10 Hz, so theta (4-7 Hz) will be filtered out. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical - LFF removes slow activity below the cutoff.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation with eyes closed, normal photic driving is:
options: Most prominent (eyes closed enhances alpha range response)
questions.explanation: Photic driving is most prominent with eyes closed, as it enhances alpha range response. Understanding activation protocols and their effects is critical for proper procedure performance.

questions.stem: Vertex waves are most prominent during:
questions.explanation: Vertex waves are most prominent during light sleep (N1/N2). Understanding sleep stage characteristics is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: Glossokinetic artifact is best reduced by:
options: Asking patient to keep tongue still, or repositioning electrodes if necessary
questions.explanation: Glossokinetic artifact is best reduced by asking patient to keep tongue still or repositioning electrodes if necessary. Do not just filter - address the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: When comparing bipolar and referential montages, if activity appears focal in bipolar but widespread in referential, this suggests:
options: Activity may be more widespread than bipolar suggests, or reference contamination
questions.explanation: Activity appearing focal in bipolar but widespread in referential suggests activity may be more widespread than bipolar suggests, or reference contamination. Comparing montages helps clarify. Understanding montage differences is critical.

questions.stem: In the 10-20 system, the distance between Fp1 and F3 is:
questions.explanation: Fp1 to F3 is 20% of the nasion-inion distance. The 10-20 system uses 10% and 20% increments. Understanding 10-20 system measurements is foundational for electrode placement.

questions.stem: After skin preparation, if impedance remains high (>10 kΩ), the technologist should:
options: Re-prepare the electrode site (more thorough cleaning, abrading, reapply paste/gel)
questions.explanation: High impedance after preparation requires re-preparation: more thorough cleaning, abrading, reapply paste/gel. Do not compensate with settings - fix the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: If sensitivity is set to 5 μV/mm, a 50 μV signal will display as:
questions.explanation: Sensitivity = μV/mm. For 50 μV signal at 5 μV/mm sensitivity: 50 / 5 = 10 mm deflection. Understanding sensitivity calculations is critical for amplitude measurement.

questions.stem: To accurately record activity up to 50 Hz without aliasing, the minimum sampling rate should be:
questions.explanation: Nyquist theorem: minimum sampling rate = 2 × highest frequency. For 50 Hz, minimum is 100 Hz. Understanding Nyquist is critical for digital EEG recording to avoid aliasing.

questions.stem: Before starting recording, the technologist should:
options: Check all electrode impedances, verify they are balanced and <5 kΩ, then start recording
questions.explanation: Before recording, check all electrode impedances, verify they are balanced and <5 kΩ. This ensures optimal signal quality. Understanding pre-recording checks is critical for quality assurance.

questions.stem: Posterior dominant rhythm (alpha) in normal awake adults should:
questions.explanation: Normal PDR (alpha) should attenuate (decrease) with eye opening - this is reactivity. Lack of reactivity may be significant. Understanding normal reactivity is critical for EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: If an electrode shows intermittent artifacts despite acceptable initial impedance, the technologist should:
options: Re-check impedance, re-prepare electrode if necessary, or replace electrode/cable if problem persists
questions.explanation: Intermittent artifacts despite acceptable initial impedance require re-checking impedance, re-preparing electrode, or replacing electrode/cable if problem persists. Do not just filter - troubleshoot the source.

questions.stem: In a bipolar montage, if a spike shows phase reversal in longitudinal chains but not in transverse chains, this suggests:
options: Activity localized in anterior-posterior direction, not well-lateralized
questions.explanation: Phase reversal in longitudinal but not transverse chains suggests anterior-posterior localization without clear lateralization. Understanding phase reversal patterns in different chain orientations is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 0.3 Hz and HFF 50 Hz. This will:
options: Preserve frequencies approximately 0.3-50 Hz, removing very slow activity and beta/gamma above 50 Hz
questions.explanation: LFF 0.3 Hz removes activity below 0.3 Hz; HFF 50 Hz removes activity above 50 Hz. This preserves 0.3-50 Hz, removing very slow activity and beta/gamma. Understanding filter effects is critical.

questions.stem: If a patient cannot maintain adequate hyperventilation technique, the technologist should:
options: Provide coaching, demonstrate technique, or consider alternative activation if patient cannot cooperate
questions.explanation: If patient cannot maintain adequate technique, provide coaching, demonstrate, or consider alternatives. Document the attempt and limitations. Understanding activation procedure adaptation is important.

questions.stem: In neonatal EEG, the background pattern changes with:
options: Conceptual age (gestational + postnatal age), sleep state, and wakefulness
questions.explanation: Neonatal background patterns change with conceptual age (gestational + postnatal age), sleep state, and wakefulness. Understanding age-specific patterns is critical for neonatal EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Eye movement artifacts are caused by:
options: Corneoretinal potential (electrical potential between cornea and retina)
questions.explanation: Eye movement artifacts are caused by corneoretinal potential - electrical potential between cornea (positive) and retina (negative). Understanding artifact mechanisms helps with identification and troubleshooting.

questions.stem: For localizing occipital activity, using an occipital reference (O1/O2) may:
options: Cause reference contamination if the activity is in the occipital region (reference is in the field)
questions.explanation: Using a reference in the same region as the activity (e.g., occipital reference for occipital activity) causes reference contamination. Understanding reference selection is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: A time constant of 0.16 seconds corresponds to an LFF cutoff of approximately:
questions.explanation: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × TC). For TC = 0.16s: LFF = 1 / (2π × 0.16) ≈ 1.0 Hz. Understanding TC-LFF relationship is a critical ABRET topic.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, if photic driving occurs at multiple frequencies (e.g., 8, 10, 12 Hz), this is:
options: Normal - photic driving can occur at multiple frequencies in alpha range
questions.explanation: Photic driving at multiple frequencies in alpha range (8-16 Hz) is normal. Understanding normal photic responses including frequency range is critical for interpretation.

questions.stem: N3 sleep (deep sleep, slow-wave sleep) is characterized by:
options: High-amplitude delta waves (slow-wave sleep), >20% of epoch
questions.explanation: N3 sleep (deep sleep) is characterized by high-amplitude delta waves, with >20% of epoch showing slow-wave activity. Understanding sleep stages is critical for sleep activation.

questions.stem: If electrode cables are moving during recording, this can cause:
options: Movement artifacts, baseline instability, and signal distortion
questions.explanation: Moving cables cause movement artifacts, baseline instability, and signal distortion. Cables should be secured. Understanding cable management is important for signal quality.

questions.stem: For detecting subtle amplitude asymmetries, the technologist should:
options: Use referential montage (to see amplitude differences) and confirm with bipolar
questions.explanation: Referential montage shows amplitude differences better than bipolar. Use referential to detect asymmetries, then confirm with bipolar. Understanding montage selection for different findings is critical.

questions.stem: If LFF is set to 1 Hz and HFF is set to 15 Hz, alpha activity (8-13 Hz) will be:
options: Preserved (alpha 8-13 Hz is within 1-15 Hz range)
questions.explanation: LFF 1 Hz and HFF 15 Hz preserve frequencies 1-15 Hz. Alpha (8-13 Hz) is within this range, so it will be preserved. Understanding filter ranges is critical.

questions.stem: After stopping hyperventilation, the build-up of slow activity typically:
options: Gradually resolves over 1-2 minutes as CO2 returns to normal
questions.explanation: After stopping hyperventilation, build-up gradually resolves over 1-2 minutes as CO2 returns to normal. Understanding response timing and recovery is important for proper procedure performance.

questions.stem: During ICU continuous EEG, rhythmic delta activity (RDA) is characterized by:
options: Rhythmic delta activity, often focal or lateralized, may be ictal or interictal
questions.explanation: RDA is rhythmic delta activity, often focal or lateralized, which may be ictal or interictal. Understanding ICU patterns is critical for continuous monitoring and seizure detection.

questions.stem: Muscle artifact in temporal regions is often caused by:
options: Jaw clenching, teeth grinding, or temporalis muscle tension
questions.explanation: Temporal muscle artifact is often caused by jaw clenching, teeth grinding, or temporalis muscle tension. Understanding artifact sources helps with identification and troubleshooting.

questions.stem: When activity shows clear phase reversal in bipolar but appears equal in all channels in referential, this suggests:
options: Focal activity with reference contamination in referential montage
questions.explanation: Clear phase reversal in bipolar but equal in referential suggests focal activity with reference contamination in referential. Comparing montages helps identify reference contamination. Understanding montage differences is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 0.1 Hz and HFF 100 Hz. This will:
options: Preserve frequencies approximately 0.1-100 Hz (very wide bandpass)
questions.explanation: LFF 0.1 Hz and HFF 100 Hz preserve 0.1-100 Hz (very wide bandpass), including gamma activity. Understanding filter ranges is critical for preserving desired frequency bands.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation with eyes open, photic driving is typically:
options: More prominent than with eyes closed
Less prominent or absent (eyes closed enhances alpha range response)
questions.explanation: Photic driving is less prominent or absent with eyes open, as eyes closed enhances alpha range response. Understanding activation protocols and their effects is critical.

questions.stem: Sleep spindles typically have a frequency of:
questions.explanation: Sleep spindles are 11-15 Hz rhythmic activity. Understanding normal sleep graphoelements and their characteristics is critical for sleep activation and interpretation.

questions.stem: If an electrode shows baseline drift (slow, irregular movement), this may indicate:
options: Poor electrode contact, unstable impedance, or sweat artifact
questions.explanation: Baseline drift suggests poor electrode contact, unstable impedance, or sweat artifact. Understanding artifact characteristics helps with troubleshooting and resolution.

questions.stem: For routine EEG, switching between montages during recording allows:
options: Comparison of findings, confirmation of localization, and identification of artifacts
questions.explanation: Switching between montages allows comparison of findings, confirmation of localization, and identification of artifacts. Understanding montage strategy is critical for comprehensive EEG recording.

questions.stem: If HFF is set to 20 Hz, beta activity (20-30 Hz) will be:
options: Partially filtered (20 Hz preserved, 21-30 Hz filtered out)
questions.explanation: HFF 20 Hz preserves activity up to 20 Hz but filters out activity above 20 Hz. Beta 20-30 Hz: 20 Hz preserved, 21-30 Hz filtered. Understanding filter cutoffs is critical.

questions.stem: Sleep deprivation enhances diagnostic yield by:
options: Increasing likelihood of sleep during study and enhancing activation of epileptiform discharges
questions.explanation: Sleep deprivation increases likelihood of sleep during study and enhances activation of epileptiform discharges. Understanding activation mechanisms is critical for diagnostic yield.

questions.stem: In the 10-20 system, electrode P3 is located:
options: At 20% of the distance from Cz to the left ear, along the parietal line
questions.explanation: P3 is located at 20% of the distance from Cz to the left ear, along the parietal line. Understanding 10-20 system electrode locations is foundational for EEG recording and localization.

questions.stem: If impedances are balanced (all <5 kΩ) but one electrode pair shows different amplitudes, this suggests:
options: True amplitude difference (not an impedance artifact)
questions.explanation: If impedances are balanced and low, amplitude differences suggest true amplitude differences, not impedance artifacts. Understanding impedance effects vs true findings is critical for interpretation.

questions.stem: If a 100 μV spike is clipping (going off-screen) at sensitivity 5 μV/mm, the technologist should:
options: Decrease sensitivity (increase μV/mm, e.g., to 10 μV/mm) to bring signal on-screen
questions.explanation: Clipping means sensitivity is too high. Decrease sensitivity (increase μV/mm, e.g., 5 to 10 μV/mm) to bring 100 μV signal on-screen. Understanding sensitivity adjustment is critical.

questions.stem: If a digital EEG system samples at 500 Hz, the highest frequency that can be accurately recorded is:
questions.explanation: Nyquist theorem: highest frequency = sampling rate / 2. For 500 Hz sampling, highest frequency = 250 Hz. Understanding Nyquist is critical for digital EEG recording to avoid aliasing.

questions.stem: The ground electrode in EEG recording is essential for:
options: Electrical safety and signal quality (provides reference point, reduces noise)
questions.explanation: Ground electrode is essential for both electrical safety (prevents shock) and signal quality (provides reference point, reduces noise). Understanding grounding is critical for safety and signal quality.

questions.stem: Beta activity may be increased by:
options: Benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and other CNS depressants
questions.explanation: Beta activity may be increased by benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and other CNS depressants. Understanding medication effects on EEG is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: If multiple electrodes show high impedance (>10 kΩ), the technologist should:
options: Re-prepare all affected electrodes (systematic approach to reduce impedance)
questions.explanation: Multiple high-impedance electrodes require systematic re-preparation of all affected electrodes. Do not compensate with settings - fix the source. Understanding troubleshooting approach is critical.

questions.stem: When comparing montages, if activity appears in only one channel in referential but shows phase reversal in bipolar, this suggests:
options: Focal activity with good localization (referential shows field, bipolar confirms with phase reversal)
questions.explanation: Activity in one referential channel with phase reversal in bipolar suggests focal activity with good localization. Comparing montages confirms localization. Understanding montage comparison is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist uses LFF 0.5 Hz and HFF 70 Hz. This is appropriate for:
options: Routine EEG recording (standard settings preserve 0.5-70 Hz range)
questions.explanation: LFF 0.5 Hz and HFF 70 Hz are standard settings for routine EEG, preserving 0.5-70 Hz range (delta through beta). Understanding standard settings is critical for routine recording.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, if a patient becomes lightheaded, the technologist should:
options: Stop hyperventilation, allow patient to recover, and document the response
questions.explanation: Lightheadedness during hyperventilation requires stopping the procedure, allowing patient to recover, and documenting the response. Patient safety is paramount. Understanding activation safety is critical.

questions.stem: In neonatal EEG, sleep states are typically classified as:
options: Active sleep, quiet sleep, indeterminate sleep (different from adult sleep stages)
questions.explanation: Neonatal sleep states are active sleep, quiet sleep, and indeterminate sleep - different from adult sleep stages. Understanding age-specific classifications is critical for neonatal EEG.

questions.stem: Eye blink artifact shows positive deflection in Fp1 because:
options: Cornea (positive) moves toward Fp1, creating positive deflection
questions.explanation: Eye blink shows positive deflection in Fp1 because cornea (positive) moves toward Fp1. Understanding corneoretinal potential and polarity helps with artifact identification.

questions.stem: For detecting midline activity, using Cz as reference may:
options: Cause reference contamination if activity is at Cz (reference is in the field)
questions.explanation: Using Cz as reference for midline activity causes reference contamination if activity is at Cz - the reference is in the field. Understanding reference selection is critical for accurate localization.

questions.stem: A time constant of 2.0 seconds corresponds to an LFF cutoff of approximately:
questions.explanation: TC = 1 / (2π × LFF), so LFF = 1 / (2π × TC). For TC = 2.0s: LFF = 1 / (2π × 2.0) ≈ 0.08 Hz. Very long TC = very low LFF, preserving very slow activity. Understanding TC-LFF relationship is critical.

questions.stem: During photic stimulation, if photic driving is absent at all frequencies, this:
options: May be normal - not all individuals show photic driving
questions.explanation: Absence of photic driving may be normal - not all individuals show photic driving. Understanding normal response variability is important for proper interpretation.

questions.stem: REM sleep is characterized by:
options: Low-voltage, mixed-frequency activity, rapid eye movements, muscle atonia, sawtooth waves
questions.explanation: REM sleep shows low-voltage, mixed-frequency activity, rapid eye movements, muscle atonia, and sawtooth waves. Understanding sleep stages is critical for sleep activation.

questions.stem: If electrode cables are creating artifacts during recording, the technologist should:
options: Secure cables to prevent movement, use cable management, or reposition if necessary
