questions.explanation: Cable artifacts require securing cables to prevent movement, using cable management, or repositioning. Do not just filter - address the source. Understanding troubleshooting hierarchy is critical.

questions.stem: For detecting temporal lobe activity, the technologist should use:
options: Both referential (to see amplitude) and bipolar (to confirm localization with phase reversal) montages
questions.explanation: For temporal lobe activity, use both referential (to see amplitude) and bipolar (to confirm localization with phase reversal) montages. Comparing montages improves accuracy. Understanding montage strategy is critical.

questions.stem: If LFF is set to 3 Hz and HFF is set to 30 Hz, theta activity (4-7 Hz) will be:
options: Preserved (theta 4-7 Hz is within 3-30 Hz range)
questions.explanation: LFF 3 Hz and HFF 30 Hz preserve frequencies 3-30 Hz. Theta (4-7 Hz) is within this range, so it will be preserved. Understanding filter ranges is critical.

questions.stem: During hyperventilation, the response may be affected by:
options: Patient age, cooperation, baseline EEG, medications, and individual variability
questions.explanation: Hyperventilation response is affected by multiple factors: age, cooperation, baseline EEG, medications, and individual variability. Understanding response variability is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: During ICU continuous EEG, ictal patterns that evolve in frequency and amplitude suggest:
options: Seizure activity (evolution is characteristic of ictal patterns)
questions.explanation: Ictal patterns that evolve in frequency and amplitude suggest seizure activity. Evolution is a key characteristic of ictal patterns. Understanding ictal characteristics is critical for ICU monitoring.

questions.stem: A technologist accidentally emails an EEG report to the wrong patient. The report contains protected health information (PHI). What must the technologist do?
options: Nothing if the patient doesn't complain
Immediately notify supervisor, document the breach, and follow facility HIPAA breach notification protocol (may require patient notification within 60 days)
Delete the email and hope no one notices
questions.explanation: HIPAA requires immediate notification of supervisor, documentation of the breach, and following facility breach notification protocol. Breaches may require patient notification within 60 days. Understanding HIPAA breach requirements is critical for compliance.

questions.stem: A patient asks the technologist to interpret their EEG results and explain what the findings mean for their diagnosis. The technologist should:
options: Provide a detailed interpretation and diagnosis
Explain that technologists provide technical observations only, and interpretation/diagnosis is the physician's responsibility
Give a brief summary of what was seen
questions.explanation: Technologists provide technical observations only; interpretation and diagnosis are the physician's responsibility. Understanding scope of practice is critical - technologists do NOT diagnose or interpret clinical significance.

questions.stem: In a technical report, the technologist should describe epileptiform discharges as:
options: 'Epileptiform discharges' or 'spike-and-wave complexes' (objective description, not diagnostic)
questions.explanation: Technical reports use objective terminology: 'epileptiform discharges' or 'spike-and-wave complexes', not diagnostic terms like 'seizure activity' or 'epilepsy'. Understanding proper technical terminology is critical for scope of practice.

questions.stem: During routine equipment check, the technologist notices that calibration signals are consistently 2% lower than expected across all channels. The technologist should:
options: Continue using the equipment and note the 2% difference
Tag equipment as out of service, notify supervisor, and use backup equipment (calibration errors affect signal accuracy)
Adjust settings to compensate for the 2% difference
Only document it if it gets worse
questions.explanation: Calibration errors, even small ones, affect signal accuracy and must be addressed. Equipment with calibration problems must be tagged out of service, supervisor notified, and backup equipment used. Never compensate with settings.

questions.stem: A technologist posts on social media: 'Just finished an interesting EEG case today - patient had some really unusual patterns!' without identifying information. This is:
options: Acceptable since no identifying information was shared
Unacceptable - discussing patient cases on social media violates confidentiality and professional boundaries, even without identifiers
Acceptable if the patient gave permission
Acceptable if the post is private
questions.explanation: Discussing patient cases on social media violates confidentiality and professional boundaries, even without identifiers. HIPAA and professional ethics prohibit such discussions. Understanding professional boundaries is critical.

questions.stem: Before starting an EEG, the technologist notices a frayed power cord on the amplifier. The technologist should:
options: Continue if the equipment still works
Tag equipment as out of service, notify supervisor, and use backup equipment (electrical safety hazard)
Tape the frayed area and continue
questions.explanation: Frayed power cords are electrical safety hazards and must be addressed immediately. Equipment must be tagged out of service, supervisor notified, and backup equipment used. Electrical safety is paramount.

questions.stem: A family member calls and asks for information about a patient's EEG results. The technologist should:
options: Provide information if the family member sounds concerned
Verify identity and authorization (patient consent or legal authorization) before releasing any PHI
Refer to the physician only if it's bad news
questions.explanation: HIPAA requires verification of identity and authorization (patient consent or legal authorization) before releasing any PHI to family members. Understanding HIPAA authorization requirements is critical for patient privacy.

questions.stem: A technologist documents: 'The EEG shows improvement compared to previous study, suggesting the medication is working.' This documentation is:
options: Inappropriate - technologists should describe findings objectively without clinical interpretation or medication assessment
Appropriate if it's clearly an improvement
questions.explanation: Technologists should describe findings objectively without clinical interpretation, medication assessment, or diagnostic conclusions. 'Improvement' and 'medication working' are clinical interpretations beyond scope of practice.

questions.stem: A technologist needs to use a cleaning solution for equipment disinfection. The technologist should:
options: Check MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheet) for proper use, safety precautions, and personal protective equipment requirements
Ask a colleague what they use
questions.explanation: OSHA requires checking MSDS for proper use, safety precautions, and personal protective equipment requirements before using cleaning solutions. Understanding workplace safety protocols is critical.

questions.stem: During an EEG, a patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The technologist should:
options: Place an object in the patient's mouth to prevent tongue biting
Ensure patient safety (protect head, prevent injury), do NOT place objects in mouth, time the seizure, maintain airway if possible, and activate emergency response if seizure >5 minutes
Only call for help if the seizure lasts >10 minutes
questions.explanation: During seizures: ensure patient safety (protect head, prevent injury), do NOT place objects in mouth (critical safety rule), time the seizure, maintain airway if possible, and activate emergency response if seizure >5 minutes (status epilepticus).

questions.stem: A technologist overhears colleagues discussing a patient's case in the hallway where others can hear. The technologist should:
options: Remind colleagues that patient discussions should occur in private areas to protect confidentiality
Ignore it if no patients are nearby
Only intervene if it's sensitive information
questions.explanation: Patient discussions must occur in private areas to protect confidentiality. Overhearing PHI in public areas violates HIPAA. Understanding workplace confidentiality is critical for professional conduct.

questions.stem: A technologist documents: 'The EEG is consistent with temporal lobe epilepsy.' This documentation is:
options: Appropriate - technologists can identify epilepsy types
Inappropriate - technologists should describe patterns objectively (e.g., 'left temporal spikes') without diagnostic conclusions
Appropriate if the pattern is classic
questions.explanation: Technologists should describe patterns objectively (e.g., 'left temporal spikes') without diagnostic conclusions like 'temporal lobe epilepsy'. Understanding scope of practice and proper terminology is critical.

questions.stem: Equipment preventive maintenance should be performed:
options: According to manufacturer recommendations and facility schedule (regular, scheduled maintenance)
questions.explanation: Preventive maintenance should be performed according to manufacturer recommendations and facility schedule. Regular, scheduled maintenance prevents equipment failure and ensures optimal performance. Understanding quality assurance is critical.

questions.stem: HIPAA's 'minimum necessary' rule means:
options: Share all information with anyone who asks
Access and share only the minimum PHI necessary to perform job duties
questions.explanation: HIPAA's 'minimum necessary' rule requires accessing and sharing only the minimum PHI necessary to perform job duties. Understanding HIPAA principles is critical for compliance.

questions.stem: Standard precautions for infection control include:
options: Hand hygiene, personal protective equipment (gloves, gowns, masks as indicated), and safe handling of equipment/materials
Only for patients with known infections
questions.explanation: Standard precautions include hand hygiene, personal protective equipment (gloves, gowns, masks as indicated), and safe handling of equipment/materials. These apply to ALL patients, not just those with known infections.

questions.stem: A physician asks a technologist to interpret an EEG and provide a diagnosis. The technologist should:
options: Explain that technologists provide technical observations only, and interpretation/diagnosis is the physician's responsibility
questions.explanation: Technologists provide technical observations only; interpretation and diagnosis are the physician's responsibility, even if a physician asks. Understanding scope of practice is critical - technologists do NOT diagnose.

questions.stem: A technologist recognizes a patient from a previous study and mentions details from that study to the patient. This is:
options: Potentially inappropriate - patient may not remember or may not want previous studies discussed; maintain professional boundaries
Acceptable if the information is positive
Acceptable if the patient initiates the discussion
questions.explanation: Discussing previous studies may be inappropriate - patient may not remember or may not want previous studies discussed. Maintain professional boundaries and focus on current study unless patient initiates discussion.

questions.stem: A technologist documents: 'The EEG shows resolution of previous abnormalities, indicating successful treatment.' This documentation is:
options: Appropriate - technologists can assess treatment response
Inappropriate - technologists should describe current findings objectively without treatment assessment or clinical interpretation
questions.explanation: Technologists should describe current findings objectively without treatment assessment or clinical interpretation. 'Successful treatment' is a clinical interpretation beyond scope of practice.

questions.stem: OSHA electrical safety requirements for EEG equipment include:
options: Proper grounding, inspection of cords/plugs, and safe handling of electrical equipment
questions.explanation: OSHA requires proper grounding, inspection of cords/plugs, and safe handling of electrical equipment. Understanding workplace safety regulations is critical for compliance.

questions.stem: During an EEG, a patient becomes unresponsive with no pulse. The technologist should:
options: Continue recording to document the event
Immediately activate emergency response (Code Blue), begin CPR if trained, and ensure patient safety (recording can continue if it doesn't interfere)
Wait to see if patient recovers
Only call for help if patient doesn't recover in 1 minute
questions.explanation: Cardiac arrest requires immediate activation of emergency response (Code Blue), beginning CPR if trained, and ensuring patient safety. Recording can continue if it doesn't interfere with emergency care.

questions.stem: A technologist leaves a patient's EEG report visible on a computer screen in an unsecured area. This is:
options: Acceptable if no one is around
HIPAA violation - PHI must be protected from unauthorized access, screens should be secured or logged out
Acceptable if the report is not sensitive
Acceptable if it's only for a few minutes
questions.explanation: Leaving PHI visible on unsecured screens violates HIPAA. PHI must be protected from unauthorized access - screens should be secured or logged out when unattended. Understanding HIPAA security requirements is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist documents: 'The EEG pattern is diagnostic of absence epilepsy.' This documentation is:
options: Appropriate - technologists can diagnose epilepsy types
Inappropriate - technologists should describe patterns objectively (e.g., 'generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave') without diagnostic conclusions
Appropriate if the pattern is classic
questions.explanation: Technologists should describe patterns objectively (e.g., 'generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave') without diagnostic conclusions like 'diagnostic of absence epilepsy'. Understanding scope of practice is critical.

questions.stem: Equipment calibration checks should be performed:
options: Regularly according to facility protocol (typically daily or before each study)
questions.explanation: Calibration checks should be performed regularly according to facility protocol (typically daily or before each study). Regular calibration ensures signal accuracy and equipment reliability.

questions.stem: A technologist discusses a patient's case with a friend who is also a healthcare worker but not involved in the patient's care. This is:
options: Acceptable since the friend is a healthcare worker
Unacceptable - sharing PHI with anyone not involved in patient care violates HIPAA and confidentiality, regardless of their profession
Acceptable if the friend promises not to tell anyone
Acceptable if no names are mentioned
questions.explanation: Sharing PHI with anyone not involved in patient care violates HIPAA and confidentiality, regardless of their profession. Understanding HIPAA authorization requirements is critical.

questions.stem: Personal protective equipment (PPE) should be used:
options: Only for patients with known infections
According to standard precautions and facility protocol (based on anticipated exposure, not just known infections)
Only if the patient requests it
questions.explanation: PPE should be used according to standard precautions and facility protocol, based on anticipated exposure, not just known infections. Standard precautions apply to ALL patients.

questions.stem: A technologist notices a potential error in a physician's interpretation. The technologist should:
options: Privately discuss concerns with the physician or supervisor in a professional, respectful manner
Ignore it since physicians are always correct
Document it in the patient's chart without discussing
questions.explanation: Concerns about interpretations should be discussed privately with the physician or supervisor in a professional, respectful manner. Understanding professional communication and teamwork is critical.

questions.stem: A technologist accesses a patient's EEG records for a study they are not involved in, out of curiosity. This is:
options: Acceptable if no one finds out
HIPAA violation - accessing PHI without job-related need violates 'minimum necessary' rule and patient privacy
Acceptable if the patient is a friend
Acceptable if the records are interesting
questions.explanation: Accessing PHI without job-related need violates HIPAA's 'minimum necessary' rule and patient privacy. Understanding HIPAA access requirements is critical - only access PHI needed for job duties.

questions.stem: A technologist documents: 'The EEG findings are consistent with a good prognosis.' This documentation is:
options: Inappropriate - technologists should describe findings objectively without prognostic assessment or clinical interpretation
Appropriate if the findings are clearly positive
questions.explanation: Technologists should describe findings objectively without prognostic assessment or clinical interpretation. 'Good prognosis' is a clinical interpretation beyond scope of practice.

questions.stem: OSHA requires that healthcare workers:
options: Follow standard precautions, use appropriate PPE, and follow facility safety protocols
Only follow safety protocols in high-risk areas
Only follow safety protocols if they choose to
questions.explanation: OSHA requires following standard precautions, using appropriate PPE, and following facility safety protocols. Understanding workplace safety regulations is critical for compliance.

questions.stem: During an EEG, a patient has a seizure that lasts 6 minutes without stopping. The technologist should:
options: Continue monitoring and wait for it to stop
Immediately activate emergency response (status epilepticus - medical emergency requiring immediate intervention)
Only call if it lasts >10 minutes
questions.explanation: Seizures >5 minutes without stopping indicate status epilepticus, a medical emergency requiring immediate activation of emergency response. Understanding emergency response protocols is critical.

questions.stem: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) are most commonly associated with:
options: Acute stroke (ischemic or hemorrhagic) - most common cause, but also seen in HSE, brain tumors, trauma, and other acute structural lesions
questions.explanation: PLEDs are most commonly associated with acute stroke (ischemic or hemorrhagic), but are also seen in herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE), brain tumors, traumatic brain injury, intracerebral hemorrhage, and other acute structural lesions. Understanding PLEDs associations is critical for interpretation.

questions.stem: PLEDs are classically associated with which infectious condition?
questions.explanation: PLEDs are classically associated with herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE), though they are also seen in many other conditions including stroke, tumors, and trauma. Understanding this classic association is important for pattern recognition.

questions.stem: PLEDs are characterized by:
options: Periodic, lateralized (unilateral) epileptiform discharges occurring at regular intervals (typically 0.5–2 Hz)
questions.explanation: PLEDs are periodic, lateralized (unilateral) epileptiform discharges occurring at regular intervals (typically 0.5–2 Hz). They are lateralized, distinguishing them from bilateral periodic patterns like PSWCs (CJD) or GPDs.

questions.stem: How do PLEDs differ from periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) seen in CJD?
options: PLEDs are lateralized (unilateral); PSWCs are bilateral and synchronous
PLEDs are only seen in sleep
questions.explanation: PLEDs are lateralized (unilateral), while PSWCs are bilateral and synchronous. This is a key distinguishing feature. PLEDs indicate focal cortical dysfunction; PSWCs are characteristic of CJD (generalized prion disease).

questions.stem: PLEDs may be:
options: Ictal or interictal - clinical correlation is essential for interpretation
questions.explanation: PLEDs may be ictal or interictal. Clinical correlation is essential for interpretation. They indicate acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction and require clinical context to determine significance.

questions.stem: PLEDs are seen in all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Normal sleep (PLEDs are always abnormal, indicating acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction)
questions.explanation: PLEDs are always abnormal and indicate acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction. They are NOT seen in normal sleep. PLEDs are associated with acute stroke, HSE, brain tumors, trauma, and other acute structural lesions.

questions.stem: PLEDs typically occur at what frequency?
questions.explanation: PLEDs typically occur at 0.5–2 Hz, meaning they recur at regular intervals every 0.5–2 seconds. This periodic nature is a key characteristic distinguishing them from other patterns.

questions.stem: PLEDs are:
questions.explanation: PLEDs are lateralized (unilateral or predominantly one hemisphere). This lateralization distinguishes them from generalized periodic patterns like GPDs or PSWCs. The lateralization indicates focal cortical dysfunction.

questions.stem: PLEDs may be seen after:
options: Acute stroke, traumatic brain injury, recent neurosurgery, intracerebral hemorrhage, and other acute structural lesions
questions.explanation: PLEDs may be seen after acute stroke, traumatic brain injury, recent neurosurgery, intracerebral hemorrhage, and other acute structural lesions. They indicate acute/subacute focal cortical dysfunction.

questions.stem: PLEDs are often associated with:
options: Focal slowing and background suppression in the affected region
questions.explanation: PLEDs are often associated with focal slowing and background suppression in the affected region. These associated findings help confirm the focal nature of the dysfunction and support the PLEDs pattern.

questions.stem: The precentral gyrus is located in which lobe?
options: Frontal lobe (primary motor cortex, Brodmann area 4)
questions.explanation: The precentral gyrus is located in the frontal lobe and corresponds to the primary motor cortex (M1, Brodmann area 4). It lies anterior to the central sulcus and is responsible for voluntary motor control of the contralateral body. Understanding motor cortex localization is critical for EEG interpretation.

questions.stem: Focal epileptiform discharges over the precentral gyrus (motor cortex) would be best detected by electrodes:
questions.explanation: The precentral gyrus (motor cortex) is located in the central region, best detected by C3/C4 electrodes. Understanding electrode correlations with cortical anatomy is critical for localization.

questions.stem: The most common site for brain tumors in children is:
options: Posterior fossa (cerebellum, brainstem, fourth ventricle) - accounts for ~60% of childhood brain tumors
questions.explanation: The posterior fossa (cerebellum, brainstem, fourth ventricle) is the most common site for brain tumors in children, accounting for ~60% of cases. This contrasts with adults, where supratentorial tumors are more common. Understanding age-specific tumor locations is important for clinical correlation.

questions.stem: The most common malignant brain tumor in children is:
options: Medulloblastoma (most common malignant brain tumor in children, located in posterior fossa/cerebellum)
questions.explanation: Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, typically located in the posterior fossa (cerebellum). Understanding pediatric tumor types and locations is important for clinical correlation.

questions.stem: Posterior fossa tumors in children typically:
options: Do not produce focal epileptiform discharges unless there is supratentorial involvement or secondary effects (e.g., hydrocephalus)
questions.explanation: Posterior fossa tumors usually do not produce focal epileptiform discharges unless there is supratentorial involvement or secondary effects (e.g., obstructive hydrocephalus). Understanding tumor location and EEG correlation is important for interpretation.

questions.stem: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is characterized by:
options: Rapidly progressive dementia over weeks to months, with myoclonus, cerebellar dysfunction, and periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) on EEG
questions.explanation: CJD is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia over weeks to months (not years), with myoclonus, cerebellar dysfunction, and periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) at 1-2 Hz on EEG. Understanding CJD clinical presentation and EEG correlation is critical.

questions.stem: In Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), myoclonus is:
options: Common and often stimulus-sensitive (sound, touch, light), correlating with periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) on EEG
questions.explanation: In CJD, myoclonus is common and often stimulus-sensitive (sound, touch, light), correlating with periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) on EEG. Understanding CJD clinical-EEG correlation is important for recognition.

questions.stem: In Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), the EEG:
options: Is always diagnostic from the start
May be normal or nonspecific early, becoming diagnostic later with periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs)
questions.explanation: In CJD, the EEG may be normal or nonspecific early in the disease, becoming diagnostic later with periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) at 1-2 Hz. Absence of PSWCs does not exclude CJD, especially early or in variant forms.

questions.stem: First-line treatment for infantile spasms (West syndrome) includes:
options: Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) or high-dose oral corticosteroids (prednisolone), and vigabatrin (especially for tuberous sclerosis)
questions.explanation: First-line treatment for infantile spasms includes ACTH (gold standard) or high-dose oral corticosteroids (prednisolone), and vigabatrin (especially for tuberous sclerosis). Treatment is urgent as delayed control is associated with poor neurodevelopmental outcomes.

questions.stem: Successful treatment of infantile spasms is indicated by:
options: Cessation of spasms and improvement or normalization of EEG (resolution of hypsarrhythmia)
questions.explanation: Successful treatment of infantile spasms is indicated by both cessation of spasms and improvement or normalization of EEG (resolution of hypsarrhythmia). Persistent hypsarrhythmia indicates poor prognosis. Understanding treatment response criteria is critical.

questions.stem: Vigabatrin, used in treatment of infantile spasms, requires:
options: Ophthalmologic monitoring due to risk of irreversible peripheral visual field constriction
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin requires ophthalmologic monitoring due to risk of irreversible peripheral visual field constriction. This is a major concern with vigabatrin therapy. Understanding medication side effects and monitoring requirements is important.

questions.stem: The single most effective measure for preventing nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections is:
options: Strict hand hygiene (hand washing with soap/water when visibly soiled, alcohol-based hand rubs before/after patient contact)
questions.explanation: Strict hand hygiene is the single most effective measure for preventing nosocomial infections, reducing hospital-acquired infections by up to 50%. Hand washing with soap/water when visibly soiled, and alcohol-based hand rubs before/after patient contact, are essential.

questions.stem: Effective prevention of nosocomial infections requires:
options: Hand hygiene + aseptic technique + early isolation (foundation of infection prevention)
questions.explanation: Effective prevention of nosocomial infections requires hand hygiene + aseptic technique + early isolation. These form the foundation of infection prevention. Technology, antibiotics, and protocols cannot compensate for poor compliance with these basics.

questions.stem: Proper sterilization and disinfection of EEG equipment is essential to prevent:
options: Device-related infections and transmission of pathogens (critical for infection prevention)
questions.explanation: Proper sterilization and disinfection of EEG equipment (electrodes, probes, etc.) is essential to prevent device-related infections and transmission of pathogens. Failure here directly increases bloodstream and device-related infections.

questions.stem: Antimicrobial stewardship in preventing nosocomial infections involves:
options: Avoiding unnecessary antibiotics, using correct drug/dose/duration to prevent emergence of multidrug-resistant organisms (MDROs)
questions.explanation: Antimicrobial stewardship involves avoiding unnecessary antibiotics and using correct drug/dose/duration to prevent emergence of multidrug-resistant organisms (MDROs). This is a key component of infection prevention.

questions.stem: Acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas) arise from which cranial nerve?
options: Cranial Nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear) - specifically the vestibular portion
questions.explanation: Acoustic neuromas (vestibular schwannomas) arise from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII), specifically from Schwann cells of the vestibular division. They are located in the cerebellopontine angle (CPA) and internal auditory canal.

questions.stem: Thrombosis of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) would most likely cause:
options: Left-sided weakness and sensory loss (face and arm > leg), left homonymous hemianopia, and left hemispatial neglect (classic for right MCA)
questions.explanation: Right MCA thrombosis causes contralateral (left-sided) motor and sensory deficits (face and arm > leg), left homonymous hemianopia, and left hemispatial neglect. Left hemispatial neglect is the key distinguishing feature of a RIGHT MCA stroke. Aphasia is more typical of LEFT (dominant) MCA strokes.

questions.stem: Aphasia is most commonly associated with:
options: Left (dominant) MCA stroke (affects language centers in dominant hemisphere)
questions.explanation: Aphasia is most commonly associated with left (dominant) MCA stroke, which affects language centers in the dominant hemisphere. Right MCA strokes typically cause hemispatial neglect rather than aphasia.

questions.stem: Papilledema (bilateral optic disc swelling) is commonly associated with:
options: Raised intracranial pressure (ICP) - caused by brain tumors, hydrocephalus, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, meningitis, intracranial hemorrhage, or severe head injury
questions.explanation: Papilledema is bilateral optic disc swelling caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Common causes include brain tumors, hydrocephalus, idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, meningitis, intracranial hemorrhage, or severe head injury. Papilledema = raised ICP until proven otherwise.

questions.stem: Papilledema differs from optic neuritis in that papilledema:
options: Causes early vision loss and pain with eye movement
Is usually bilateral, caused by raised ICP, and vision is often initially preserved (no early vision loss, no pain with eye movement)
questions.explanation: Papilledema is usually bilateral, caused by raised ICP, and vision is often initially preserved (no early vision loss, no pain with eye movement). Optic neuritis is often unilateral, causes early vision loss and pain with eye movement, and is due to inflammation.

questions.stem: Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is characterized by:
options: Genetic multisystem disorder with benign hamartomas, seizures (often infantile spasms), intellectual disability, and facial angiofibromas (Vogt triad)
questions.explanation: Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a genetic multisystem disorder characterized by benign hamartomas in multiple organs, seizures (often infantile spasms), intellectual disability, and facial angiofibromas (Vogt triad). It involves brain (cortical tubers), skin, kidneys, heart, and lungs.

questions.stem: Vigabatrin is especially indicated for infantile spasms associated with:
options: All causes of infantile spasms equally
Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) - first-line choice for TSC-related infantile spasms
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin is especially indicated for infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) and is the first-line choice for TSC-related infantile spasms. Understanding TSC-specific treatment is important for clinical management.

questions.stem: EEG findings in tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) with infantile spasms typically include:
options: Hypsarrhythmia and multifocal epileptiform discharges (cortical tubers are epileptogenic foci)
questions.explanation: EEG findings in TSC with infantile spasms typically include hypsarrhythmia and multifocal epileptiform discharges. Cortical tubers are epileptogenic foci, leading to multifocal discharges. Understanding TSC EEG patterns is important for diagnosis and management.

questions.stem: Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is characterized by:
options: Facial port-wine stain (trigeminal V1 distribution), leptomeningeal angiomas, and early-onset focal seizures (classic triad)
questions.explanation: Sturge-Weber syndrome is characterized by facial port-wine stain (trigeminal V1 distribution), leptomeningeal angiomas, and early-onset focal seizures (classic triad). It is a sporadic neurocutaneous disorder (not inherited) with unilateral focal EEG abnormalities corresponding to the side of the leptomeningeal angioma.

questions.stem: EEG findings in Sturge-Weber syndrome typically include:
options: Unilateral focal slowing, focal epileptiform discharges, and background asymmetry (affected hemisphere) - corresponding to the side of the leptomeningeal angioma
questions.explanation: EEG findings in Sturge-Weber syndrome typically include unilateral focal slowing, focal epileptiform discharges, and background asymmetry (affected hemisphere). These abnormalities correspond to the side of the leptomeningeal angioma. Understanding SWS EEG patterns is important for diagnosis.

questions.stem: Binocular diplopia (present when both eyes open, disappears when one eye closed) is most commonly caused by:
options: Cranial nerve palsies (CN III, IV, VI), brainstem lesions, or neuromuscular junction disorders (e.g., myasthenia gravis)
questions.explanation: Binocular diplopia (present when both eyes open, disappears when one eye closed) is most commonly caused by cranial nerve palsies (CN III, IV, VI), brainstem lesions, or neuromuscular junction disorders (e.g., myasthenia gravis). Monocular diplopia (persists with one eye closed) is usually non-neurological (cataract, corneal irregularities).

questions.stem: CN VI (abducens) palsy, causing horizontal diplopia and inability to abduct the eye, is commonly associated with:
options: Raised intracranial pressure (common cause of CN VI palsy)
questions.explanation: CN VI (abducens) palsy, causing horizontal diplopia and inability to abduct the eye, is commonly associated with raised intracranial pressure. This is an important clinical sign of increased ICP. Understanding cranial nerve palsies and their associations is critical for clinical correlation.

questions.stem: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is characterized by:
options: Chronic autoimmune demyelinating disease with dissemination of lesions in time and space, commonly presenting with optic neuritis, sensory symptoms, motor weakness, and internuclear ophthalmoplegia
questions.explanation: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by dissemination of lesions in time and space. Common presentations include optic neuritis, sensory symptoms (Lhermitte sign), motor weakness, internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), and fatigue. MRI shows periventricular plaques (Dawson's fingers).

questions.stem: In multiple sclerosis (MS), the EEG:
options: Is often normal, may show nonspecific focal or diffuse slowing, and is not diagnostic (EEG is supportive, not primary)
questions.explanation: In multiple sclerosis, the EEG is often normal, may show nonspecific focal or diffuse slowing, and is not diagnostic. EEG is supportive (helps exclude seizures or encephalopathy) but not primary for MS diagnosis. MRI is the key diagnostic modality for MS.

questions.stem: A spike or sharp wave arises from:
options: Cerebral cortex, specifically due to synchronous abnormal depolarization of cortical pyramidal neurons (paroxysmal depolarization shift - PDS)
questions.explanation: Spikes and sharp waves arise from the cerebral cortex, specifically due to synchronous abnormal depolarization of cortical pyramidal neurons (paroxysmal depolarization shift - PDS). This cortical origin is why spikes and sharp waves are considered epileptiform. Subcortical structures alone cannot generate spikes visible on scalp EEG.

questions.stem: The difference between a spike and a sharp wave is:
options: Duration: spike <70 ms, sharp wave 70-200 ms (both share the same cortical origin and mechanism)
questions.explanation: The difference between a spike and a sharp wave is duration: spike <70 ms, sharp wave 70-200 ms. Both share the same cortical origin (paroxysmal depolarization shift in cortical pyramidal neurons) and mechanism.

questions.stem: A left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke would most likely cause:
options: Right face and arm weakness only
Right lower limb weakness (leg > arm > face), behavioral changes (abulia, apathy), urinary incontinence, and transcortical motor aphasia
questions.explanation: Left ACA stroke causes contralateral (right-sided) lower-limb–predominant deficits (leg > arm > face), behavioral changes (abulia, apathy), urinary incontinence, and transcortical motor aphasia. This contrasts with MCA stroke (face/arm > leg) and PCA stroke (visual defects).

questions.stem: Characteristic features of anterior cerebral artery (ACA) stroke include:
options: Lower limb weakness (leg > arm), gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and frontal lobe behavioral changes (abulia, apathy)
questions.explanation: ACA stroke characteristically causes lower limb weakness (leg > arm > face), gait disturbance, urinary incontinence (medial frontal micturition center), and frontal lobe behavioral changes (abulia, apathy, poor judgment). Understanding ACA territory symptoms is important for localization.

questions.stem: The occipital lobe receives its primary arterial blood supply from:
options: Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) - supplies occipital lobe (visual cortex), inferior temporal lobe, and thalamus
questions.explanation: The occipital lobe receives its primary arterial blood supply from the posterior cerebral artery (PCA), which is a terminal branch of the basilar artery. The calcarine artery, a branch of the PCA, specifically supplies the primary visual cortex (V1).

questions.stem: A posterior cerebral artery (PCA) infarct would most likely cause:
options: Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (visual field defect) due to occipital lobe involvement
questions.explanation: PCA infarct causes contralateral homonymous hemianopia due to occipital lobe (visual cortex) involvement. Often with macular sparing due to collateral supply from the MCA. Understanding PCA territory symptoms is important for localization.

questions.stem: The earliest and most common sign of phenytoin (Dilantin) toxicity is:
options: Horizontal nystagmus (earliest and most common sign)
questions.explanation: Horizontal nystagmus is the earliest and most common sign of phenytoin toxicity. Other early signs include dizziness, blurred or double vision, and nausea. Understanding phenytoin toxicity signs is important for clinical correlation.

questions.stem: Moderate phenytoin (Dilantin) toxicity is characterized by:
options: Ataxia, gait instability, slurred speech (dysarthria), tremor, and incoordination
questions.explanation: Moderate phenytoin toxicity is characterized by ataxia, gait instability, limb incoordination, slurred speech (dysarthria), and tremor. This progresses from early signs (nystagmus) and can progress to severe toxicity (confusion, coma, seizures).

questions.stem: In severe phenytoin (Dilantin) toxicity, the EEG may show:
questions.explanation: In severe phenytoin toxicity, the EEG may show diffuse slowing due to CNS depression. Severe toxicity includes marked CNS depression, confusion/delirium, lethargy → coma, and paradoxical seizures. Understanding AED toxicity and EEG correlation is important.

questions.stem: Chronic phenytoin (Dilantin) toxicity may include:
options: Gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, coarsening of facial features, peripheral neuropathy, osteomalacia, and folate deficiency
questions.explanation: Chronic phenytoin toxicity includes gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, coarsening of facial features, peripheral neuropathy, osteomalacia/vitamin D deficiency, and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia). Understanding chronic vs acute toxicity is important.

questions.stem: Precocious puberty is most classically associated with:
options: Hypothalamic hamartoma (benign congenital lesion causing premature HPG axis activation)
questions.explanation: Precocious puberty is most classically associated with hypothalamic hamartoma, a benign congenital lesion of the hypothalamus that causes premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. This leads to GnRH secretion independent of normal pubertal timing.

questions.stem: Hypothalamic hamartoma is highly characteristic of which seizure type?
options: Gelastic seizures (laughing seizures) - highly characteristic of hypothalamic hamartoma
questions.explanation: Hypothalamic hamartoma is highly characteristic of gelastic seizures (laughing seizures). The classic presentation is precocious puberty + gelastic seizures = hypothalamic hamartoma until proven otherwise. Understanding this association is important for diagnosis.

questions.stem: The classic clinical presentation of hypothalamic hamartoma includes:
options: Precocious puberty + gelastic seizures (laughing seizures) + behavioral problems or developmental delay (variable)
questions.explanation: The classic clinical presentation of hypothalamic hamartoma includes precocious puberty (often very young), gelastic seizures (laughing seizures - highly characteristic), and behavioral problems or developmental delay (variable). Understanding this classic triad is important for recognition.

questions.stem: In neurophysiology, SDS stands for:
options: Sharp Waves with Delta Slowing (epileptiform sharp waves superimposed on focal or regional delta slowing)
questions.explanation: In neurophysiology, SDS stands for Sharp Waves with Delta Slowing - an EEG pattern characterized by epileptiform sharp waves superimposed on focal or regional delta slowing. This combination strongly suggests underlying focal cortical pathology (focal epilepsy, brain tumors, stroke, cortical dysplasia).

questions.stem: Sharp Waves with Delta Slowing (SDS) on EEG is commonly associated with:
options: Focal cortical pathology - focal epilepsy, brain tumors, stroke (subacute/chronic), cortical dysplasia, or post-traumatic cortical injury
questions.explanation: Sharp Waves with Delta Slowing (SDS) indicates structural or functional cortical abnormality and is commonly associated with focal epilepsy, brain tumors, stroke (subacute/chronic), cortical dysplasia, or post-traumatic cortical injury. This pattern suggests epileptogenic cortex with structural correlation.

questions.stem: Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) has an onset:
options: In infancy, often at birth or within the first year of life (port-wine stain at birth, seizures typically begin in infancy)
questions.explanation: Sturge-Weber syndrome has an onset in infancy, often at birth or within the first year of life. The facial port-wine stain is usually visible from birth, and seizures typically begin in infancy (often before 1 year of age), usually as focal seizures that may secondarily generalize.

questions.stem: The classic presentation of Sturge-Weber syndrome includes:
options: Port-wine stain present at birth + seizures starting in infancy (within the first year of life)
questions.explanation: The classic presentation of Sturge-Weber syndrome includes port-wine stain (nevus flammeus) present at birth (usually in V1 trigeminal distribution) and seizures starting in infancy (within the first year of life). This early onset is characteristic and helps distinguish SWS from other neurocutaneous syndromes.

questions.stem: A tangle of arteries and veins with a tendency to bleed is called:
options: Arteriovenous malformation (AVM) - abnormal direct connection between arteries and veins with no intervening capillary bed
questions.explanation: An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal direct connection between arteries and veins with no intervening capillary bed, resulting in high-pressure arterial flow entering veins. This causes vessel wall weakening and risk of intracranial hemorrhage, especially in young patients.

questions.stem: An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) may present with EEG findings of:
options: Focal slowing or epileptiform discharges if cortex is involved (may also present with intracerebral hemorrhage, seizures, headache, or focal neurological deficits)
questions.explanation: An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) may present with focal slowing or epileptiform discharges on EEG if the cortex is involved. AVMs may also present clinically with intracerebral hemorrhage, seizures, headache, or focal neurological deficits.

questions.stem: The third ventricle communicates with the lateral ventricles through the:
options: Interventricular foramen (Foramen of Monro) - there are two, one for each lateral ventricle
questions.explanation: The third ventricle communicates with the lateral ventricles through the interventricular foramen (Foramen of Monro). There are two foramina of Monro, one for each lateral ventricle, allowing CSF flow from the lateral ventricles into the third ventricle.

questions.stem: Obstruction at the foramen of Monro may cause:
options: Unilateral or bilateral hydrocephalus (common causes include colloid cysts, tumors, or intraventricular hemorrhage)
questions.explanation: Obstruction at the foramen of Monro may cause unilateral or bilateral hydrocephalus. Common causes of blockage include colloid cysts, tumors, or intraventricular hemorrhage. Understanding ventricular anatomy and CSF flow is important for recognizing hydrocephalus patterns.

questions.stem: With larger acoustic neuromas, which cranial nerve is most commonly affected secondarily?
options: CN VII (facial nerve) - compression by larger tumors causes facial weakness
questions.explanation: With larger acoustic neuromas, CN VII (facial nerve) is most commonly affected secondarily, causing facial weakness. CN V (trigeminal) compression may also occur, causing facial numbness. Understanding cranial nerve involvement patterns helps localize tumor size and location.

questions.stem: Acoustic neuromas typically cause:
options: Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (most common presenting symptom)
questions.explanation: Acoustic neuromas typically cause progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, which is the most common presenting symptom. Other symptoms include tinnitus, vertigo/imbalance, and with larger tumors, facial nerve (CN VII) involvement and trigeminal nerve (CN V) compression.

questions.stem: The cerebellopontine angle (CPA) is a common location for which tumors?
options: Acoustic neuromas (most common), meningiomas, epidermoid cysts, and other CPA tumors
questions.explanation: The cerebellopontine angle (CPA) is a common location for acoustic neuromas (most common CPA tumor), meningiomas, epidermoid cysts, and other CPA tumors. Understanding CPA tumor differentials is important for diagnosis and management.

questions.stem: Bilateral acoustic neuromas are characteristic of:
options: Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) - bilateral acoustic neuromas are pathognomonic
questions.explanation: Bilateral acoustic neuromas are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and are pathognomonic for this condition. NF2 is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NF2 gene (merlin/schwannomin).

questions.stem: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) has which main branches?
options: Superior (M2) and inferior (M3) divisions, with M1 (horizontal segment) and M4 (cortical branches)
questions.explanation: The middle cerebral artery has M1 (horizontal segment), M2 (superior division), M3 (inferior division), and M4 (cortical branches). Understanding MCA branches helps localize stroke territories and predict clinical deficits.

questions.stem: The MCA superior division supplies:
options: Frontal and parietal lobes (motor and sensory cortex for face and arm)
questions.explanation: The MCA superior division supplies the frontal and parietal lobes, including the motor and sensory cortex for the face and arm. This explains why MCA strokes cause face and arm weakness more than leg weakness (leg is supplied by ACA).

questions.stem: In acute MCA stroke, the EEG may show:
options: Focal slowing over the affected hemisphere, attenuation of background activity, and may show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) in subacute phase
questions.explanation: In acute MCA stroke, the EEG may show focal slowing over the affected hemisphere, attenuation of background activity, and may show periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) in the subacute phase. Understanding stroke EEG patterns helps with clinical correlation.

questions.stem: Complications of large MCA strokes include:
options: Malignant MCA infarction (massive edema), herniation risk, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure
questions.explanation: Complications of large MCA strokes include malignant MCA infarction (massive edema), herniation risk, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure. Large MCA strokes can be life-threatening due to mass effect and require close monitoring.

questions.stem: Left MCA stroke (dominant hemisphere) is distinguished from right MCA stroke by:
options: Aphasia (language impairment) - left MCA affects language centers; right MCA causes hemispatial neglect
questions.explanation: Left MCA stroke (dominant hemisphere) is distinguished by aphasia (language impairment) as it affects language centers. Right MCA stroke causes hemispatial neglect. Both cause contralateral motor and sensory deficits, but the cortical signs differ.

questions.stem: In papilledema, visual acuity is:
options: Often initially preserved (early stages), but may be affected later with chronic papilledema or optic atrophy
questions.explanation: In papilledema, visual acuity is often initially preserved in early stages, distinguishing it from optic neuritis. However, visual acuity may be affected later with chronic papilledema or optic atrophy. Transient visual obscurations are common early symptoms.

questions.stem: Papilledema can be distinguished from pseudopapilledema (optic disc drusen) by:
options: Papilledema shows venous engorgement, hemorrhages, and elevated ICP; pseudopapilledema (drusen) shows buried drusen, no hemorrhages, and normal ICP
questions.explanation: Papilledema shows venous engorgement, hemorrhages, and elevated ICP, while pseudopapilledema (optic disc drusen) shows buried drusen, no hemorrhages, and normal ICP. Distinguishing these is critical as papilledema requires urgent treatment of raised ICP.

questions.stem: Before performing a lumbar puncture in a patient with papilledema, it is essential to:
options: Exclude space-occupying lesions by imaging (CT or MRI) - LP can cause herniation if there is mass effect
questions.explanation: Before performing a lumbar puncture in a patient with papilledema, it is essential to exclude space-occupying lesions by imaging (CT or MRI). LP can cause herniation if there is mass effect and raised ICP. This is a critical safety consideration.

questions.stem: Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is caused by mutations in:
options: TSC1 (hamartin, chromosome 9) or TSC2 (tuberin, chromosome 16) - leads to overactivation of mTOR pathway
questions.explanation: Tuberous sclerosis complex is caused by mutations in TSC1 (hamartin, chromosome 9) or TSC2 (tuberin, chromosome 16), leading to overactivation of the mTOR pathway and abnormal cell growth. Many cases are sporadic (new mutations).

questions.stem: Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (SEGA) in tuberous sclerosis:
options: Is always benign and never causes problems
May cause obstructive hydrocephalus and requires monitoring (often near foramen of Monro)
questions.explanation: Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (SEGA) in tuberous sclerosis may cause obstructive hydrocephalus (often near foramen of Monro) and requires monitoring. Progressive hydrocephalus in TSC should raise suspicion for SEGA. Treatment may include mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus) or surgery.

questions.stem: The most common cutaneous feature of tuberous sclerosis is:
options: Hypomelanotic ash-leaf spots (best seen with Wood's lamp) - most common and often earliest sign
questions.explanation: The most common cutaneous feature of tuberous sclerosis is hypomelanotic ash-leaf spots, which are best seen with Wood's lamp and are often the earliest sign. Other features include facial angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and periungual fibromas (Koenen tumors).

questions.stem: Renal angiomyolipomas in tuberous sclerosis:
options: Are always benign and never cause problems
May cause bleeding and require monitoring (risk of hemorrhage, especially if large)
questions.explanation: Renal angiomyolipomas in tuberous sclerosis may cause bleeding and require monitoring, especially if large. They carry a risk of hemorrhage. Treatment may include mTOR inhibitors or embolization. Regular monitoring is important for TSC patients.

questions.stem: The classic MRI finding in multiple sclerosis is:
options: T2/FLAIR hyperintense periventricular plaques (Dawson's fingers) - perpendicular to ventricles, characteristic of MS
questions.explanation: The classic MRI finding in multiple sclerosis is T2/FLAIR hyperintense periventricular plaques, often called Dawson's fingers because they appear perpendicular to the ventricles. This pattern is characteristic of MS and helps distinguish it from other demyelinating diseases.

questions.stem: CSF findings in multiple sclerosis typically include:
options: Oligoclonal IgG bands and elevated IgG index (supportive but not diagnostic)
questions.explanation: CSF findings in multiple sclerosis typically include oligoclonal IgG bands and elevated IgG index. These are supportive findings but not diagnostic alone. MRI is the key diagnostic modality for MS. CSF helps support the diagnosis and exclude other conditions.

questions.stem: The most common clinical course of multiple sclerosis is:
options: Relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS) - most common, characterized by relapses and remissions
questions.explanation: The most common clinical course of multiple sclerosis is relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS), characterized by relapses (acute attacks) and remissions (recovery). Many patients eventually transition to secondary progressive MS (SPMS) with progressive disability.

questions.stem: Multiple sclerosis must be distinguished from:
options: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMO), acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), CNS vasculitis, vitamin B12 deficiency, and other demyelinating conditions
questions.explanation: Multiple sclerosis must be distinguished from neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMO), acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM), CNS vasculitis, vitamin B12 deficiency, sarcoidosis, HIV-related demyelination, and other conditions. NMO is particularly important as it has different treatment.

questions.stem: The classic CT finding in Sturge-Weber syndrome is:
options: Tram-track calcifications (appear with age) - gyriform calcifications following cortical sulci
questions.explanation: The classic CT finding in Sturge-Weber syndrome is tram-track calcifications (gyriform calcifications following cortical sulci), which appear with age. MRI with contrast shows leptomeningeal enhancement and cortical atrophy. Understanding imaging findings helps with diagnosis.

questions.stem: Treatment options for Sturge-Weber syndrome include:
options: Aggressive seizure control (often polytherapy), low-dose aspirin (to reduce stroke-like episodes), and epilepsy surgery (for medically refractory cases)
questions.explanation: Treatment options for Sturge-Weber syndrome include aggressive seizure control (often polytherapy), low-dose aspirin (used in some patients to reduce stroke-like episodes due to venous congestion), and epilepsy surgery (considered in medically refractory epilepsy, including hemispherotomy).

questions.stem: CN III (oculomotor) palsy with pupil involvement suggests:
options: Compression (e.g., aneurysm, uncal herniation) - pupil-sparing CN III palsy suggests microvascular ischemia (diabetes, hypertension)
questions.explanation: CN III palsy with pupil involvement suggests compression (e.g., posterior communicating artery aneurysm, uncal herniation). Pupil-sparing CN III palsy suggests microvascular ischemia (diabetes, hypertension). This distinction is critical as compressive lesions require urgent evaluation.

questions.stem: CN IV (trochlear) palsy causes:
options: Vertical diplopia (worse on looking down stairs or reading) - CN IV innervates superior oblique muscle
questions.explanation: CN IV (trochlear) palsy causes vertical diplopia, which is worse on looking down stairs or reading, as CN IV innervates the superior oblique muscle. This is a common pattern and helps localize the lesion.

questions.stem: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is caused by:
options: Lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) - causes impaired adduction of affected eye and nystagmus of abducting eye
questions.explanation: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is caused by a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), resulting in impaired adduction of the affected eye and nystagmus of the abducting eye. INO is classic for multiple sclerosis in young patients.

questions.stem: The mechanism underlying spike and sharp wave generation is:
options: Paroxysmal depolarization shift (PDS) - sudden excessive hypersynchronous neuronal firing in cortical pyramidal neurons, followed by hyperpolarizing after-potential
questions.explanation: The mechanism underlying spike and sharp wave generation is the paroxysmal depolarization shift (PDS) - a sudden, excessive, hypersynchronous neuronal firing in cortical pyramidal neurons, followed by a hyperpolarizing after-potential (inhibitory phase). This is the fundamental mechanism of epileptiform activity.

questions.stem: Benign sharp transients (e.g., BETS, SSS) can be distinguished from epileptiform spikes by:
options: Lack of aftergoing slow wave, no disruption of background, low amplitude, short duration, and absence of clinical correlation (benign transients lack these features)
questions.explanation: Benign sharp transients (e.g., BETS, SSS) can be distinguished from epileptiform spikes by lack of aftergoing slow wave, no disruption of background, low amplitude, short duration, and absence of clinical correlation. Epileptiform spikes typically have aftergoing slow waves and may disrupt background.

questions.stem: Bilateral ACA stroke may cause:
options: Callosal disconnection syndromes (e.g., alien hand phenomenon, inability to name objects in left hand) - due to corpus callosum involvement
questions.explanation: Bilateral ACA stroke may cause callosal disconnection syndromes, including alien hand phenomenon and inability to name objects in the left hand (due to disconnection of language areas from right hemisphere). These are rare but characteristic of bilateral ACA involvement.

questions.stem: Primitive reflexes commonly seen in ACA stroke include:
options: Grasp reflex and snout reflex (due to frontal lobe involvement)
questions.explanation: Primitive reflexes commonly seen in ACA stroke include grasp reflex and snout reflex, due to frontal lobe involvement. These are release phenomena indicating frontal lobe dysfunction. Understanding these helps localize ACA territory strokes.

questions.stem: PCA stroke may involve the thalamus, causing:
options: Thalamic pain syndrome, sensory loss, memory impairment, and altered consciousness (depending on thalamic nuclei involved)
questions.explanation: PCA stroke may involve the thalamus, causing thalamic pain syndrome, sensory loss, memory impairment, and altered consciousness, depending on which thalamic nuclei are involved. The PCA supplies the thalamus in addition to the occipital lobe.

questions.stem: Top of the basilar syndrome involves:
options: Bilateral PCA territories, thalamus, midbrain, and may cause altered consciousness, visual disturbances, and oculomotor abnormalities
questions.explanation: Top of the basilar syndrome involves bilateral PCA territories, thalamus, and midbrain, and may cause altered consciousness, visual disturbances, and oculomotor abnormalities. This is a severe stroke syndrome with multiple deficits.

questions.stem: Phenytoin toxicity risk is increased by:
options: Liver disease, hypoalbuminemia, and drug interactions (e.g., valproate increases free phenytoin levels)
questions.explanation: Phenytoin toxicity risk is increased by liver disease, hypoalbuminemia, and drug interactions (e.g., valproate increases free phenytoin levels by displacing protein binding). Understanding drug interactions is important for safe medication management.

questions.stem: Therapeutic phenytoin levels are typically:
options: 10-20 µg/mL (therapeutic range) - levels above 20 µg/mL may show nystagmus, above 30 µg/mL show ataxia
questions.explanation: Therapeutic phenytoin levels are typically 10-20 µg/mL. Levels above 20 µg/mL may show nystagmus (earliest sign), above 30 µg/mL show ataxia, and above 40-50 µg/mL show confusion and lethargy. Monitoring levels is important to avoid toxicity.

questions.stem: Phenytoin differs from carbamazepine in that phenytoin:
options: Has non-linear (zero-order) kinetics (small dose increases can cause large level increases), while carbamazepine has linear kinetics
questions.explanation: Phenytoin has non-linear (zero-order) kinetics, meaning small dose increases can cause large level increases, making it prone to toxicity. Carbamazepine has linear kinetics. This is why phenytoin requires careful dose adjustment and monitoring.

questions.stem: Hypothalamic hamartoma is best visualized on:
options: MRI (T1 and T2 weighted images show the hamartoma as a well-defined lesion in the hypothalamus)
questions.explanation: Hypothalamic hamartoma is best visualized on MRI, where T1 and T2 weighted images show the hamartoma as a well-defined lesion in the hypothalamus. CT may miss small hamartomas. MRI is the imaging modality of choice for diagnosis.

questions.stem: Treatment options for hypothalamic hamartoma include:
options: Surgical resection (for gelastic seizures), endoscopic resection, stereotactic radiosurgery, and medical management of precocious puberty
questions.explanation: Treatment options for hypothalamic hamartoma include surgical resection (for gelastic seizures), endoscopic resection, stereotactic radiosurgery, and medical management of precocious puberty. Gelastic seizures are often refractory to medications, making surgery an important option.

questions.stem: In an EEG report, Sharp Waves with Delta Slowing (SDS) should be described as:
options: Focal sharp waves with associated delta slowing over [region], suggesting underlying focal cortical pathology (structural or functional abnormality)
questions.explanation: In an EEG report, Sharp Waves with Delta Slowing should be described as focal sharp waves with associated delta slowing over the affected region, suggesting underlying focal cortical pathology. This pattern indicates epileptogenic cortex with structural correlation.

questions.stem: AVMs are commonly graded using:
options: Spetzler-Martin grading system (size, eloquence of location, venous drainage pattern) - helps determine surgical risk
questions.explanation: AVMs are commonly graded using the Spetzler-Martin grading system, which considers size, eloquence of location, and venous drainage pattern. This helps determine surgical risk and treatment approach. Lower grades (I-III) are more amenable to surgery.

questions.stem: Treatment options for AVMs include:
options: Surgical resection, endovascular embolization, stereotactic radiosurgery, or combination therapy (depending on size, location, and Spetzler-Martin grade)
questions.explanation: Treatment options for AVMs include surgical resection, endovascular embolization, stereotactic radiosurgery, or combination therapy, depending on size, location, and Spetzler-Martin grade. Treatment decisions require multidisciplinary evaluation.

questions.stem: AVMs differ from cavernous malformations in that AVMs:
options: Have high-flow arteriovenous shunting (visible on angiography), while cavernous malformations are low-flow lesions without arteriovenous shunting
questions.explanation: AVMs have high-flow arteriovenous shunting (visible on angiography), while cavernous malformations are low-flow lesions without arteriovenous shunting. AVMs are visible on angiography, while cavernous malformations show characteristic popcorn appearance on MRI but are angiographically occult.

questions.stem: The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle through the:
options: Aqueduct of Sylvius (cerebral aqueduct) - obstruction causes obstructive hydrocephalus
questions.explanation: The third ventricle communicates with the fourth ventricle through the aqueduct of Sylvius (cerebral aqueduct). Obstruction at the aqueduct causes obstructive hydrocephalus. Understanding CSF flow pathways is important for recognizing hydrocephalus patterns.

questions.stem: The fourth ventricle communicates with the subarachnoid space through:
options: Foramen of Magendie (median) and foramina of Luschka (lateral) - allow CSF to exit into subarachnoid space
questions.explanation: The fourth ventricle communicates with the subarachnoid space through the foramen of Magendie (median) and the foramina of Luschka (lateral). These allow CSF to exit the ventricular system into the subarachnoid space. Obstruction causes communicating hydrocephalus.

questions.stem: Obstructive hydrocephalus differs from communicating hydrocephalus in that obstructive:
options: Results from blockage within the ventricular system (e.g., aqueduct stenosis, tumor), while communicating results from impaired CSF absorption (e.g., subarachnoid hemorrhage, meningitis)
questions.explanation: Obstructive hydrocephalus results from blockage within the ventricular system (e.g., aqueduct stenosis, tumor blocking foramen of Monro or aqueduct), while communicating hydrocephalus results from impaired CSF absorption (e.g., subarachnoid hemorrhage, meningitis). This distinction guides treatment.

questions.stem: In hydrocephalus, the EEG may show:
options: Diffuse slowing, especially with increased intracranial pressure, and may show periodic patterns if severe
questions.explanation: In hydrocephalus, the EEG may show diffuse slowing, especially with increased intracranial pressure. Severe hydrocephalus with raised ICP may show periodic patterns. Understanding EEG correlation with hydrocephalus helps with clinical assessment.

questions.stem: Weber syndrome (midbrain stroke) is characterized by:
options: Ipsilateral CN III palsy and contralateral hemiparesis (due to cerebral peduncle involvement)
questions.explanation: Weber syndrome results from midbrain stroke affecting the cerebral peduncle and CN III nucleus/fascicle, causing ipsilateral CN III palsy (ptosis, down and out eye) and contralateral hemiparesis. This localizes to the midbrain.

questions.stem: Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome) is caused by occlusion of:
options: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - causes ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss, Horner syndrome, ataxia, and contralateral body pain/temperature loss
questions.explanation: Wallenberg syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), resulting in lateral medullary infarction. Features include ipsilateral facial pain/temperature loss (CN V), Horner syndrome, ataxia, dysphagia/dysarthria (CN IX/X), and contralateral body pain/temperature loss.

questions.stem: Millard-Gubler syndrome (ventral pontine lesion) causes:
options: Ipsilateral CN VI and CN VII palsies with contralateral hemiparesis (ventral pons lesion)
questions.explanation: Millard-Gubler syndrome results from ventral pontine lesion, causing ipsilateral CN VI palsy (lateral gaze palsy), ipsilateral CN VII palsy (facial weakness), and contralateral hemiparesis. This localizes to the ventral pons.

questions.stem: Vermal (midline) cerebellar lesions cause:
options: Truncal ataxia, gait instability, and nystagmus (midline structures affect balance and coordination)
questions.explanation: Vermal (midline) cerebellar lesions cause truncal ataxia, gait instability, and nystagmus. Midline structures (vermis) are involved in balance and coordination. Hemispheric lesions cause ipsilateral limb ataxia and intention tremor.

questions.stem: Hemispheric cerebellar lesions cause:
options: Ipsilateral limb ataxia, intention tremor, dysmetria, and dysdiadochokinesia (hemispheric lesions affect coordination of ipsilateral limbs)
questions.explanation: Hemispheric cerebellar lesions cause ipsilateral limb ataxia, intention tremor, dysmetria (past-pointing), and dysdiadochokinesia (impaired rapid alternating movements). Cerebellar lesions are ipsilateral because of double decussation of pathways.

questions.stem: Parkinson disease results from degeneration of:
options: Dopamine-producing neurons in substantia nigra pars compacta (leads to bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor, postural instability)
questions.explanation: Parkinson disease results from degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, and postural instability. This disrupts the basal ganglia motor circuit.

questions.stem: Huntington disease is characterized by degeneration of:
options: Basal ganglia, especially caudate nucleus (leads to chorea, cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms)
questions.explanation: Huntington disease is characterized by degeneration of the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, leading to chorea (involuntary movements), cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms. It is an autosomal dominant trinucleotide repeat disorder.

questions.stem: The ventral posterior (VP) nucleus of the thalamus:
options: Processes somatosensory information (receives input from medial lemniscus and spinothalamic tract)
questions.explanation: The ventral posterior (VP) nucleus of the thalamus processes somatosensory information, receiving input from the medial lemniscus (fine touch, proprioception) and spinothalamic tract (pain, temperature). Lesions cause contralateral sensory loss.

questions.stem: Thalamic pain syndrome (Dejerine-Roussy syndrome) is characterized by:
options: Severe, intractable pain in the contralateral body (often burning, dysesthetic) following thalamic stroke
questions.explanation: Thalamic pain syndrome (Dejerine-Roussy syndrome) is characterized by severe, intractable pain in the contralateral body (often burning, dysesthetic) following thalamic stroke, especially involving the ventral posterior nucleus. This is a devastating complication.

questions.stem: Brodmann area 4 corresponds to:
options: Primary motor cortex (M1) in precentral gyrus (controls voluntary movement)
questions.explanation: Brodmann area 4 corresponds to the primary motor cortex (M1) in the precentral gyrus, controlling voluntary movement. Lesions cause contralateral weakness. Area 3,1,2 is primary sensory cortex (postcentral gyrus).

questions.stem: Brodmann area 17 corresponds to:
options: Primary visual cortex (V1) in occipital lobe (calcarine sulcus) - processes visual information
questions.explanation: Brodmann area 17 corresponds to the primary visual cortex (V1) in the occipital lobe (calcarine sulcus), processing visual information. Lesions cause contralateral homonymous hemianopia or quadrantanopia.

questions.stem: Wernicke area (Brodmann area 22) is located in:
options: Posterior superior temporal gyrus (dominant hemisphere) - involved in language comprehension
questions.explanation: Wernicke area (Brodmann area 22) is located in the posterior superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, involved in language comprehension. Lesions cause Wernicke aphasia (fluent speech with poor comprehension).

questions.stem: Broca area (Brodmann area 44, 45) is located in:
options: Inferior frontal gyrus (dominant hemisphere) - involved in language production and speech
questions.explanation: Broca area (Brodmann areas 44, 45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, involved in language production and speech. Lesions cause Broca aphasia (non-fluent speech with preserved comprehension).

questions.stem: Focal aware seizures (formerly simple partial seizures) are characterized by:
options: Preserved awareness and consciousness (patient aware of seizure, can respond)
questions.explanation: Focal aware seizures (formerly simple partial seizures) are characterized by preserved awareness and consciousness - the patient is aware of the seizure and can respond. This distinguishes them from focal impaired awareness seizures.

questions.stem: Focal impaired awareness seizures (formerly complex partial seizures) are characterized by:
options: Impaired awareness or consciousness (patient cannot respond appropriately, may have automatisms)
questions.explanation: Focal impaired awareness seizures (formerly complex partial seizures) are characterized by impaired awareness or consciousness - the patient cannot respond appropriately and may have automatisms (lip smacking, fumbling). This indicates spread to limbic structures.

questions.stem: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by:
options: Tonic phase (rigid extension) followed by clonic phase (rhythmic jerking), with loss of consciousness
questions.explanation: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures are characterized by a tonic phase (rigid extension of limbs, loss of consciousness) followed by a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking), with postictal confusion. This is the most dramatic seizure type.

questions.stem: Status epilepticus is defined as:
options: Seizure lasting more than 5 minutes, or two or more seizures without return to baseline consciousness between them
questions.explanation: Status epilepticus is defined as a seizure lasting more than 5 minutes, or two or more seizures without return to baseline consciousness between them. This is a medical emergency requiring urgent treatment.

questions.stem: Resting tremor is most characteristic of:
options: Parkinson disease (pill-rolling tremor at rest, improves with action)
questions.explanation: Resting tremor is most characteristic of Parkinson disease (pill-rolling tremor at rest, improves with action). Essential tremor is an action/postural tremor. Understanding tremor types helps differentiate movement disorders.

questions.stem: Chorea is characterized by:
options: Brief, irregular, involuntary movements that flow from one body part to another (classic in Huntington disease)
questions.explanation: Chorea is characterized by brief, irregular, involuntary movements that flow from one body part to another, giving a dancing quality. This is classic in Huntington disease but can occur in other conditions (Sydenham chorea, drug-induced).

questions.stem: Dystonia is characterized by:
options: Sustained muscle contractions causing twisting, repetitive movements or abnormal postures
questions.explanation: Dystonia is characterized by sustained muscle contractions causing twisting, repetitive movements or abnormal postures. It can be focal (e.g., writer's cramp, cervical dystonia), segmental, or generalized. May be primary or secondary.

questions.stem: In Alzheimer disease, the EEG typically shows:
options: Diffuse slowing, loss of normal PDR (posterior dominant rhythm), and worsening over time as disease progresses
questions.explanation: In Alzheimer disease, the EEG typically shows diffuse slowing, loss of normal PDR (posterior dominant rhythm), and worsening over time as the disease progresses. Early disease may show minimal changes, but advanced disease shows marked slowing.

questions.stem: In Parkinson disease, the EEG is typically:
options: Usually normal early in disease; mild diffuse slowing may occur late, especially if dementia develops
questions.explanation: In Parkinson disease, the EEG is usually normal early in the disease. Mild diffuse slowing may occur late, especially if Parkinson disease dementia develops. EEG is not diagnostic but helps exclude other conditions (e.g., seizures, encephalopathy).

questions.stem: Dementia with Lewy bodies is characterized by:
options: Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and REM sleep behavior disorder
questions.explanation: Dementia with Lewy bodies is characterized by fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, and REM sleep behavior disorder. It is the second most common cause of dementia after Alzheimer disease. EEG may show slowing.

questions.stem: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis most commonly affects:
options: Temporal lobes (especially medial temporal) - causes focal seizures, memory impairment, behavioral changes
questions.explanation: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis most commonly affects the temporal lobes (especially medial temporal), causing focal seizures, memory impairment, behavioral changes, and fever. EEG may show PLEDs or focal slowing. Urgent treatment with acyclovir is critical.

questions.stem: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is characterized by:
options: Psychiatric symptoms, seizures, movement disorders (orofacial dyskinesias), autonomic instability, and often associated with ovarian teratoma
questions.explanation: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis is characterized by psychiatric symptoms, seizures, movement disorders (orofacial dyskinesias), autonomic instability, and is often associated with ovarian teratoma. EEG may show extreme delta brush pattern. Treatment includes immunotherapy.

questions.stem: Hepatic encephalopathy is characterized on EEG by:
options: Triphasic waves (classic but not pathognomonic), diffuse slowing, and may progress to burst suppression in severe cases
questions.explanation: Hepatic encephalopathy is characterized on EEG by triphasic waves (classic but not pathognomonic - also seen in uremia, other metabolic disorders), diffuse slowing, and may progress to burst suppression in severe cases. EEG helps assess severity.

questions.stem: Severe hypoglycemia on EEG may show:
options: Diffuse slowing, may show epileptiform discharges or seizures, and can progress to isoelectric pattern if severe
questions.explanation: Severe hypoglycemia on EEG may show diffuse slowing, may show epileptiform discharges or seizures, and can progress to isoelectric pattern if severe and prolonged. Hypoglycemia can cause seizures and must be corrected urgently.
